As the end of the day drew on, and he (sergeant) found himself not hired, Gabriel almost wished that he (Gabriel) had joined them, and gone off to serve his (Gabriel) country. Weary of standing in the market- place, and not much minding the kind of work he (Gabriel) turned his (Gabriel) hand to, he (Gabriel) decided to offer himself in some other capacity than that of bailiff. All the farmers seemed to be wanting shepherds. Sheep-tending was Gabriel's speciality. Turning down an obscure street and entering an obscurer lane, he (Gabriel) went up to a smith's shop.
``How long would it take you to make a shepherd's crook?'' (unknown)
``Twenty minutes.'' (unknown)
``How much?'' (unknown)
``Two shillings.'' (He)
He (Gabriel) sat on a bench and the crook was made, a stem being given him (crook) into the bargain. He (crook) then went to a ready-made clothes' shop, the owner of which had a large rural connection. As the crook had absorbed most of Gabriel's money, he (Gabriel) attempted, and carried out, an exchange of his (Gabriel) overcoat for a shepherd's regulation smock-frock. This transaction having been completed, he (Gabriel) again hurried off to the centre of the town, and stood on the kerb of the pavement, as a shepherd, crook in hand. Now that Oak had turned himself into a shepherd, it seemed that bailifs were most in demand. However, two or three farmers noticed him (Oak) and drew near. Dialogues followed, more or lessin the subjoined for: --
``Where do you come from?'' (unknown)
``Norcombe.'' (unknown)
``That's a long way. ``Fifteen miles.'' ``Who's farm were you upon last?'' ``My own.'' This reply invariably operated like a rumour of cholera. The inquiring farmer would edge away and shake his (farmer) head dubiously. Gabriel, like his (Gabriel) dog, was too good to be trustworthy,. and he (Gabriel) never made advance beyond this point. It is safer to accept any chance that offers itself, and extemporize a procedure to fit it, than to get a good shepherd, but had laid himself out for anything in the whole cycle of labour that was required in the fair. It grew dusk. Some merry men were whistling and singing by the corn-exchange. Gabriel's hand, which had lain for some time idle in his (Gabriel) smock-frock pocket, touched his (Gabriel) flute which he (Gabriel) carried there. Here was an opportunity for putting his (Gabriel) dearly bought wisdom into practice. He (Gabriel) drew out his (Gabriel) flute and began to play ``Jockey to the Fair'' in the style of a man who had never known moment's sorrow. Oak could pipe with Arcadian sweetness and the sound of the well-known notes cheered his (Gabriel) own heart as well as those of the loungers. He (Gabriel) played on with spirit, and in half an hour had earned in pence what was a small fortune to a destitute man. By making inquiries he (man) learnt that there was another fair at Shottsford the next day. ``How far is Shottsford?'' ``Ten miles t`other side of Weatherbury.'' Weatherbury! It was where Bathsheba had gone two months before. This information was like coming from night into noon. ``How far is it to Weatherbury?'' ``Five or six miles.'' Bathsheba had probably left Weatherbury long before this time, but the place had enough interest attaching to it to lead Oak to choose Shottsford fair as his (man) next field of inquiry, because it lay in the Weatherbury quarter. Moreover, the Weatherbury folk were by no means uninteresting intrinsically. If report spoke truly they were as hardy, merry, thriving, wicked a set as any in the whole county. Oak resolved to sleep at Weatherbury -- that -- night on his (man) way to Shottsford, and struck out at once -- into the -- high road which had been recommended as the direct route to the village in question. The road stretched through water-meadows traversed by little brooks, whose quivering surfaces were braided along their centres, and folded into creases at the sides; or, where the flow was more rapid, the stream was pied with spots of white froth, which rode on in undisturbed serenity. On the higher levels the dead and dry carcasses of leaves tapped the ground as they bowled along helter- skelter upon the shoulders of the wind, and little birds in the hedges were rustling their feathers and tucking themselves in comfortably for the night, retaining their places if Oak kept moving, but flying away if he (Oak) stopped to look at them. He (Oak) passed by Yalbury-Wood where the game-birds were rising to their roosts, and heard the crack-voiced cock-pheasants ``cu-uck, cuck,'' and the wheezy whistle of the hens. By the time he (Oak) had walked three or four miles every shape in the-landscape had assumed a uniform hue of blackness. He (Oak) descended Yalbury Hill and could just discern ahead of him (Oak) a waggon, drawn up under a great over-hanging tree by the roadside. On coming close, he (Oak) found there were no horses attached to it, the spot being apparently quite deserted. The waggon, from its position, seemed to have been left there for the night, for beyond about half a truss of hay which was heaped in the bottom, it was quite empty. Gabriel sat down on the shafts of the vehicle and con- sidered his (Gabriel) position. He (Gabriel) calculated that he (Gabriel) had walked a very fair proportion of the journey; and having been on foot since daybreak, he (Gabriel) felt tempted to lie down upon the hay in the waggon instead of pushing on to the village of Weatherbury, and having to pay for a lodging. Eating his (Gabriel) las slices of bread and ham, and drinking from the bottle of cider he (Gabriel) had taken the precaution to bring with him (Gabriel), he (Gabriel) got into the lonely waggon. Here he (Gabriel) spread half of the hay as a bed, and, as well as he (Gabriel) could in the darkness, pulled the other half over him (Gabriel) by way of bed-clothes, covering himself entirely, and feeling, physically, as comfortable as ever he (Gabriel) had been in his (Gabriel) life. Inward melancholy it was impossible for a man like Oak, introspective far beyond his (Oak) neighbours, to banish quite, whilst conning the present. untoward page of his (Oak) history. So, thinking of his (Oak) misfortunes, amorous and pastoral he (Oak) fell asleep, shepherds enjoying, in common with sailors, the privilege of being able to summon the god instead of having to wait for him (god). On somewhat suddenly awaking after a sleep of whose length he (god) had no idea, Oak found that the waggon was in motion. He (Oak) was being carried along the road at a rate rather considerable for a vehicle without springs, and under circumstances of physical uneasiness, his (Oak) head being dandled up and down on the bed of the waggon like a kettledrum-stick. He (Oak) then dis- tinguished voices in conversation, coming from the forpart of the waggon. His (Oak) concern at this dilemma -LRB-which would have been alarm, had he (Oak) been a thriving man; but -- misfortune is a fine opiate to personal terror-RRB- led him (Oak) to peer cautiously from the hay, and the first sight he (Oak) beheld was the stars above him (Oak). Charles's Wain was getting towards a right angle with the Pole star, and Gabriel concluded that it must be about nine o'clock -- in other words, that he (Gabriel) had slept two hours. This small astronomical calculation was made without any positive effort, and whilst he (Gabriel) was stealthily turning to discover, if possible, into whose hands he (Gabriel) had fallen. Two figures were dimly visible in front, sitting with their legs outside the waggon, one of whom was driving. Gabriel soon found that this was the waggoner, and it appeared they had come from Casterbridge fair, like himself. A conversation was in progress, which continued thus: -- ``Be as `twill, she (it)'s a fine handsome body as far's looks be concerned. But that's only the skin of the woman, and these dandy cattle be as-proud as a lucifer in their insides.'' ``Ay -- so 'a do seem, Billy Smallbury -- so 'a do seem.'' This utterance was very shaky by nature, and more so by circumstance, the jolting of the waggon not being- without its effect upon the speaker's larynx. It came ``from the man who held the reins.
``She (woman)'s a very vain feymell -- so `tis said here and there.'' (unknown)
``Ah, now. If so be `tis like that, I can't look her (woman) in the face. Lord, no: not I -- heh-heh-heh! Such a shy man as I be!'' (unknown)
``Yes -- she (woman)'s very vain. ``Tis said that every night at going to bed she (woman) looks in the glass to put on her (woman) night- cap properly.'' ``And not a married woman. Oh, the world!'' ``And 'a can play the peanner, so `tis said. Can play so clever that 'a can make a psalm tune sound as well as the merriest loose song a man can wish for.'' ``D'ye tell o`t! A happy time for us, and I feel quite a new man! And how do she (woman) play?'' ``That I don't know, Master Poorgrass.'' On hearing these and other similar remarks, a wild thought flashed into Gabriel's mind that they might be speaking of Bathsheba. There were, however, no ground for retaining such a supposition, for the waggon, though going in the direction of Weatherbury, might be going beyond it, and the woman alluded to seemed to be the mistress of some estate. They were now apparently close upon Weatherbury and not to alarm the speakers unnecessarily, Gabriel slipped out of the waggon unseen. He (Gabriel) turned to an opening in the hedge, which he (Gabriel) found to be a gate, and mounting thereon, he (Gabriel) sat meditating whether to seek a cheap lodging in the village, or to ensure a cheaper one by lying under some hay or corn-stack. The crunching jangle of the waggon died upon his (Gabriel) ear. He (Gabriel) was about to walk on, when he (Gabriel) noticed on his (Gabriel) left hand an unusual light -- appearing about half a mile distant. Oak watched it, and the glow increased. Something was on fire. Gabriel again mounted the gate, and, leaping down on the other side upon what he (Gabriel) found to be ploughed soil, made across the field in the exact direction of the fire. The blaze, enlarging in a double ratio by his (Gabriel) approach and its own increase, showed him (Gabriel) as he (Gabriel) drew nearer the outlines of ricks beside it, lighted up to great distinctness. A rick-yard was the source of the fire. His (Gabriel) weary face now began to be painted over with a rich orange glow, and the whole front of his (Gabriel) smock- frock and gaiters was covered with a dancing shadow pattern of thorn-twigs -- the light reaching him (Gabriel) through a leafless intervening hedge -- and the metallic curve of his (Gabriel) sheep-crook shone silver-bright in the same abound- ing rays. He (Gabriel) came up to the boundary fence, and stood to regain breath. It seemed as if the spot was unoccupied by a living soul. The fire was issuing from a long straw-stack, which was so far gone as to preclude a possibility of saving it. A rick burns differently from a house. As the wind blows the fire inwards, the portion in flames completely disappears like melting sugar, and the outline is lost to the eye. However, a hay or a wheat-rick, well put together, will resist combustion for a length of time, if it begins on the outside. This before Gabriel's eyes was a- rick of straw, loosely put together, and the flames darted into it with lightning swiftness. It glowed on the windward side, rising and falling in intensity, like the coal of a cigar. Then a superincumbent bundle rolled down, with a whisking noise; flames elongated, and bent themselves about with a quiet roar, but no crackle. Banks of smoke went off horizontally at the back like passing clouds, and behind these burned hidden pyres, illuminating the semi-transparent sheet of smoke to a lustrous yellow uniformity. Individual straws in the foreground were consumed in a creeping movement of ruddy heat, as if they were knots of red worms, and above shone imaginary fiery faces, tongues hanging from lips, glaring eyes, and other impish forms, from which at intervals sparks flew in clusters like birds from a nest, Oak suddenly ceased from being a mere spectator by discovering the case to be more serious than he (spectator) had at first imagined. A scroll of smoke blew aside and revealed to him (spectator) a wheat-rick in startling juxtaposition with the decaying one, and behind this a series of others, composing the main corn produce of the farm; so that instead of the straw-stack standing, as he (spectator) had imagined comparatively isolated, there was a regular connection between it and the remaining stacks of the group. Gabriel leapt over the hedge, and saw that he (Gabriel) was not alone. The first man he (Gabriel) came to was running about in a great hurry, as if his (Gabriel) thoughts were several yards in advance of his (Gabriel) body, which they could never drag on fast enough. ``O, man -- fire, fire! A good master and a. bad servant is fire, fire! -- I mane a bad servant and a good master O, Mark Clark -- come! And you, Billy Smallbury -- and you, Maryann Money -- and you, Jan Coggan, and Matthew there!'' Other figures now appeared behind this shouting man and among the smoke, and Gabriel found that, far from being alone he (Gabriel) was in a great company -- whose shadows danced merrily up and down, timed by the jigging of the flames, and not at all by their owners' movements. The assemblage -- belonging to that class of society which casts its thoughts into the form of feeling, and its feelings into the form of commotion -- set to work with a remarkable confusion of purpose. ``Stop the draught under the wheat-rick!'' cried Gabriel to those nearest to him (Gabriel). The corn stood on stone staddles, and between these, tongues of yellow hue from the burning straw licked and darted playfully. If the fire once got under this stack, all would be lost. ``Get a tarpaulin -- quick!'' said Gabriel. A rick-cloth was brought, and they hung it like a curtain across the channel. The flames immediately ceased to go under the bottom of the corn-stack, and stood up vertical. ``Stand here with a bucket of water and keep the cloth wet.'' said Gabriel again. The flames, now driven upwards, began to attack the angles of the huge roof covering the wheat-stack. ``A ladder.'' cried Gabriel. ``The ladder was against the straw-rick and is burnt to a cinder.'' said a spectre-like form in the smoke. Oak seized the cut ends of the sheaves, as if he (Gabriel) were going to engage in the operation of ``reed-drawing,'' and digging in his (Gabriel) feet, and occasionally sticking in the stem of his (Gabriel) sheep-crook, he (Gabriel) clambered up the beetling face. He (Gabriel) at once sat astride the very apex, and began with his (Gabriel) crook to beat off the fiery fragments which had lodged thereon, shouting to the others to get him (Gabriel) a bough and a ladder, and some water. Billy Smallbury -- one of the men who had been on the waggon -- by this time had found a ladder, which Mark Clark ascended, holding on beside Oak upon the thatch. The smoke at this corner was stifling, and Clark, a nimble fellow, having been handed a bucket of water, bathed Oak's face and sprinkled him (Oak) generally, whilst Gabriel, now with a long beech-bough in one hand, in addition to his (Gabriel) crook in the other, kept sweeping the stack and dislodging all fiery particles. On the ground the groups of villagers were still occupied in doing all they could to keep down the conflagration, which was not much. They were all tinged orange, and backed up by shadows of varying pattern. Round the corner of the largest stack, out of the direct rays of the fire, stood a pony, bearing a young woman on its back. By her (woman) side was another woman, on foot. These two seemed to keep at a distance from the fire, that the horse might not become restive. ``He (Matthew)'s a shepherd.'' said the woman on foot. ``Yes -- he (Matthew) is. See how his (Matthew) crook shines as he (Matthew) beats the rick with it. And his (Matthew) smock-frock is burnt in two holes, I declare! A fine young shepherd he (shepherd) is too, ma'am.'' ``Whose shepherd is he (shepherd)?'' said the equestrian in a clear voice. ``Don't know, ma'am.'' ``Don't any of the others know?'' ``Nobody at all -- I've asked 'em. Quite a stranger, they say.'' The young woman on the pony rode out from the shade and looked anxiously around. ``Do you think the barn is safe?'' she (woman) said. ``D'ye think the barn is safe, Jan Coggan?'' said the second woman, passing on the question to the nearest man in that direction. ``Safe -now -- leastwise I think so. If this rick had gone the barn would have followed.
``Tis- that bold shepherd up there that have done the most good -- he (shepherd) sitting on the top o' rick, whizzing his (shepherd) great long-arms about like a windmill.'' (unknown)
``He (shepherd) does work hard.'' (the woman)
said the young woman on horseback, looking up at Gabriel through her (woman) thick woollen veil.
``I wish he (shepherd) was shepherd here. Don't any of you know his (shepherd) name.'' (unknown)
``Never heard the man's name in my life, or seed his (shepherd) form afore.'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
The fire began to get worsted, and Gabriel's elevated position being no longer required of him (Gabriel), he (Gabriel) made as if to descend.
``Maryann.'' (the girl)
said the girl on horseback,
``go to him (shepherd) as he (shepherd) comes down, and say that the farmer wishes to thank him (farmer) for the great service he (farmer) has done.'' (the girl)
Maryann stalked off towards the rick and met Oak at the foot of the ladder. She (Maryann) delivered her (Maryann) message.
``Where is your master the farmer?'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
asked Gabriel, kindling with the idea of getting employment that seemed to strike him (Gabriel) now.
''`Tisn't a master; `tis a mistress, shepherd.'' (him)
``A woman farmer?'' (unknown)
``Ay, 'a b`lieve, and a rich one too!'' (unknown)
said a by- stander.
``Lately 'a came here from a distance. Took on her (woman) uncle's farm, who died suddenly. Used to measure his (uncle) money in half-pint cups. They say now that she (woman)'ve business in every bank in Casterbridge, and thinks no more of playing pitch-and-toss sovereign than you and I, do pitch-halfpenny -- not a bit in the world, shepherd.'' (unknown)
``That's she (woman), back there upon the pony.'' (Mary)
said Mary- ann.
``wi' her (woman) face a-covered up in that black cloth with holes in it.'' (crook)
Oak, his (shepherd) features smudged, grimy, and undiscoverable from the smoke and heat, his (shepherd) smock-frock burnt-into holes and dripping with water, the ash stem of his (shepherd) sheep- crook charred six inches shorter, advansed with the humility stern adversity had thrust upon him (shepherd) up to the slight female form in the saddle. He (shepherd) lifted his (shepherd) hat with respect, and not without gallantry: stepping close to her (Mary) hanging feet he (shepherd) said in a hesitating voice, --
``Do you happen to want a shepherd, ma'am?'' (he)
She (Mary) lifted the wool veil tied round her (Mary) face, and looked all astonishment. Gabriel and his (Gabriel) cold-hearted darling, Bathsheba Everdene, were face to face. Bathsheba did not speak, and he (Gabriel) mechanically repeated in an abashed and sad voice, --
``Do you want a shepherd, ma'am?'' (he)

CHAPTER VII

RECOGNITION -- A TIMID GIRL

BATHSHEBA withdrew into the shade. She (GIRL) scarcely knew whether most to be amused at the singularity of the meeting, or to be concerned at its awkwardness. There was room for a little pity, also for a very little exultation: the former at his (Gabriel) position, the latter at her (GIRL) own. Embarrassed she (GIRL) was not, and she (GIRL)'' remembered Gabriel's declaration of love to her (GIRL) at Norcombe only to think she (GIRL) had nearly forgotten it. ``Yes,'' she (GIRL) murmured, putting on an air of dignity, and turning again to him (Gabriel) with a little warmth of cheek; ``I do want a shepherd. But -- -- '' ``He (shepherd)'s the very man, ma'am.'' said one of the villagers, quietly. Conviction breeds conviction. ``Ay, that 'a is.'' said a second, decisively. ``The man, truly!

'' said a third, with heartiness.'' (The man)
``He (man)'s all there!'' (unknown)
said number four, fervidly.'' Then will you tell him (Gabriel) to speak to the bailiff, said Bathsheba. All ``was practical again now. A summer eve and loneliness would have been necessary to give the meeting its proper fulness of romance. the palpitation within his (man) breast at discovering that this Ashtoreth of strange report was only a modification of Venus the well-known and admired, retired with him (man) to talk over the necessary preliminaries of hiring. The fire before them wasted away.
``Men.'' (Bathsheba/Bathsheba Everdene/BATHSHEBA)
said Bathsheba,
'' you shall take a little refreshment after this extra work. Will you come to the house?'' (Bathsheba/Bathsheba Everdene/BATHSHEBA)
``We could knock in a bit and a drop a good deal freer, Miss, if so be ye'd send it to Warren's Malthouse,'' (the spokesman)
replied the spokesman. Bathsheba then rode off into the darkness, and the men straggled on to the village in twos and threes -- Oak and the bailiff being left by the rick alone.
``And now.'' (the bailiff)
said the bailiff, finally,
``all is settled, I think, about your coming, and I am going home-along. Good-night to ye, shepherd.'' (the bailiff)
``Can you get me a lodging?'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
inquired Gabriel.
``That I can't, indeed,'' (he)
he (Gabriel) said, moving past Oak as a Christian edges past an offertory-plate when he (Gabriel) does not mean to contribute.
``If you follow on the road till you come to Warren's Malthouse, where they are all gone to have their snap of victuals, I daresay some of 'em will tell you of a place. Good-night to ye, shepherd.'' (The bailiff)
The bailiff who showed this nervous dread of loving his (bailiff) neighbour as himself, went up the hill, and Oak walked on to the village, still astonished at the ren- counter with Bathsheba, glad of his (Oak) nearness to her (men), and perplexed at the rapidity with which the unpractised girl of Norcombe had developed into the supervising and cool woman here. But some women only require an emerg- ency to make them fit for one. Obliged, to some extent, to forgo dreaming in order to find the way, he (Oak) reached the churchyard, and passed round it under the wall where several ancient trees grew. There was a wide margin of grass along here, and Gabriel's footsteps were deadened by its softness, even at this indurating period of the year. When abreast of a trunk which appeared to be the oldest of the old, he (Gabriel) became aware that a figure was standing behind it. Gabriel did not pause in his (Gabriel) walk, and in another moment he (Gabriel) accidentally kicked a loose stone. The noise was enough to disturb the motionless stranger, who started and assumed a careless position. It was a slim girl, rather thinly clad.
``Good-night to you.'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
said Gabriel, heartily.
``Good-night.'' (the girl)
said the girl to Gabriel. The voice was unexpectedly attractive; it was
``the low and dulcet note suggestive of romance,'' (unknown)
common in descriptions, rare in experience.
``I'll thank you to tell me if I'm in the way for Warren's Malthouse?'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
Gabriel resumed, primarily to gain the information, indirectly to get more of the music.
``Quite right. It's at the bottom of the hill. And do you know -- --'' (The girl)
The girl hesitated and then went on again.
``Do you know how late they keep open the Buck's Head Inn?'' (She)
She (girl) seemed'' to be won by Gabriel's heartiness, as Gabriel had been won by her (girl) modulations. ``I don't know where the Buck's Head is, or anything about it. Do you think of going there to-night?'' ``Yes -- --'' The woman again paused. There was no necessity for any continuance of speech, and the fact that she (girl) did add more seemed to proceed from an unconscious desire to show unconcern by making a remark, which is noticeable in the ingenuous when they are acting by stealth. ``You are not a Weatherbury man?'' she (girl) said, timorously. ``I am not. I am the new shepherd -- just arrived.'' ``Only a shepherd -- and you seem almost a farmer by your ways.'' ``Only a shepherd.'' Gabriel repeated, in a dull cadence of finality. ``His (shepherd) thoughts were directed to the past, his (shepherd) eyes to the feet of the girl; and for the first time he (shepherd) saw lying there a bundle of some sort. She (girl) may have perceived the direction of his (shepherd) face, for she (girl) said coaxingly, --
``You won't say anything in the parish about having seen me here, will you -- at least, not for a day or two?'' (she)
``I won't if you wish me not to.'' (unknown)
said Oak.
``Thank you, indeed.'' (unknown)
the other replied.
``I am rather poor, and I don't want people to know anything about me.'' (she)
Then she (girl) was silent and shivered.
``You ought to have a cloak on such a cold night,'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
Gabriel observed.
``I would advise `ee to get indoors.'' (unknown)
``O no! Would you mind going on and leaving me? I thank you much for what you have told me.'' (unknown)
``I will go on.'' (he)
he (Gabriel) said; adding hesitatingly, --
``Since you are not very well off, perhaps you would accept this trifle from me. It is only a shilling, but it is all I have to spare.'' (he)
``Yes, I will take it.'' (the stranger)
said the stranger, gratefully. She (girl) extended her (girl) hand; Gabriel his (Gabriel). In feeling for each other's palm in the gloom before the money could be passed, a minute incident occurred which told much. Gabriel's fingers alighted on the young woman's wrist. It was beating with a throb of tragic intensity. He (Gabriel) had frequently felt the same quick, hard beat in the femoral artery of -- his (Gabriel) lambs when overdriven. It suggested a consumption too great of a vitality which, to judge from her (woman) figure and stature, was already too little.
``What is the matter?'' (unknown)
``Nothing.'' (unknown)
``But there is?'' (unknown)
``No, no, no! Let your having seen me be a secret!'' (unknown)
``Very well; I will. Good-night, again.'' (unknown)
``Good-night.'' (The girl)
The young girl remained motionless by the tree, and Gabriel descended into the village of Weatherbury, or Lower Longpuddle as it was sometimes called. He (Gabriel) fancied that he (Gabriel) had felt himself in the penumbra of a very deep sadness when touching that slight and fragile creature. But wisdom lies in moderating mere impres- sions, and Gabriel endeavoured to think little of this.

CHAPTER VIII

THE MALTHOUSE -- THE CHAT -- NEWS

WARREN``S Malthouse was enclosed by an old wall inwrapped with ivy, and though not much of the exterior was visible at this hour, the character and purposes of the building were clearly enough shown by its outline upon the sky. From the walls an overhanging thatched roof sloped up to a point in the centre, upon which rose a small wooden lantern, fitted with louvre-boards on all the four sides, and from these openings a mist was dimly perceived to be escaping into the night air. There was no window in front; but a square hole in the door was glazed with a single pane, through which red, comfortable rays now stretched out upon the ivied wall in front. Voices were to be heard inside. Oak's hand skimmed the surface of the door with fingers extended to an Elymas-the-Somerer pattern, till he found a leathern strap, which he (he) pulled. This lifted a wooden latch, and the door swung open. The room inside was lighted only by the, ruddy glow from the kiln mouth, which shone over ,the floor with the streaming, horizontality of the setting sun, and threw upwards the shadows of all facial irregularities in those assembled around. The stone-flag floor was worn into a path from the doorway to the kiln, and into undula- tions everywhere. A curved settle of unplaned oak stretched along one side, and in a remote corner was a small bed and bedstead, the owner and frequent occupier of which was the maltster. This aged man was now sitting opposite the fire, his (man) frosty white hair and beard overgrowing his (man) gnarled figure like the grey moss and lichen upon a leafless apple-tree. He (man) wore breeches and the laced-up shoes called ankle-jacks; he (man) kept his (man) eyes fixed upon the fire. Gabriel's nose was greeted by an atmosphere laden with the sweet smell of new malt. The conversation -LRB-which seemed to have been concerning the origin of the fire-RRB- immediately ceased, and every one ocularly criticised him (Gabriel) to the degree expressed by contracting the flesh of their foreheads and looking at him (Gabriel) with narrowed eye- lids, as if he (Gabriel) had been a light too strong for their sight. Several exclaimed meditatively, after this operation had been completed: -- ``Oh, `tis the new shepherd, 'a b`lieve.'' ``We thought we heard a hand pawing about the door for the bobbin, but weren't sure `twere not a dead leaf blowed across.'' said another. ``Come in, shepherd; sure ye be welcome, though we don't know yer name.'' ``Gabriel Oak, that's my name, neighbours.'' The ancient maltster sitting in the midst turned up this -- his (WARREN) turning being as the turning of a rusty crane. ``That's never Gable Oak's grandson over at Nor- combe -- never!'' he (WARREN) said, as a formula expressive of surprise, which nobody was supposed to take literally'. ``My father and my grandfather were old men of the name of Gabriel.'' said the shepherd, placidly. ``Thought I knowed the man's face as I seed him (Gabriel) on the rick! -- thought I did! And where be ye trading o't to now, shepherd?'' ``I'm thinking of biding here.'' said Mr. Oak. ``Knowed yer grandfather for years and years!'' continued the maltster, the words coming forth of their own accord as if the momentum previously imparted had been sufficient. ``Ah -- and did you!'' ``Knowed yer grandmother.'' ``And her (grandmother) too!'' ``Likewise knowed yer father when he (father) was a child. Why, my boy Jacob there and your father were sworn brothers -- that they were sure -- weren't ye, Jacob?'' ``Ay, sure.'' said his (Oak) son, a young man about sixty- five, with a semi-bald head and one tooth in the left centre of his (Oak) upper jaw, which made much of itself by standing prominent, like a milestone in a bank. ``But

``twas Joe had most to do with him (Joe). However, my son William must have knowed the very man afore us -- didn't ye, Billy, afore ye left Norcombe?'' (unknown)
``No, 'twas Andrew.'' (Jacob/Jacob Smallbury)
said Jacob's son Billy, a child of forty, or thereabouts, who manifested the peculiarity of possessing a cheerful soul in a gloomy body, and whose whiskers were assuming a chinchilla shade here and there.
``I can mind Andrew.'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
said Oak,
``as being a man in the place when I was quite a child.'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
``Ay -- the other day I and my youngest daughter, Liddy, were over at my grandson's christening.'' (Billy Smallbury/Billy)
continued Billy. ``We were talking about this very family, and ``twas only last Purification Day in this very world, when the use-money is gied away to the second-best poor folk, you know, shepherd, and I can mind the day because they all had to traypse up to the vestry -- yes, this very man's family.'' ``Come, shepherd, and drink.
``Tis gape and swaller with us -- a drap of sommit, but not of much account.'' (unknown)
said the maltster, removing from the fire his (Oak) eyes, which were vermilion-red and bleared by gazing into it for so many years.
``Take up the God-forgive- me, Jacob. See if `tis warm, Jacob.'' (Jacob/Jacob Smallbury)
Jacob stooped to the God-forgive-me, which was a two-handled tall mug standing in the ashes, cracked and charred with heat: it was rather furred with ex- traneous matter about the outside, especially in the crevices of the handles, the innermost curves of which may not have seen daylight for several years by reason of this encrustation thereon -- formed of ashes accident- ally wetted with cider and baked hard; but to the mind of any sensible drinker the cup was no worse for that, being incontestably clean on the inside and about the rim. It may be observed that such a class of mug is called a God-forgive-me in Weatherbury and its vicinity for uncertain reasons; probably because its size makes any given toper feel ashamed of himself when he (drinker) sees its bottom in drinking it empty. Jacob, on receiving the order to see if the liquor was warm enough, placidly dipped his (Jacob) forefinger into it by way of thermometer, and having pronounced it nearly of the proper degree, raised the cup and very civilly attempted to dust some of the ashes from the bottom with the skirt of his (Jacob) smock-frock, because Shepherd Oak was a stranger.
``A clane cup for the shepherd.'' (unknown)
said the maltster commandingly.
``No -- not at all,'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
said Gabriel, in a reproving tone of considerateness.
``I never fuss about dirt in its pure state, and when I know what sort it is.'' (he)
Taking the mug he (Gabriel) drank an inch or more from the depth of its contents, and duly passed it to the next man. wouldn't think of giving such trouble to neighbours in washing up when there's so much work to be done in the world already.'' continued Oak in a moister tone, after recovering from the stoppage of breath which is occasioned by pulls at large mugs. ``A right sensible man.'' said Jacob. ``True, true; it can't be gainsaid!'' observed a brisk young man -- Mark Clark by name, a genial and pleasant gentleman, whom to meet anywhere in your travels was to know, to know was to drink with, and to drink with was, unfortunately, to pay for. ``And here's a mouthful of bread and bacon that mis`ess have sent, shepherd. The cider will go down better with a bit of victuals. Don't ye chaw quite close, shepherd, for I let the bacon fall in the road outside as I was bringing it along, and may be `tis rather gritty. There, `tis clane dirt; and we all know what that is, as you say, and you bain't a particular man we see, shepherd.'' ``True, true -- not at all.'' said the friendly Oak. ``Don't let your teeth quite meet, and you won't feel the sandiness at all. Ah! `tis wonderful what can be done by contrivance!'' ``My own mind exactly, neighbour.'' ``Ah, he (man)'s his (man) grandfer's own grandson! -- his (man) grandfer were just such a nice unparticular man!'' said the maltster. ``Drink, Henry Fray -- drink.'' magnanimously said Jan Coggan, a person who held Saint-Simonian notions of share and share alike where liquor was concerned, as the vessel showed signs of approaching him (Coggan) in its gradual revolution among them. Having at this moment reached the end of a wistful gaze into mid-air, Henry did not refuse. He (Henry) was a man of more than middle age, with eyebrows high up in his (Henry) forehead, who laid it down that the law of the world was bad, with a long-suffering look through his (Henry) listeners at the world alluded to, as it presented itself to his (Henry) imagination. He (Henry) always signed his (Henry) name ``Henery'' -- strenuously insisting upon that spelling, and if any passing schoolmaster ventured to remark that the second ``e'' was superfluous and old-fashioned, he (Henry) received the reply that ``H-e-n-e-r-y'' was the name he (Henry) was christened and the name he (Henry) would stick to -- in the tone of one to whom orthographical differences were matters which had a great deal to do with personal character. Mr. Jan Coggan, who had passed the cup to Henery, was a crimson man with a spacious countenance, and private glimmer in his (man) eye, whose name had appeared on the marriage register of Weatherbury and neighbour- ing parishes as best man and chief witness in countless unions of the previous twenty years; he (man) also very frequently filled the post of head godfather in baptisms of the subtly-jovial kind. ``Come, Mark Clark -- come. Ther's plenty more in the barrel.'' said Jan. ``Ay -- that I will, `tis my only doctor.'' replied Mr. Clark, who, twenty years younger than Jan Coggan, revolved in the same orbit. He (Coggan) secreted mirth on all occasions for special discharge at popular parties. ``Why, Joseph Poorgrass, ye han't had a drop!'' said Mr. Coggan to a self-conscious man in the background, thrusting the cup towards him (Coggan). ``Such a modest man as he (man) is!'' said Jacob Smallbury. ``Why, ye've hardly had strength of eye enough to look in our young mis`ess's face, so I hear, Joseph?'' All looked at Joseph Poorgrass with pitying reproach. ``No -- I've hardly looked at her (our) at all.'' simpered Joseph, reducing his (Joseph) body smaller whilst talking, apparently from a meek sense of undue prominence. ``And when I seed her (our), 'twas nothing but blushes with me!'' ``Poor feller.
'' said Mr. Clark. '' (Poor feller)
`Tis a curious nature for a man.'' said Jan Coggan. ``Yes.
'' continued Joseph Poorgrass -- his (Coggan) shyness, which was so painful as a defect, filling him (Coggan) with a mild complacency now that it was regarded as an interesting study. '' (me)
`Twere blush, blush, blush with me every minute of the time, when she (Coggan) was speaking to me.'' ``I believe ye, Joseph Poorgrass, for we all know ye to be a very bashful man.
'' '' (a man)
`Tis a' awkward gift for a man, poor soul.'' said the maltster. ``And ye have suffered from it a long time, we know.'' ``Ay ever since I was a boy. Yes -- mother was concerned to her (mother) heart about it -- yes. But twas all nought.'' ``Did ye ever go into the world to try and stop it, Joseph Poorgrass?'' ``Oh ay, tried all sorts o' company. They took me to Greenhill Fair, and into a great gay jerry-go-nimble show, where there were women-folk riding round -- standing upon horses, with hardly anything on but their smocks; but it didn't cure me a morsel. And then I was put errand-man at the Women's Skittle Alley at the back of the Tailor's Arms in Casterbridge.
``Twas a horrible sinful situation, and a very curious place for a good man. I had to stand and look ba`dy people in the face from morning till night; but 'twas no use -- I was just as-bad as ever after all. Blushes hev been in the family for generations. There, `tis a happy pro- vidence that I be no worse.'' (unknown)
``True.'' (Jacob/Jacob Smallbury)
said Jacob Smallbury, deepening his (Smallbury) thoughts to a profounder view of the subject.
''`Tis a thought to look at, that ye might have been worse; but even as you be, `tis a very bad affliction for `ee, Joseph. For ye see, shepherd, though `tis very well for a woman, dang it all, `tis awkward for a man like him (man), poor feller?'' (Jacob/Jacob Smallbury)
''`Tis -- `tis.'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
said Gabriel, recovering from a medita- tion.
``Yes, very awkward for the man.'' (unknown)
``Ay, and he (man)'s very timid, too.'' (Coggan/Jan Coggan/Jan)
observed Jan Coggan.
``Once he (man) had been working late at Yalbury Bottom, and had had a drap of drink, and lost his (man) way as he (man) was coming home-along through Yalbury Wood, didn't ye, Master Poorgrass?'' (unknown)
``No, no, no; not that story!'' (the man)
expostulated the modest man, forcing a laugh to bury his (man) concern.
''-- -- And so 'a lost himself quite.'' (the man)
continued Mr Coggan, with an impassive face, implying that a true narrative, like time and tide, must run its course and would respect no man. ``And as he (Master) was coming along in the middle of the night, much afeared, and not able to find his (Master) way out of the trees nohow, 'a cried out, ``Man-a-lost! man-a-lost!'' A owl in a tree happened to be crying ``Whoo-whoo-whoo!
'' as owls do, you know, shepherd'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
-LRB-Gabriel nodded-RRB-,
'' and Joseph, all in a tremble, said, '' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
Joseph Poorgrass, of Weatherbury, sir!'' ``No, no, now -- that's too much!'' said the timid man, becoming a man of brazen courage all of a sudden. ``I didn't say sir. I'll tike my oath I didn't say
'' Joseph Poorgrass o' Weatherbury, sir.'' (I)
No, no; what's right is right, and I never said sir to the bird, knowing very well that no man of a gentleman's rank would be hollering there at that time o' night.
'' Joseph Poor- grass of Weatherbury,'' (a gentleman)
-- that's every word I said, and I shouldn't ha' said that if 't hadn't been for Keeper Day's metheglin... There, 'twas a merciful thing it ended where it did.'' The question of which was right being tacitly waived by the company, Jan went on meditatively: -- ``And he (Master)'s the fearfullest man, bain't ye, Joseph? Ay, another time ye were lost by Lambing-Down Gate, weren't ye, Joseph?'' ``I was.'' replied Poorgrass, as if there were some conditions too serious even for modesty to remember itself under, this being one. ``Yes; that were the middle of the night, too. The gate would not open, try how he (Joseph) would, and knowing there was the Devil's hand in it, he (Devil) kneeled down.'' ``Ay.'' said Joseph, acquiring confidence from the warmth of the fire, the cider, and a perception of the narrative capabilities of the experience alluded to. ``My heart died within me, that time; but I kneeled down and said the Lord's Prayer, and then the Belie right through, and then the Ten Commandments, in earnest prayer. But no, the gate wouldn't open; and then I went on with Dearly Beloved Brethren, and, thinks I, this makes four, and `tis all I know out of book, and if this don't do it nothing will, and I'm a lost man. Well, when I got to Saying After Me, I rose from my knees and found the gate would open -- yes, neighbours, the gate opened the same as ever.'' A meditation on the obvious inference was indulged in by all, and during its continuance each directed his (Joseph) vision into the ashpit, which glowed like a desert in the tropics under a vertical sun, shaping their eyes long and liny, partly because of the light, partly from the depth of the subject discussed. Gabriel broke the silence. ``What sort of a place is this to live at, and what sort of a mis`ess is she (I) to work under?'' Gabriel's bosom thrilled gently as he (Gabriel) thus slipped under the notice of the assembly the inner- most subject of his (Gabriel) heart. ``We d' know little of her (I) -- nothing. She (I) only showed herself a few days ago. Her (I) uncle was took bad, and the doctor was called with his (doctor) world-wide skill; but he (doctor) couldn't save the man. As I take it, she (I)'s going to keep on the farm.
``That's about the shape o`t, 'a b`lieve.'' (Coggan/Jan Coggan/Jan)
said Jan uncle was a very fair sort of man. Did ye know en, be under 'em as under one here and there. Her (ye) uncle was a very fair sort of man. Did ye know `en, shepherd -- a bachelor-man?'' ``Not at all.'' ``I used to go to his (doctor) house a-courting my first wife, Charlotte, who was his (doctor) dairymaid. Well, a very good- hearted man were Farmer Everdene, and I being a respectable young fellow was allowed to call and see her (Charlotte) and drink as much ale as I liked, but not to carry away any -- outside my skin I mane of course.'' ``Ay, ay, Jan Coggan; we know yer meaning.'' ``And so you see 'twas beautiful ale, and I wished to value his (Coggan) kindness as much as I could, and not to be so ill-mannered as to drink only a thimbleful, which would have been insulting the man's generosity -- -- '' ``True, Master Coggan, `twould so.
'' corroborated Mark Clark. '' (Master Coggan)
-- -- And so I used to eat a lot of salt fish afore going, and then by the time I got there I were as dry as a lime-basket -- so thorough dry that that ale would slip down -- ah, `twould slip down sweet! Happy times! heavenly times! Such lovely drunks as I used to have at that house! You can mind, Jacob? You used to go wi' me sometimes.'' ``I can -- I can.'' said Jacob. ``That one, too, that we had at Buck's Head on a White Monday was a pretty tipple.
'' '' (White)
'Twas. But for a wet of the better class, that brought you no nearer to the horned man than you were afore you begun, there was none like those in Farmer Everdene's kitchen. Not a single damn allowed; no, not a bare poor one, even at the most cheerful moment when all were blindest, though the good old word of sin thrown in here and there at such times is a great relief to a merry soul.'' ``True.'' said the maltster. ``Nater requires her (Coggan) swearing at the regular times, or she (Coggan)'s not herself; and unholy exclamations is a necessity of life.'' ``But Charlotte.'' continued Coggan -- ``not a word of the sort would Charlotte allow, nor the smallest item of taking in vain... Ay, poor Charlotte, I wonder if she (Charlotte) had the good fortune to get into Heaven when 'a died! But 'a was never much in luck's way, and perhaps 'a went downwards after all, poor soul.'' ``And did any of you know Miss Everdene's-father and mother?'' inquired the shepherd, who found some difficulty in keeping the conversation in the desired channel. ``I knew them a little.'' said Jacob Smallbury; ``but they were townsfolk, and didn't live here. They've been dead for years. Father, what sort of people were mis`ess' father and mother?'' ``Well.'' said the maltster, ``he (father) wasn't much to look at; but she (mother) was a lovely woman. He (father) was fond enough of her (mother) as his (father) sweetheart.'' ``Used to kiss her (mother) scores and long-hundreds o times, so 'twas said.'' observed Coggan. ``He (father) was very proud of her (mother), too, when they were married, as I've been told.'' said the maltster. ``Ay.'' said Coggan. ``He (father) admired her (mother) so much that he (father) used to light the candle three time a night to look at her (mother).'' ``Boundless love; I shouldn't have supposed it in the universe!'' murmered Joseph Poorgrass, who habitually spoke on a large scale in his (Coggan) moral reflections. ``Well, to be sure.'' said Gabriel. ``Oh, `tis true enough. I knowed the man and woman both well. Levi Everdene -- that was the man's name, sure.
``Man.'' (he)
saith I in my hurry, but he (Gabriel) were of a higher circle of life than that -- 'a was a gentleman- tailor really, worth scores of pounds. And he (tailor) became a very celebrated bankrupt two or three times.'' ``Oh, I thought he (Man) was quite a common man!'' said Joseph. ``O no, no! That man failed for heaps of money; hundreds in gold and silver.'' The maltster being rather short of breath, Mr. Coggan, after absently scrutinising a coal which had fallen among the ashes, took up the narrative, with a private twirl of his (Coggan) eye: -- ``Well, now, you'd hardly believe it, but that man -- husbands alive, after a while. Understand? 'a didn't want to be fickle, but he (man) couldn't help it. The poor feller were faithful and true enough to her (man) in his (feller) wish, but his (feller) heart would rove, do what he (feller) would. He (feller) spoke to me in real tribulation about it once.
``Coggan,'' (he)
he (Coggan) said,
``I could never wish for a handsomer woman than I've got, but feeling she (woman)'s ticketed as my lawful wife, I can't help my wicked heart wandering, do what I will.'' (he)
But at last I believe he (Coggan) cured it by making her (I) take off her (I) wedding-ring and calling her (I) by her (I) maiden name as they sat together after the shop was shut, and so 'a would get to fancy she (I) was only his (Coggan) sweetheart, and not married to him (Coggan) at all. And as soon as he (Coggan) could thoroughly fancy he (Coggan) was doing wrong and committing the seventh, 'a got to like her (I) as well as ever, and they lived on a perfect picture of mutel love.'' ``Well, 'twas a most ungodly remedy.'' murmured Joseph Poorgrass; ``but we ought to feel deep cheerful- ness that a happy Providence kept it from being any worse. You see, he (Coggan) might have gone the bad road and given his (Coggan) eyes to unlawfulness entirely -- yes, gross un- lawfulness, so to say it.'' ``You see.'' said Billy Smallbury, ``The man's will was to do right, sure enough, but his (man) heart didn't chime in.'' ``He (man) got so much better, that he (man) was quite godly in his (man) later years, wasn't he (man), Jan?'' said Joseph Poor- grass. ``He (Jan) got himself confirmed over again in a more serious way, and took to saying
``Amen'' (He)
almost as loud as the clerk, and he (Poor) liked to copy comforting verses from the tombstones. He (Poor) used, too, to hold the money- plate at Let Your Light so Shine, and stand godfather to poor little come-by-chance children; and he (godfather) kept a missionary box upon his (godfather) table to nab folks unawares when they called; yes, and he (godfather) would-box the charity- boys' ears, if they laughed in church, till they could hardly stand upright, and do other deeds of piety natural to the saintly inclined.'' ``Ay, at that time he (Jan) thought of nothing but high things.'' added Billy Smallbury. ``One day Parson Thirdly met him (Parson) and said,
``Good-Morning, Mister Everdene; `tis a fine day!'' (him)
``Amen'' (Bathsheba/Bathsheba Everdene/BATHSHEBA)
said Everdene, quite absent- like, thinking only of religion when he (Smallbury) seed a parson-
``Their daughter was not at all a pretty chile at that time.'' (a parson)
said Henery Fray.
``Never should have. thought she (daughter)'d have growed up such a handsome body as she (daughter) is.'' (unknown)
''`Tis to be hoped her (they) temper is as good as her (they) face.'' (unknown)
``Well, yes; but the baily will have most to do with the business and ourselves. Ah!'' (Henery)
Henery gazed into the ashpit, and smiled volumes of ironical knowledge. ``A queer Christian, like the Devil's head in a cowl, ``He (Devil) is.'' said Henery, implying that irony must cease at a certain point. ``Between we two, man and man, I believe that man would as soon tell a lie Sundays as working-days -- that I do so.'' ``Good faith, you do talk!'' said Gabriel. ``True enough.'' said the man of bitter moods, looking round upon the company with the antithetic laughter that comes from a keener appreciation of the miseries of life than ordinary men are capable of. ``Ah, there's people of one sort, and people of another, but that man -- bless your souls!'' Gabriel thought fit to change the subject. ``You must be a very aged man, malter, to have sons growed mild and ancient'' he (Gabriel) remarked. ``Father's so old that 'a can't mind his (Father) age, can ye, father?'' interposed Jacob. ``And he (Father) growled terrible crooked too, lately'' Jacob continued, surveying his (Jacob) father's figure, which was rather more bowed than his (Jacob) own. ``Really one may say that father there is three-double.'' ``Crooked folk will last a long while.'' said the maltster, grimly, and not in the best humour. ``Shepherd would like to hear the pedigree of yer life, father -- wouldn't ye, shepherd?
``Ay that I should.'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
said Gabriel with the heartiness of a man who had longed to hear it for several months.
``What may your age be, malter?'' (unknown)
The maltster cleared his (Gabriel) throat in an exaggerated form for emphasis, and elongating his (Gabriel) gaze to the remotest point of the ashpit! said, in the slow speech justifiable when the importance of a subject is so generally felt that any mannerism must be tolerated in getting at it,
``Well, I don't mind the year I were born in, but perhaps I can reckon up the places I've lived at, and so get it that way. I bode at Upper Long- puddle across there'' (unknown)
-LRB-nodding to the north-RRB-
``till I were eleven. I bode seven at Kingsbere'' (unknown)
-LRB-nodding to the east-RRB-
``where I took to malting. I went therefrom to Norcombe, and malted there two-and-twenty years, and- two-and-twenty years I was there turnip-hoeing and harvesting. Ah, I knowed that old place, Norcombe, years afore you were thought of, Master Oak'' (unknown)
-LRB-Oak smiled sincere belief in the fact-RRB-.
``Then I malted at Dur- nover four year, and four year turnip-hoeing; and I was fourteen times eleven months at Millpond St. Jude's'' (unknown)
-LRB-nodding north-west-by-north-RRB-.
``Old Twills wouldn't hire me for more than eleven months at a time, to keep me from being chargeable to the parish if so be I was disabled. Then I was three year at Mellstock, and I've been here one-and-thirty year come Candlemas. How much is that?'' (unknown)
``Hundred and seventeen.'' (another gentleman)
chuckled another old gentleman, given to mental arithmetic and little con- versation, who had hitherto sat unobserved in a corner.
``Well, then, that's my age.'' (unknown)
said the maltster, em- phatically.
``O no, father!'' (Jacob/Jacob Smallbury)
said Jacob.
``Your turnip-hoeing were in the summer and your malting in the winter of the same years, and ye don't ought to count-both halves father.'' (unknown)
``Chok' it all! I lived through the summers, didn't I? That's my question. I suppose ye'll say next I be no age at all to speak of?'' (unknown)
``Sure we shan't.'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
said Gabriel, soothingly.
``Ye be a very old aged person, malter.'' (Coggan/Jan Coggan/Jan)
attested Jan must have a wonderful talented constitution to be able to live so long, mustn't he (Jan), neighbours?'' ``True, true; ye must, malter, wonderful,
'' said the meeting unanimously. The maltster, being know pacified, was even generous enough to voluntarily disparage in a slight degree the virtue of having lived a great many years, by mentioning that the cup they were drinking out of was three years older than he (Jan). While the cup was being examined, the end of Gabriel Oak's flute became visible over his (Oak) smock-frock I seed you blowing into a great flute by now at Caster- bridge?'' (unknown)
``You did.'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
said Gabriel, blushing faintly.
``I've been in great trouble, neighbours, and was driven to it. take it careless-like, shepherd and your time will come tired?'' (unknown)
``Neither drum nor trumpet have I heard since Christmas.'' (Coggan/Jan Coggan/Jan)
said Jan Coggan.
``Come, raise a tune, Master Oak!'' (unknown)
``That I will.'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
said Gabriel, pulling out his (Gabriel) flute and putting it together.
``A poor tool, neighbours; but such as I can do ye shall have and welcome.'' (unknown)
Oak then struck up
``Jockey to the Fair.'' (jerks)
and played that sparkling melody three times through accenting the notes in the third round in a most artistic and lively manner by bending his (Gabriel) body in small jerks and tapping with his (Gabriel) foot to beat time.
``He (Master) can blow the flute very well -- that 'a can.'' (a man)
said a young married man, who having no individuality worth mentioning was known as
``Susan Tall's husband.'' (a man)
He (man) continued,
``I'd as lief as not be able to blow into a flute as well-as that.'' (He)
``He (husband)'s a clever man, and `tis a true comfort for us to have such a shepherd.'' (Joseph/Joseph Poorgrass/Poorgrass)
murmured Joseph Poorgrass, in a soft cadence.
``We ought to feel full o' thanksgiving that he (shepherd)'s not a player of ba`dy songs `instead of these merry tunes; for `twould have been just as easy for God to have made the shepherd a loose low man -- a man of iniquity, so to speak it -- as what he (man) is. Yes, for our wives'' (daughters)
and daughters' sakes we should feel real thanks giving.'' ``True, true, -- real thanksgiving!'' dashed in Mark Clark conclusively, not feeling it to be of any conse- quence to his (Clark) opinion that he (Clark) had only heard about a word and three-quarters of what Joseph had said. ``Yes.'' added Joseph, beginning to feel like a man in the Bible; ``for evil do thrive so in these times that ye may be as much deceived in the cleanest shaved and whitest shirted man as in the raggedest tramp upon the turnpike, if I may term it so.'' ``Ay, I can mind yer face now, shepherd.'' said Henery Fray, criticising Gabriel with misty eyes as he (Gabriel) entered upon his (Gabriel) second tune. ``Yes -- now I see `ee blowing into the flute I know `ee to be the same man I see play at Casterbridge, for yer mouth were scrimped up and yer eyes a-staring out like a strangled man's -- just as they be now.
'' '' (a man)
`Tis a pity that playing the flute should make a man look such a scarecrow.'' observed Mr. Mark Clark, with additional criticism of Gabriel's countenance, the latter person jerking out, with the ghastly grimace required by the instrument, the chorus of ``Dame Durden!
``I hope you don't mind that young man's bad manners in naming your features?'' (Joseph/Joseph Poorgrass/Poorgrass)
whispered Joseph to Gabriel.
``Not at all.'' (Mr. Oak)
said Mr. Oak.
``For by nature ye be a very handsome man, shepherd.'' (Joseph/Joseph Poorgrass/Poorgrass)
continued Joseph Poorgrass, with winning sauvity.
``Ay, that ye be, shepard.'' (unknown)
said the company.
``Thank you very much.'' (he)
said Oak, in the modest tone good manners demanded, thinking, however, that he (Oak) would never let Bathsheba see him (Oak) playing the flute; in this severe showing a discretion equal to that related to its sagacious inventress, the divine Minerva herself.
``Ah, when I and my wife were married at Norcombe Church.'' (unknown)
said the old maltster, not pleased at finding himself left out of the subject
``we were called the handsomest couple in the neighbourhood -- everybody said so.'' (unknown)
``Danged if ye bain't altered now, malter.'' (unknown)
said a voice with the vigour natural to the enunciation of a remark- ably evident truism. It came from the old man in the background, whose offensiveness and spiteful ways were barely atoned for by the occasional chuckle he (man) con- tributed to general laughs.
``O no, no.'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
said Gabriel.
``Don't ye play no more shepherd'' (Susan Tall/Susan/Tall)
said Susan Tall's husband, the young married man who had spoken once before.
``I must be moving and when there's tunes going on I seem as if hung in wires. If I thought after I'd left that music was still playing, and I not there, I should be quite melancholy-like.'' (unknown)
``What's yer hurry then, Laban?'' (Coggan/Jan Coggan/Jan)
inquired Coggan.
``You used to bide as late as the latest.'' (unknown)
``Well, ye see, neighbours, I was lately married to a woman, and she (woman)'s my vocation now, and so ye see -- -- '' (The man)
The young man hated lamely.
``New Lords new laws, as the saying is, I suppose,'' (Coggan/Jan Coggan/Jan)
remarked Coggan.
``Ay, 'a b`lieve -- ha, ha!'' (Susan Tall/Susan/Tall)
said Susan Tall's husband, in a tone intended to imply his (husband) habitual reception of jokes without minding them at all. The young man then wished them good-night and withdrew. Henery Fray was the first to follow. Then Gabriel arose and went off with Jan Coggan, who had offered him (Gabriel) a lodging. A few minutes later, when the remaining ones were on their legs and about to depart, Fray came back again in a hurry. Flourishing his (Gabriel) finger ominously he (Gabriel) threw a gaze teeming with tidings just -- where his (Gabriel) eye alighted by accident, which happened to be in Joseph Poorgrass's face.
``O -- what's the matter, what's the matter, Henery?'' (Joseph/Joseph Poorgrass/Poorgrass)
said Joseph, starting back.
``What's a-brewing, Henrey?'' (Jacob/Jacob Smallbury)
asked Jacob and Mark Clark.
``Baily Pennyways -- Baily Pennyways -- I said so; yes, I said so!'' (unknown)
``What, found out stealing anything?'' (unknown)
``Stealing it is. The news is, that after Miss Everdene got home she (Everdene) went out again to see all was safe, as she (Everdene) usually do, and coming in found Baily Pennyways creeping down the granary steps with half a a bushel of barley. She (Everdene) fleed at him (I) like a cat -- never such a tomboy as she (Everdene) is -- of course I speak with closed doors?'' (unknown)
``You do -- you do, Henery.'' (unknown)
``She (Everdene) fleed at him (I), and, to cut a long story short, he (I) owned to having carried off five sack altogether, upon her (Everdene) promising not to persecute him (I). Well, he (I)'s turned out neck and crop, and my question is, who's going to be baily now?'' (Henery)
The question was such a profound one that Henery was obliged to drink there and then from the large cup till the bottom was distinctly visible inside. Before he (Clark) had replaced it on the table, in came the young man, Susan Tall's husband, in a still greater hurry.
``Have ye heard the news that's all over parish?'' (unknown)
``About Baily Pennyways?'' (unknown)
``But besides that?'' (unknown)
``No -- not a morsel of it!'' (the midst)
they replied, looking into the very midst of Laban Tall as if to meet his (man) words half-way down his (man) throat.
``What a night of horrors!'' (Joseph Poor)
murmured Joseph Poor- grass, waving his (man) hands spasmodically.
``I've had the news-bell ringing in my left ear quite bad enough for a murder, and I've seen a magpie all alone!'' (unknown)
``Fanny Robin -- Miss everdene's youngest servant -- can't be found. They've been wanting to lock up the door these two hours, but she (Fanny) isn't come in. And they don't know what to do about going to hed for fear of locking her (Fanny) out. They wouldn't be so concerned if she (Fanny) hadn't been noticed in such low spirits these last few days, and Maryann d'think the beginning of a crowner's inquest has happened to the poor girl.'' (unknown)
``O -- `tis burned -- `tis burned!'' (Joseph/Joseph Poorgrass/Poorgrass)
came from Joseph Poorgrass's dry lips.
``No -- `tis drowned!'' (unknown)
said Tall.
``Or `tis her (girl) father's razor!'' (Billy Smallbury/Billy)
suggested Billy Smallbury, with a vivid sense of detail.
``Well -- Miss Everdene wants to speak to one or two of us before we go to bed. What with this trouble about the baily, and now about the girl, mis`ess is almost wild.'' (unknown)
They all hastened up the lane to the farmhouse, excepting the old maltster, whom neither news, fire, rain, nor thunder could draw from his (Smallbury) hole. There, as the others' footsteps died away he (Smallbury) sat down again and continued gazing as usual into the furnace with his (Smallbury) red, bleared eyes. From the bedroom window above their heads Bath- sheba's head and shoulders, robed in mystic white, were dimly seen extended into the air.
``Are any of my men among you?'' (she)
she (their) said anxiously.
``Yes, ma'am, several.'' (Susan Tall/Susan/Tall)
said Susan Tall's husband.
``Tomorrow morning I wish two or three of you to make inquiries in the villages round if they have seen such a person as Fanny Robin. Do it quietly; there is no reason for alarm as yet. She (Fanny) must have left whilst we were all at the fire.'' (unknown)
``I beg yer pardon, but had she (Fanny) any young man court- ing her (Fanny) in the parish, ma'am?'' (Jacob/Jacob Smallbury)
asked Jacob Smallbury.
``I don't know.'' (Bathsheba/Bathsheba Everdene/BATHSHEBA)
said Bathsheba.
``I've never heard of any such thing, ma'am.'' (unknown)
said two or three.
``It is hardly likely, either.'' (Bathsheba/Bathsheba Everdene/BATHSHEBA)
continued Bathsheba.
``For any lover of hers might have come to the house if he (lover) had been a respectable lad. The most mysterious matter connected with her (Fanny) absence -- indeed, the only thing which gives me serious alarm -- is that she (Fanny) was seen to go out of the house by Maryann with only her (Maryann) indoor working gown on -- not even a bonnet.'' (unknown)
``And you mean, ma'am, excusing my words, that a young woman would hardly go to see her (woman) young man without dressing up.'' (Jacob/Jacob Smallbury)
said Jacob, turning his (Jacob) mental vision upon past experiences.
``That's true -- she (woman) would not, ma'am.'' (unknown)
``She (woman) had, I think, a bundle, though I couldn't see very well.'' (Maryann/Maryann Money)
said a female voice from another window, which seemed that of Maryann.
``But she (woman) had no young man about here. Hers lives in Casterbridge, and I believe he (man)'s a soldier.'' (unknown)
``Do you know his (man) name?'' (Bathsheba/Bathsheba Everdene/BATHSHEBA)
Bathsheba said.
``No, mistress; she (mistress) was very close about it.'' (unknown)
``Perhaps I might be able to find out if I went to Casterbridge barracks.'' (William/William Smallbury)
said William Smallbury.
``Very well; if she (mistress) doesn't return tomorrow, mind you go there and try to discover which man it is, and see him (man). I feel more responsible than I should if she (mistress) had had any friends or relations alive. I do hope she (mistress) has come to no harm through a man of that kind... And then there's this disgraceful affair of the bailiff -- but I can't speak of him (bailiff) now.'' (Bathsheba/Bathsheba Everdene/BATHSHEBA)
Bathsheba had so many reasons for uneasiness that it seemed she (Maryann) did not think it worth while to dwell upon any particular one.
``Do as I told you, then'' (she)
she (Maryann) said in conclusion, closing the casement.
``Ay, ay, mistress; we will.'' (unknown)
they replied, and moved away. That night at Coggan's, Gabriel Oak, beneath the screen of closed eyelids, was busy with fancies, and full of movement, like a river flowing rapidly under its ice. Night had always been the time at which he (Oak) saw Bath- sheba most vividly, and through the slow hours of shadow he (Oak) tenderly regarded her (Maryann) image now. It is rarely that the pleasures of the imagination will compen- sate for the pain of sleeplessness, but they possibly did with Oak to-night, for the delight of merely seeing her (Maryann) effaced for the time his (Oak) perception of the great differ- ence between seeing and possessing. He (Oak) also thought of Plans for fetching his (Oak) few utensils and books from Norcombe. The Young Man's Best Companion, The Farrier's Sure Guide, The Veterinary Surgeon, Paradise Lost, The Pilgrim's Progress, Robinson Crusoe, Ash's Dictionary, the Walkingame's Arithmetic, constituted his (Robinson) library; and though a limited series, it was one from which he (Robinson) had acquired more sound informa- tion by diligent perusal than many a man of opportunities has done from a furlong of laden shelves.

CHAPTER IX

THE HOMESTEAD -- A VISITOR -- HALF-CONFIDENCES

By daylight, the Bower of Oak's new-found mistress, Bathsheba Everdene, presented itself as a hoary build- ing, of the early stage of Classic Renaissance as regards its architecture, and of 'a proportion which told at a glance that, as is so frequently the case, it had once been the memorial hall upon a small estate around it, now altogether effaced as a distinct property, and merged in the vast tract of a non-resident landlord, which com- prised several such modest demesnes. Fluted pilasters, worked from the solid stone, decorated its front, and above the roof the chimneys were panelled or columnar, some coped gables with finials and like features still retaining traces of their Gothic extraction. Soft Brown mosses, like faded velveteen, formed cushions upon the stone tiling, and tufts of the houseleek or sengreen sprouted from the eaves of the low surrounding buildings. A gravel walk leading from the door to the road in front was encrusted at the sides with more moss -- here it was a silver-green variety, the nut-brown of the gravel being visible to the width of only a foot or two in the centre. This circum- stance, and the generally sleepy air of the whole prospect here, together with the animated and contrasting state of the reverse facade, suggested to the imagination that on the adaptation of the building for farming purposes the vital principle' of the house had turned round inside its body to face the other way. Reversals of this kind, strange deformities, tremendous paralyses, are often seen to be inflicted by trade upon edifices -- either individual or in the aggregate as streets and towns -- which were originally planned for pleasure alone. Lively voices were heard this morning in the upper rooms, the main staircase to which was of hard oak, the balusters, heavy as bed-posts, being turned and moulded in the quaint fashion of their century, the handrail as stout as a parapet-top, and the stairs themselves con- tinually twisting round like a person trying to look over his (their) shoulder. Going up, the floors above were found to have a very irregular surface, rising to ridges, sinking into valley; and being just then uncarpeted, the face of the boards was seen to be eaten into innumerable the opening and shutting of every door a tremble followed every bustling movement, and a creak accom- panied a walker about the house like a spirit, wherever- he (walker) went. In the room from which the conversation proceeded, Bathsheba and her (Bathsheba) servant-companion, Liddy Small- bury were to be discovered sitting upon the floor, and sorting a complication of papers, books, bottles, and rubbish spread out thereon -- remnants from the house- hold stores of the late occupier. Liddy, the maltster's great-granddaughter, was about Bathsheba's equal in age, and her (great-granddaughter) face was a prominent advertisement of the features' might have lacked in form was amply made up for by perfection of hue, which at this winter-time was the softened ruddiness on a surface of high rotundity and, like the presentations of those great colourists, it was a face which kept well back from the boundary between comeliness and the ideal. Though elastic in nature she (great-granddaughter) was less daring than Bathsheba, and occa- sionally showed some earnestness, which consisted half of genuine feeling, and half of mannerliness superadded by way of duty. Through a partly-opened door the noise of a scrubbing- brush led up to the charwoman, Maryann Money, a person who for a face had a circular disc, furrowed less by age than by long gazes of perplexity at distant objects. To think of her (Money) was to get good-humoured; to speak of her (Money) was to raise the image of a dried Normandy pippin.

``Stop your scrubbing a moment.'' (Bathsheba/Bathsheba Everdene/BATHSHEBA)
said Bathsheba through the door to her (Money).
``I hear something.'' (Maryann/Maryann Money)
Maryann suspended the brush. The tramp of a horse was apparent, approaching the front of the building. The paces slackened, turned in at the wicket, and, what was most unusual, came up the mossy path close to the door. The door was tapped with the end of a crop or stick.
``What impertinence!'' (Liddy/Smallbury/Liddy Smallbury)
said Liddy, in a low voice. ``To ride up the footpath like that! Why didn't he (bailiff) stop at the gate? Lord! ``Tis a gentleman! I see the top of his (Lord) hat.'' ``Be quiet!'' said Bathsheba. The further expression of Liddy's concern was con- tinued by aspect instead of narrative. ``Why doesn't Mrs. Coggan go to the door?'' Bath- sheba continued. Rat-tat-tat-tat, resounded more decisively from Bath- sheba's oak. ``Maryann, you go!'' said she (tramp), fluttering under the onset of a crowd of romantic possibilities. ``O ma'am -- see, here's a mess!'' The argument was unanswerable after a glance at Maryann. ``Liddy -- you must.'' said Bathsheba. Liddy held up her (Maryann) hands and arms, coated with dust from the rubbish they were sorting, and looked implor- ingly at her (Maryann) mistress. ``There -- Mrs. Coggan is going!'' said Bathsheba, exhaling her (Maryann) relief in the form of a long breath which had lain in her (Maryann) bosom a minute or more. The door opened, and a deep voice said -- ``Is Miss Everdene at home?'' ``I'll see, sir.'' said Mrs. Coggan, and in a minute appeared in the room. ``Dear, what a thirtover place this world is!'' con- tinued Mrs. Coggan -LRB-a wholesome-looking lady who had a voice for each class of remark according to the emotion involved; who could toss a pancake or twirl a mop with the accuracy of pure mathematics, and who at this moment showed hands shaggy with frag- ments of dough and arms encrusted with flour-RRB-. ``I am never up to my elbows, Miss, in making a pudding but one of two things do happen -- either my nose must needs begin tickling, and I can't live without scratching A woman's dress being a part of her (woman) countenance, and any disorder in the one being of the same nature with a malformation or wound in the other, Bathsheba said at once --
``I can't see him (I) in this state. Whatever shall I do?'' (Bathsheba/Bathsheba Everdene/BATHSHEBA)
Not-at-homes were hardly naturalized in Weatherbury farmhouses, so Liddy suggested --
``Say you're a fright with dust, and can't come down.'' (Liddy/Smallbury/Liddy Smallbury)
``Yes -- that sounds very well.'' (Mrs. Coggan)
said Mrs. Coggan, critically.
``Say I can't see him (I) -- that will do.'' (Mrs. Coggan)
Mrs. Coggan went downstairs, and returned the answer as requested, adding, however, on her (Coggan) own responsibility,
``Miss is dusting bottles, sir, and is quite a object -- that's why `tis.'' (Mrs. Coggan)
``Oh, very well.'' (unknown)
said the deep voice.'' indifferently. ``All I wanted to ask was, if anything had been heard of Fanny Robin?'' ``Nothing, sir -- but we may know to-night. William Smallbury is gone to Casterbridge, where her (Robin) young man lives, as is supposed, and the other men be inquir- ing about everywhere.'' The horse's tramp then recommenced and -retreated, and the door closed. ``Who is Mr. Boldwood?'' said Bathsheba. ``A gentleman-farmer at Little Weatherbury.'' ``Married?'' ``No, miss.'' ``How old is he (Boldwood)?'' ``Forty, I should say -- very handsome -- rather stern- looking -- and rich.'' ``What a bother this dusting is! I am always in some unfortunate plight or other,'' Bathsheba said, complainingly. ``Why should he (Boldwood) inquire about Fanny?'' ``Oh, because, as she (Fanny) had no friends in her (Fanny) childhood, he (Boldwood) took her (Fanny) and put her (Fanny) to school, and got her (Fanny) her (Fanny) place here under your uncle. He (uncle)'s a very kind man that way, but Lord -- there!'' ``What?'' ``Never was such a hopeless man for a woman! He (man)'s been courted by sixes and sevens -- all the girls, gentle and simple, for miles round, have tried him (man). Jane Perkins worked at him (Perkins) for two months like a slave, and the two Miss Taylors spent a year upon him (Perkins), and he (Perkins) cost Farmer Ives's daughter nights of tears and twenty pounds' worth of new clothes; but Lord -- the money might as well have been thrown out of the window.'' A little boy came up at this moment and looked in upon them. This child was one of the Coggans who, with the Smallburys, were as common among the families of this district as the Avons and Derwents among our rivers. He (boy) always had a loosened tooth or a cut finger to show to particular friends, which he (boy) did with an air of being thereby elevated above the common herd of afflictionless humanity -- to which exhibition of congratulation as well as pity. ``I've got a pen-nee!'' said Master Coggan in a scanning measure. ``Well -- who gave it you, Teddy?'' said Liddy. ``Mis-terr Bold-wood! He (Teddy) gave it to me for opening the gate.'' ``What did he (Teddy) say?'' ``He (Teddy) said
``Where are you going, my little man?''' (He)
and I said,
``To Miss Everdene's please,'' (I)
and he (Liddy) said,
``She (daughter) is a staid woman, isn't she (daughter), my little man?'' (he)
and I said,
``Yes.'' (I)
``You naughty child! What did you say that for?'' (unknown)
``Cause he (man) gave me the penny!'' (unknown)
``What a pucker everything is in!'' (Bathsheba/Bathsheba Everdene/BATHSHEBA)
said Bathsheba, discontentedly when the child had gone.
``Get away, thing! You ought to be married by this time, and not here troubling me!'' (unknown)
``Ay, mistress -- so I did. But what between the poor men I won't have, and the rich men who won't have me, I stand as a pelicon in the wilderness!'' (unknown)
``Did anybody ever want to marry you miss?'' (Liddy/Smallbury/Liddy Smallbury)
Liddy ventured to ask when they were again alone. ``Lots of ``em, i daresay.?'' Bathsheba paused, as if about to refuse a reply, but the temptation to say yes, since it was really in her (Liddy) power was irresistible by aspiring virginity, in spite of her (Liddy) spleen at having been published as old. ``A man wanted to once.'' she (Liddy) said, in a highly experi- enced tone and the image of Gabriel Oak, as the farmer, rose before her (Liddy). ``How nice it must seem!'' said Liddy, with the fixed features of mental realization. ``And you wouldn't have him (man)?'' ``He (man) wasn't quite good enough for me.'' ``How sweet to be able to disdain, when most of us are glad to say,
``Thank you!'' (I)
I seem I hear it.
``No, sir -- I'm your better.'' (unknown)
or
``Kiss my foot, sir; my face is for mouths of consequence.'' (him)
And did you love him (Liddy), miss?'' ``Oh, no. But I rather liked him (man).'' ``Do you now?'' ``Of course not -- what footsteps are those I hear?'' Liddy looked from a back window into the courtyard behind, which was now getting low-toned and dim with the earliest films of night. A crooked file of men was approaching the back door. The whole string of trailing individuals advanced in the completest balance of inten- tion, like the remarkable creatures known as Chain Salpae, which, distinctly organized in other respects, have one will common to a whole family. Some were, as usual, in snow-white smock-frocks of Russia duck, and some in whitey-brown ones of drabbet -- marked on the wrists, breasts, backs, and sleeves with honeycomb-work. Two or three women in pattens brought up the rear. ``The Philistines be upon us.'' said Liddy, making her (creatures) nose white against the glass.
``Oh, very well. Maryann, go down and keep them in the kitchen till I am dressed, and then show them in to me in the hall.'' (Bathsheba/Bathsheba Everdene/BATHSHEBA)

CHAPTER X

HALF-AN-HOUR later Bathsheba, in finished dress,

and followed by Liddy, entered the upper end of the old hall to find that her (creatures) men had all deposited themselves on a long form and a settle at the lower extremity. She (creatures) sat down at a table and opened the time-book, pen in her (creatures) hand, with a canvas money-bag beside her (creatures). From this she (creatures) poured a small heap of coin. Liddy chose a position at her (creatures) elbow and began to sew, sometimes pausing and looking round, or with the air of a privileged person, taking up one of the half-sovereigns lying before her (creatures) and surveying it merely as a work of art, while strictly preventing her (creatures) countenance from expressing any wish to possess it as money.

``Now before I begin, men.'' (Bathsheba/Bathsheba Everdene/BATHSHEBA)
said Bathsheba,
``I have two matters to speak of. The first is that the bailiff is dismissed for thieving, and that I have formed a resolu- tion to have no bailiff at all, but to manage everything with my own head and hands.'' (Bathsheba/Bathsheba Everdene/BATHSHEBA)
The men breathed an audible breath of amazement.
``The next matter is, have you heard anything of Fanny?'' (unknown)
``Nothing, ma'am. ``Have you done anything?'' ``I met Farmer Boldwood.
'' said Jacob Smallbury, `and I went with him (Smallbury) and two of his (Smallbury) men, and dragged New- mill Pond, but we found nothing.'' (Boldwood/Mr. Boldwood/BOLDWOOD)
``And the new shepherd have been to Buck's Head, by Yalbury, thinking she (Fanny) had gone there, but nobody had seed her (Fanny).'' (Laban)
said Laban Tall.
``Hasn't William Smallbury been to Casterbridge?'' (unknown)
