But you know well enough how it is, and who she (man) is that I like too well, and feel too much like a fool about to be civil to her (man)!
'' It is more than probable that she (Sergeant) privately and un- consciously respected him (Gabriel) a little for this grim fidelity, which had been shown in his (Gabriel) tone even more than in his (Gabriel) words. At any rate she (Sergeant) murmured something to the effect that he (Gabriel) might stay if he (Gabriel) wished. She (Sergeant) said more distinctly, '' (a fool)
Will you leave me alone now? I don't order it as a mistress -- I ask it as a woman, and I expect you not to be so uncourteous as to refuse.''
``Certainly I will, Miss Everdene.'' (unknown)
said Gabriel, gently. He (Gabriel) wondered that the request should have come at this moment, for the strife was over, and they were on a most desolate hill, far from every human habitation, and the hour was getting late. He (Gabriel) stood still and allowed her (woman) to get far ahead of him (Gabriel) till he (Gabriel) could only see her (woman) form upon the sky. A distressing explanation of this anxiety to be rid of him (Gabriel) at that point now ensued. A figure apparently rose from the earth beside her (woman). The shape beyond all doubt was Troy's. Oak would not be even a possible listener, and at once turned back till a good two hundred yards were between the lovers and himself. Gabriel went home by way of the churchyard. In passing the tower he (Gabriel) thought of what she (woman) had said about the sergeant's virtuous habit of entering the church un- PARTICULARS OF A TWILIGHT WALK perceived at the beginning of service. Believing that the little gallery door alluded to was quite disused, he (Gabriel) ascended the external flight of steps at the top of which it stood, and examined it. The pale lustre yet hanging in the north-western heaven was sufficient to show that a sprig of ivy had grown from the wall across the door to a length of more than a foot, delicately tying the panel to the stone jamb. It was a decisive proof that the door had not been opened at least since Troy came back to Weatherbury.

CHAPTER XXX

HOT CHEEKS AND TEARFUL EYES

HALF an hour later Bathsheba entered her (it) own house. There burnt upon her (it) face when she (it) met the light of the candles the flush and excitement which were little less than chronic with her (it) now. The farewell words of Troy, who had accompanied her (it) to the very door, still lingered in her (it) ears. He (it) had bidden her (it) adieu for two days, which were so he (it) stated, to be spent at Bath in visiting some friends. He (it) had also kissed her (it) a second time. It is only fair to Bathsheba to explain here a little fact which did not come to light till a long time after- wards: that Troy's presentation of himself so aptly at the roadside this evening was not by any distinctly pre- concerted arrangement. He (it) had hinted -- she (Troy) had forbidden; and it was only on the chance of his (it) still coming that she (Troy) had dismissed Oak, fearing a meeting between them just then. She (Troy) now sank down into a chair, wild and perturbed by all these new and fevering sequences. Then she (Troy) jumped up with a manner of decision, and fetched her (Troy) desk from a side table. In three minutes, without pause or modification, she (Troy) had written a letter to Boldwood, at his (Boldwood) address beyond Casterbridge, saying mildly but firmly that she (Troy) had well considered the whole subject he (Boldwood) had brought before her (Troy) and kindly given her (Troy) time to decide upon; that her (Troy) final decision was that she (Troy) could not marry him (Boldwood). She (Troy) had expressed to Oak an intention to wait till Boldwood came home before communicating to him (Boldwood) her (Troy) conclusive reply. But Bathsheba found that she (Troy) could not wait. It was impossible to send this letter till the next day; yet to quell her (Troy) uneasiness by getting it out of her (Troy) hands, and so, as it were, setting the act in motion at once, she (Troy) arose to take it to any one of the women who might be in the kitchen. She (Troy) paused in the passage. A dialogue was going on in the kitchen, and Bathsheba and Troy were the subject of it.

``If he (fool) marry her (man), she (man)'ll gie up farming.'' (unknown)
``Twill be a gallant life, but may bring some trouble between the mirth -- so say I.'' (Bathsheba/Bathsheba Everdene/BATHSHEBA)
``Well, I wish I had half such a husband.'' (Bathsheba/Bathsheba Everdene/BATHSHEBA)
Bathsheba had too much sense to mind seriously what her (Troy) servitors said about her (Troy); but too much womanly redundance of speech to leave alone what was said till it died the natural death of unminded things. She (Troy) burst in upon them.
``Who are you speaking of?'' (she)
she (Troy) asked. There was a pause before anybody replied. At last Liddy said frankly,
'' What was passing was a bit of a word about yourself, miss.'' (Liddy/Smallbury/Liddy Smallbury)
``I thought so! Maryann and Liddy and Temper- ance -- now I forbid you to suppose such things. You know I don't care the least for Mr. Troy -- not I. Every- body knows how much I hate him (Troy). -- Yes.'' (the froward person)
repeated the froward young person,
``HATE him (Troy)!'' (the froward person)
``We know you do, miss.'' (Liddy/Smallbury/Liddy Smallbury)
said Liddy;
``and so do we all.'' (Liddy/Smallbury/Liddy Smallbury)
``I hate him (Troy) too.'' (Maryann/Maryann Money)
said Maryann.
``Maryann -- O you perjured woman! How can you speak that wicked story!'' (Bathsheba/Bathsheba Everdene/BATHSHEBA)
said Bathsheba, excitedly.
``You admired him (Troy) from your heart only this morning in the very world, you did. Yes, Maryann, you know it!'' (unknown)
``Yes, miss, but so did you. He (Troy) is a wild scamp now, and you are right to hate him (Troy).'' (unknown)
``He (Troy)'s NOT a wild scamp! How dare you to my face! I have no right to hate him (Troy), nor you, nor anybody. But I am a silly woman! What is it to me what he (Troy) is? You know it is nothing. I don't care for him (Troy); I don``t mean to defend his (Troy) good name, not I. Mind this, if any of you say a word against him (Troy) you'll be dismissed instantly!'' She (Maryann) flung down the letter and surged back into the parlour, with a big heart and tearful eyes, Liddy following her (Maryann). ``O miss!'' said mild Liddy, looking pitifully into Bathsheba's face. ``I am sorry we mistook you so! did think you cared for him (Troy); but I see you don't now.'' ``Shut the door, Liddy.
'' Liddy closed the door, and went on: '' (Liddy/Smallbury/Liddy Smallbury)
People always say such foolery, miss. I'll make answer hencefor`ard,
``Of course a lady like Miss Everdene can't love him (Liddy);'' (I)
I'll say it out in plain black and white.'' Bathsheba burst out: ``O Liddy, are you such a simpleton? Can't you read riddles? Can't you see? Are you a woman yourself?'' Liddy's clear eyes rounded with wonderment. ``Yes; you must be a blind thing, Liddy!'' she (Maryann) said, in reckless abandonment and grief. ``O, I love him (Liddy) to very distraction and misery and agony! Don't be frightened at me, though perhaps I am enough to frighten any innocent woman. Come closer -- closer.'' She (Maryann) put her (Maryann) arms round Liddy's neck. ``I must let it out to somebody; it is wearing me away! Don't you yet know enough of me to see through that miserable denial of mine? O God, what a lie it was! Heaven and my Love forgive me. And don't you know that a woman who loves at all thinks nothing of perjury when it is balanced against her (woman) love? There, go out of the room; I want to be quite alone.'' Liddy went towards the door. ``Liddy, come here. Solemnly swear to me that he (Liddy)'s not a fast man; that it is all lies they say about him (Liddy)!'' ``Put, miss, how can I say he (Liddy) is not if -- -- '' ``You graceless girl! How can you have the cruel heart to repeat what they say? Unfeeling thing that you are... But I
``LL see if you or anybody else in the village, or town either, dare do such a thing!'' (I)
She (Maryann) started off, pacing from fireplace to door, and back again.
``No, miss. I don't -- I know it is not true!'' (Liddy/Smallbury/Liddy Smallbury)
said Liddy, frightened at Bathsheba's unwonted vehemence. I suppose you only agree with me like that to please me. But, Liddy, he (Liddy) CANNOT BE had, as is said. Do you hear? '' ``Yes, miss, yes.'' ``And you don't believe he (Liddy) is?'' ``I don't know what to say, miss.'' said Liddy, be- ginning to cry. ``If I say No, you don
``t believe me; and if I say Yes, you rage at me!'' (I)
``Say you don't believe it -- say you don't!'' (unknown)
``I don't believe him (Liddy) to be so had as they make out.'' (unknown)
``He (Liddy) is not had at all... My poor life and heart, how weak I am!'' (she)
she (Maryann) moaned, in a relaxed, desultory way, heedless of Liddy's presence.
``O, how I wish I had never seen him (Liddy)! Loving is misery for women always. I shall never forgive God for making me a woman, and dearly am I beginning to pay for the honour of owning a pretty face.'' (She)
She (Maryann) freshened and turned to Liddy suddenly.
``Mind this, Lydia Smallbury, if you repeat anywhere a single word of what l have said to you inside this closed door, I'll never trust you, or love you, or have you with me a moment longer -- not a moment!'' (unknown)
``I don't want to repeat anything.'' (Liddy/Smallbury/Liddy Smallbury)
said Liddy, with womanly dignity of a diminutive order;
``but I don't wish to stay with you. And, if you please, I'll go at the end of the harvest, or this week, or to-day... I don't see that I deserve to be put upon and stormed at for nothing!'' (Liddy/Smallbury/Liddy Smallbury)
concluded the small woman, bigly.
``No, no, Liddy; you must stay!'' (Bathsheba/Bathsheba Everdene/BATHSHEBA)
said Bathsheba, dropping from haughtiness to entreaty with capricious inconsequence.
``You must not notice my being in a taking just now. You are not as a servant -- you are a companion to me. Dear, dear -- I don't know what I am doing since this miserable ache o'! my heart has weighted and worn upon me so! What shall I come to! I suppose I shall get further and further into troubles. I wonder sometimes if I am doomed to die in the Union. I am friendless enough, God knows!'' (unknown)
``I won't notice anything, nor will I leave you!'' (Liddy/Smallbury/Liddy Smallbury)
sobbed Liddy, impulsively putting up her (woman) lips to Bathsheba's, and kissing her (woman). Then Bathsheba kissed Liddy, and all was smooth again.
``I don't often cry, do I, Lidd? but you have made tears come into my eyes.'' (she)
she (woman) said, a smile shining through the moisture.
``Try to think him (God) a good man, won't you, dear Liddy?'' (unknown)
``I will, miss, indeed.'' (unknown)
``He (Liddy) is a sort of steady man in a wild way, you know. way. I am afraid that's how I am. And promise me to keep my secret -- do, Liddy! And do not let them know that I have been crying about him (Liddy), because it will be dreadful for me, and no good to him (Liddy), poor thing!``Death's head himself shan't wring it from me, mistress, if I've a mind to keep anything; and I'll always be your friend.'' replied Liddy, emphatically, at the same time bringing a few more tears into her (woman) own eyes, not from any particular necessity, but from an artistic sense of making herself in keeping with the remainder of the picture, which seems to influence women at such times. ``I think God likes us to be good friends, don't you?'' ``Indeed I do.'' ``And, dear miss, you won
``t harry me and storm at me, will you? because you seem to swell so tall as a lion then, and it frightens me! Do you know, I fancy you would be a match for any man when you are in one O' your takings.'' (unknown)
``Never! do you?'' (Bathsheba/Bathsheba Everdene/BATHSHEBA)
said Bathsheba, slightly laughing, though somewhat seriously alarmed by this Amazonian picture of herself.
``I hope I am not a bold sort of maid -- mannish?'' (she)
she (woman) continued with some anxiety.
``O no, not mannish; but so almighty womanish that `tis getting on that way sometimes. Ah! miss.'' (she)
she (woman) said, after having drawn her (woman) breath very sadly in and sent it very sadly out, ``I wish I had half your failing that way.
``Tis a great protection to a poor maid in these illegit`mate days!'' (Bathsheba/Bathsheba Everdene/BATHSHEBA)

CHAPTER XXXI

BLAME -- FURY

THE next evening Bathsheba, with the idea of getting out of the way of Mr. Boldwood in the event of his (Boldwood) returning to answer her (woman) note in person, proceeded to fulfil an engagement made with Liddy some few hours earlier. Bathsheba's companion, as a gage of their reconciliation, had been granted a week's holiday to visit her (woman) sister, who was married to a thriving hurdler and cattle-crib-maker living in a delightful labyrinth of hazel copse not far beyond Yalbury. The arrangement was that Miss Everdene should honour them by coming there for a day or two to inspect some ingenious con- trivances which this man of the woods had introduced into his (man) wares. Leaving her (woman) instructions with Gabriel and Maryann, that they were to see everything carefully locked up for the night, she (woman) went out of the house just at the close of a timely thunder-shower, which had refined the air, and daintily bathed the coat of the land, though all beneath was dry as ever. Freshness was exhaled in an essence from the varied contours of bank and hollow, as if the earth breathed maiden breath; and the pleased birds were hymning to the scene. Before her (woman), among the clouds, there was a contrast in the shape of lairs of fierce light which showed themselves in the neighbour- hood of a hidden sun, lingering on to the farthest north- west corner of the heavens that this midsummer season allowed. She (woman) had walked nearly two miles of her (woman) journey, watching how the day was retreating, and thinking how the time of deeds was quietly melting into the time of thought, to give place in its turn to the time of prayer and sleep, when she (woman) beheld advancing over Yalbury hill the very man she (woman) sought so anxiously to elude. Boldwood was stepping on, not with that quiet tread of reserved strength which was his (Boldwood) customary gait, in which he (Boldwood) always seemed to be balancing two thoughts. His (Boldwood) manner was stunned and sluggish now. Boldwood had for the first time been awakened to woman's privileges in tergiversation even when it involves another person's possible blight. That Bathsheba was a firm and positive girl, far less inconsequent than her (girl) fellows, had been the very lung of his (Boldwood) hope; for he (Boldwood) had held that these qualities would lead her (girl) to adhere to a straight course for consistency's sake, and accept him (Boldwood), though her (girl) fancy might not flood him (Boldwood) with the iridescent hues of uncritical love. But the argument now came back as sorry gleams from a broken mirror. The dis- covery was no less a scourge than a surprise. He (Boldwood) came on looking upon the ground, and did not see Bathsheba till they were less than a stone's throw apart. He (Boldwood) looked up at the sound of her (girl) pit-pat, and his (Boldwood) changed appearance sufficiently denoted to her (girl) the depth and strength of the feelings paralyzed by her (girl) letter.

``Oh; is it you, Mr. Boldwood?'' (she)
she (girl) faltered, a guilty warmth pulsing in her (girl) face. Those who have the power of reproaching in silence may find it a means more effective than words. There are accents in the eye which are not on the tongue, and more tales come from pale lips than can enter an ear. It is both the grandeur and the pain of the remoter moods that they avoid the pathway of sound. Bold- wood's look was unanswerable. Seeing she (girl) turned a little aside, he (girl) said,
``What, are you afraid of me?'' (he)
Why should you say that?'' said Bathsheba. ``I fancied you looked so.'' said he (girl). ``And it is most strange, because of its contrast with my feeling for you. She (maid) regained self-possession, fixed her (maid) eyes calmly, and waited.
``You know what that feeling is.'' (Boldwood/Mr. Boldwood/BOLDWOOD)
continued Boldwood, deliberately.
``A thing strong as death. No dismissal by a hasty letter affects that.'' (unknown)
``I wish you did not feel so strongly about me.'' (she)
she (girl) murmured.
``It is generous of you, and more than I deserve, but I must not hear it now.'' (unknown)
``Hear it? What do you think I have to say, then? I am not to marry you, and that's enough. Your letter was excellently plain. I want you to hear nothing -- not I.'' (Bathsheba/Bathsheba Everdene/BATHSHEBA)
Bathsheba was unable to direct her (girl) will into any definite groove for freeing herself from this fearfully and was moving on. Boldwood walked up to her (girl) heavily and dully.
``Bathsheba -- darling -- is it final indeed?'' (unknown)
``Indeed it is.'' (unknown)
``O, Bathsheba -- have pity upon me!'' (Boldwood/Mr. Boldwood/BOLDWOOD)
Boldwood burst out.
``God's sake, yes -- I am come to that low, lowest stage -- to ask a woman for pity! Still, she (woman) is you -- she (woman) is you.'' (Bathsheba/Bathsheba Everdene/BATHSHEBA)
Bathsheba commanded herself well. But she (girl) could hardly get a clear voice for what came instinctively to her (girl) lips:
``There is little honour to the woman in that speech.'' (she)
It was only whispered, for something unutter- ably mournful no less than distressing in this spectacle of a man showing himself to be so entirely the vane of a passion enervated the feminine instinct for punctilios.
``I am beyond myself about this, and am mad.'' (he)
he (man) said.
``I am no stoic at all to he (God) supplicating here; but I do supplicate to you. I wish you knew what is in me of devotion to you; but it is impossible, that. In bare human mercy to a lonely man, don't throw me off now!'' (unknown)
``I don't throw you off -- indeed, how can I? I never had you.'' (she)
In her (girl) noon-clear sense that she (girl) had never loved him (man) she (girl) forgot for a moment her (girl) thoughtless angle on that day in February.
``But there was a time when you turned to me, before I thought of you! I don't reproach you, for even now I feel that the ignorant and cold darkness that I should have lived in if you had not attracted me by that letter -- valentine you call it -- would have been worse than my knowledge of you, though it has brought this misery. But, I say, there was a time when I knew nothing of you, and cared nothing for you, and yet you drew me on. And if you say you gave me no en- couragement, I cannot but contradict you.'' (unknown)
``What you call encouragement was the childish game of an idle minute. I have bitterly repented of it -- ay, bitterly, and in tears. Can you still go on re- minding me?'' (unknown)
``I don't accuse you of it -- I deplore it. I took for earnest what you insist was jest, and now this that I pray to be jest you say is awful, wretched earnest. Our moods meet at wrong places. I wish your feeling was more like mine, or my feeling more like yours! O, could I but have foreseen the torture that trifling trick was going to lead me into, how I should have cursed you; but only having been able to see it since, I cannot do that, for I love you too well! But it is weak, idle drivelling to go on like this... Bathsheba, you are the first woman of any shade or nature that I have ever looked at to love, and it is the having been so near claiming you for my own that makes this denial so hard to bear. How nearly you promised me! But I don't speak now to move your heart, and make you grieve because of my pain; it is no use, that. I must bear it; my pain would get no less by paining you.'' (unknown)
``But I do pity you -- deeply -- O so deeply!'' (she)
she (girl) earnestly said.
``Do no such thing -- do no such thing. Your dear love, Bathsheba, is such a vast thing beside your pity, that the loss of your pity as well as your love is no great addition to my sorrow, nor does the gain of your pity make it sensibly less. O sweet -- how dearly you spoke to me behind the spear-bed at the washing-pool, and in the barn at the shearing, and that dearest last time in the evening at your home! Where are your pleasant words all gone -- your earnest hope to be able to love me? Where is your firm conviction that you would get to care for me very much? Really forgotten? -- really?'' (She)
She (girl) checked emotion, looked him (man) quietly and clearly in the face, and said in her (girl) low, firm voice,
'' Mr. Bold- wood, I promised you nothing. Would you have had me a woman of clay when you paid me that furthest, highest compliment a man can pay a woman -- telling her (woman) he (man) loves her (woman)? I was bound to show some feeling, if l would not be a graceless shrew. Yet each of those pleasures was just for the day -- the day just for the pleasure. How was I to know that what is a pastime to all other men was death to you? Have reason, do, and think more kindly of me!'' (him)
``Well, never mind arguing -- never mind. One thing is sure: you were all but mine, and now you are not nearly mine. Everything is changed, and that by you alone, remember. You were nothing to me once, and I was contented; you are now nothing to me again, and how different the second nothing is from the first! Would to God you had never taken me up, since it was only to throw me down!'' (Bathsheba/Bathsheba Everdene/BATHSHEBA)
Bathsheba, in spite of her (woman) mettle, began to feel un- mistakable signs that she (woman) was inherently the weaker vessel. She (woman) strove miserably against this feminity which would insist upon supplying unbidden emotions in stronger and stronger current. She (woman) had tried to elude agitation by fixing her (woman) mind on the trees, sky, any trivial object before her (woman) eyes, whilst his (you) reproaches fell, but ingenuity could not save her (woman) now.
``I did not take you up -- surely I did not!'' (she)
she (woman) answered as heroically as she (woman) could.
``But don't be in this mood with me. I can endure being told I am in the wrong, if you will only tell it me gently! O sir, will you not kindly forgive me, and look at it cheerfully?'' (unknown)
``Cheerfully! Can a man fooled to utter heart- burning find a reason for being merry> If I have lost, how can I be as if I had won? Heavens you must be heartless quite! Had I known what a fearfully bitter sweet this was to be, how would I have avoided you, and never seen you, and been deaf of you. I tell you all this, but what do you care! You don't care.'' (She)
She (woman) returned silent and weak denials to his (you) charges, and swayed her (woman) head desperately, as if to thrust away the words as they came showering about her (woman) ears from the lips of the trembling man in the climax of life, with his (man) bronzed Roman face and fine frame.
``Dearest, dearest, I am wavering even now between the two opposites of recklessly renouncing you, and labouring humbly for you again. Forget that you have said No, and let it be as it was! Say, Bathsheba, that you only wrote that refusal to me in fun -- come, say it to me!'' (unknown)
``It would be untrue, and painful to both of us. You overrate my capacity for love. I don't possess half the warmth of nature you believe me to have. An un- protected childhood in a cold world has beaten gentle- ness out of me.'' (He)
He (man) immediately said with more resentment:
``That may be true, somewhat; but ah, Miss Everdene, it won't do as a reason! You are not the cold woman you would have me believe. No, no! It isn't because you have no feeling in you that you don't love me. You naturally would have me think so -- you would hide from that you have a burning heart like mine. You have love enough, but it is turned into a new channel. I know where.'' (He)
The swift music of her (woman) heart became hubbub now, and she (woman) throbbed to extremity. He (man) was coming to Troy. He (man) did then know what had occurred! And the name fell from his (man) lips the next moment.
``Why did Troy not leave my treasure alone?'' (he)
he (man) asked, fiercely.
``When I had no thought of injuring him (you), why did he (you) force himself upon your notice! Before he (you) worried you your inclination was to have me; when next I should have come to you your answer would have been Yes. Can you deny it -- I ask, can you deny it?'' (She)
She (woman) delayed the reply, but was to honest to with hold it.
'' I cannot.'' (She)
she (woman) whispered.
``I know you cannot. But he (you) stole in in my absence and robbed me. Why did't he (you) win you away before, when nobody would have been grieved? -- when nobody would have been set tale-bearing. Now the people sneer at me -- the very hills and sky seem to laugh at me till I blush shamefuly for my folly. I have lost my respect, my good name, my standing -- lost it, never to get it again. Go and marry your man -- go on!'' (unknown)
``O sir -- Mr. Boldwood!'' (unknown)
``You may as well. I have no further claim upon you. As for me, I had better go somewhere alone, and hide -- and pray. I loved a woman once. I am now ashamed. When I am dead they'll say, Miserable love-sick man that he (man) was. Heaven -- heaven -- if I had got jilted secretly, and the dishonour not known, and my position kept! But no matter, it is gone, and the woman not gained. Shame upon him (man) -- shame!'' (her)
His (man) unreasonable anger terrified her (woman), and she (woman) glided from him (man), without obviously moving, as she (woman) said,
``I am only a girl -- do not speak to me so!'' (she)
``All the time you knew -- how very well you knew -- that your new freak was my misery. Dazzled by brass and scarlet -- O, Bathsheba -- this is woman's folly indeed!'' (She)
She (woman) fired up at once.
``You are taking too much upon yourself!'' (she)
she (woman) said, vehemently.
``Everybody is upon me -- everybody. It is unmanly to attack a woman so! I have nobody in the world to fight my battles for me; but no mercy is shown. Yet if a thousand of you sneer and say things against me, I WILL NOT be put down!'' (unknown)
``You'll chatter with him (freak) doubtless about me. Say to him (freak), ``Boldwood would have died for me.
'' Yes, and you have given way to him (man), knowing him (man) to be not the man for you. He (man) has kissed you -- claimed you as his (man). Do you hear -- he (man) has kissed you. Deny it!'' (me)
The most tragic woman is cowed by a tragic man, and although Boldwood was, in vehemence and glow, nearly her (woman) own self rendered into another sex, Bathsheba's cheek quivered. She (woman) gasped,
'' Leave me, sir -- leave me! I am nothing to you. Let me go on!'' (She)
``Deny that he (Boldwood) has kissed you.'' (unknown)
``I shall not.'' (unknown)
``Ha -- then he (Boldwood) has!'' (the farmer)
came hoarsely from the farmer.
``He (Boldwood) has,'' (she)
she (woman) said, slowly, and, in spite of her (woman) fear, defiantly.
``I am not ashamed to speak the truth.'' (unknown)
``Then curse him (Boldwood); and curse him (Boldwood)!'' (Boldwood/Mr. Boldwood/BOLDWOOD)
said Boldwood, breaking into a whispered fury.
'' Whilst I would have given worlds to touch your hand, you have let a rake come in without right or ceremony and -- kiss you! Heaven's mercy -- kiss you! ... Ah, a time of his (Boldwood) life shall come when he (Boldwood) will have to repent, and think wretchedly of the pain he (Boldwood) has caused another man; and then may he (Boldwood) ache, and wish, and curse, and yearn -- as I do now!'' (Boldwood/Mr. Boldwood/BOLDWOOD)
``Don't, don't, O, don't pray down evil upon him (Boldwood)!'' (she)
she (woman) implored in a miserable cry.
``Anything but that -- anything. O, be kind to him (Boldwood), sir, for I love him (Boldwood) true .'' (Boldwood/Mr. Boldwood/BOLDWOOD)
Boldwood's ideas had reached that point of fusion at which outline and consistency entirely disappear. The impending night appeared to concentrate in his (Boldwood) eye. He (Boldwood) did not hear her (woman) at all now.
``I'll punish him (Boldwood) -- by my soul, that will I! I'll meet him (Boldwood), soldier or no, and I'll horsewhip the untimely stripling for this reckless theft of my one delight. If he (Boldwood) were a hundred men I'd horsewhip him (Boldwood) -- --'' (He)
He (Boldwood) dropped his (Boldwood) voice suddenly and unnaturally.
``Bath- sheba, sweet, lost coquette, pardon me! I've been blaming you, threatening you, behaving like a churl to you, when he (Boldwood)'s the greatest sinner. He (Boldwood) stole your dear heart away with his (Boldwood) unfathomable lies! ... lt is a fortunate thing for him (Boldwood) that he (Boldwood)'s gone back to his (Boldwood) regiment -- that he (Boldwood)'s away up the country, and not here! I hope he (Boldwood) may not return here just yet. I pray God he (God) may not come into my sight, for I may be tempted beyond myself. O, Bathsheba, keep him (God) away -- yes, keep him (God) away from me!'' (Boldwood/Mr. Boldwood/BOLDWOOD)
For a moment Boldwood stood so inertly after this that his (Boldwood) soul seemed to have been entirely exhaled with the breath of his (Boldwood) passionate words. He (Boldwood) turned his (Boldwood) face away, and withdrew, and his (Boldwood) form was soon covered over by the twilight as his (Boldwood) footsteps mixed in with the low hiss of the leafy trees. Bathsheba, who had been standing motionless as a model all this latter time, flung her (woman) hands to her (woman) face, and wildly attempted to ponder on the exhibition which had just passed away. Such astounding wells of fevered feeling in a still man like Mr. Boldwood were incompre- hensible, dreadful. Instead of being a man trained to repression he (man) was -- what she (woman) had seen him (man). The force of the farmer's threats lay in their relation to a circumstance known at present only to herself: her (woman) lover was coming back to Weatherby in the course of the very next day or two. Troy had not returned to his (lover) distant barracks as Boldwood and others supposed, but had merely gone to visit some acquaintance in Bath, and had yet a week or more remaining to his (Boldwood) furlough. She (Troy) felt wretchedly certain that if he (Boldwood) revisited her (Troy) just at this nick of time, and came into contact with Boldwood,a fierce quarrel would be the consequence. She (Troy) panted with solicitude when she (Troy) thought of possible injury to Troy. The least spark would kindle the farmer's swift feelings of rage and jealousy; he (farmer) would lose his (farmer) self-mastery as he (farmer) had this evening; Troy's blitheness might become aggressive; it might take the direction of derision, and Boldwood's anger might then take the direction of revenge. With almost a morbid dread of being thought a gushing girl, this guileless woman too well concealed from the world under a manner of carelessness the warm depths of her (woman) strong emotions. But now there was no reserve. In fer her (woman) distraction, instead of advancing further she (woman) walked up and down, beating the air with her (woman) fingers, pressing on her (woman) brow, and sobbing brokenly to herself. Then she (woman) sat down on a heap of stones by the wayside to think. There she (woman) remained long. Above the dark margin of the earth appeared foreshores and promontor- ies of coppery cloud,bounding a green and pellucid expanse in the western sky. Amaranthine glosses came over them then, and the unresting world wheeled her (woman) round to a contrasting prospect eastward, in the shape of indecisive and palpitating stars. She (woman) gazed upon their silent throes amid the shades of space, but realised none at all. Her (woman) troubled spirit was far away with Troy.

CHAPTER XXXII

NIGHT -- HORSES TRAMPING

THE village of Weatherbury was quiet as the graveyard in its midst, and the living were lying well nigh as still as the dead. The church clock struck eleven. The air was so empty of other sounds that the whirr of the clock-work immediately before the strokes was distinct, and so was also the click of the same at their close. The notes flew forth with the usual blind obtuseness of inanimate things -- flapping and rebounding among walls, undulating against the scattered clouds, spreading through their interstices into unexplored miles of space. Bathsheba's crannied and mouldy halls were to-night occupied only by Maryann, Liddy being, as was stated, with her (Maryann) sister, whom Bathsheba had set out to visit. A few minutes after eleven had struck, Maryann turned in her (Maryann) bed with a sense of being disturbed. She (Maryann) was totally unconscious of the nature of the interruption to her (Maryann) sleep. It led to a dream, and the dream to an awakening, with an uneasy sensation that something had happened. She (Maryann) left her (Maryann) bed and looked out of the window. The paddock abutted on this end of the building, and in the paddock she (Maryann) could just discern by the uncertain gray a moving figure approaching the horse that was feeding there. The figure seized the horse by the forelock, and led it to the corner of the field. Here she (Maryann) could see some object which circum- stances proved to be a vehicle for after a few minutes the horse down the road, mingled with the sound of light wheels. Two varieties only of humanity could have entered the paddock with the ghostlike glide of that mysterious figure. They were a woman and a gipsy man. A woman was out of the question in such an occupation at this hour, and the comer could be no less than a thief, who might probably have known the weakness of the house- hold on this particular night, and have chosen it on that account for his (thief) daring attempt. Moreover, to raise suspicion to conviction itself, there were gipsies in! Weatherbury Bottom. Maryann, who had been afraid to shout in the robber's presence, having seen him (robber) depart had no fear. She (Maryann) hastily slipped on her (Maryann) clothes, stumped down the dis- jointed staircase with its hundred creaks, ran to Coggan's, the nearest house, and raised an alarm. Coggan called Gabriel, who now again lodged in his (Coggan) house as at first, and together they went to the paddock. Beyond all doubt the horse was gone.

``Hark!'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
said Gabriel. They listened. Distinct upon the stagnant air came the sounds of a trotting horse passing up Longpuddle Lane -- just beyond the gipsies' encampment in Weather- bury Bottom.
``That's our Dainty-i'll swear to her (my) step.'' (unknown)
said Jan.
``Mighty me! Won't mis`ess storm and call us stupids wen she (my) comes back!'' (Maryann/Maryann Money)
moaned Maryann.
``How I wish it had happened when she (my) was at home, and none of us had been answerable!'' (unknown)
``We must ride after.'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
said Gabriel, decisively. be responsible to Miss Everdene for what we do. Yes, we'll follow. '' ``Faith, I don't see how.'' said Coggan. ``All our horses are too heavy for that trick except little Poppet, and what's she (my) between two of us?-if we only had that pair over the hedge we might do something.'' ``Which pair?'' ``Mr Boldwood's Tidy and Moll.'' ``Then wait here till I come hither again.'' said Gabriel. He (Gabriel) ran down the hill towards Farmer Boldwood's. ``Farmer Boldwood is not at home.'' said Maryann. ``All the better.'' said Coggan. ``I know what he (Boldwood)'s gone for.'' Less than five minutes brought up Oak again, running at the same pace, with two halters dangling from his (Coggan) hand. ``Where did you find 'em?'' said Coggan, turning round and leaping upon the hedge without waiting for an answer. ``Under the eaves. I knew where they were kept,'' said Gabriel, following him (Gabriel). ``Coggan, you can ride bare-backed? there's no time to look for saddles.'' ``Like a hero!'' said Jan. ``Maryann, you go to hed.'' Gabriel shouted to her (Maryann) from the top of the hedge. Springing down into Boldwood's pastures, each pocketed his (Boldwood) halter to hide it from the horses, who, seeing the men empty-handed, docilely allowed them- selves to he (Boldwood) seized by the mane, when the halters were dexterously slipped on. Having neither bit nor bridle, Oak and Coggan extemporized the former by passing the rope in each case through the animal's mouth and looping it on the other side. Oak vaulted astride, and Coggan clambered up by aid of the hank, when they ascended to the gate and galloped off in the direction taken by Bathsheha's horse and the robber. Whose vehicle the horse had been harnessed to was a matter of some uncertainty. Weatherbury Bottom was reached in three or four minutes. They scanned the shady green patch by the roadside. The gipsies were gone. ``The villains!'' said Gabriel. ``Which way have they gone, I wonder?'' ``Straight on, as sure as God made little apples,'' said Jan. ``Very well; we are better mounted, and must over- discovered. The road-metal grew softer and more rain had wetted its surface to a somewhat plastic, but not muddy state. They came to cross-roads. Coggan suddenly pulled up Moll and slipped off.
``What's the matter?'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
said Gabriel.
``We must try to track 'em, since we can't hear 'em,'' (Coggan/Jan Coggan/Jan)
said Jan, fumbling in his (Gabriel) pockets. He (Gabriel) struck a light, and held the match to the ground. The rain had been heavier here, and all foot and horse tracks made previous to the storm had been abraded and blurred by the drops, and they were now so many little scoops of water, which reflected the flame of the match like eyes. One set of tracks was fresh and had no water in them; one pair of ruts was also empty, and not small canals, like the others. The footprints forming this recent impression were full of information as to pace; they were in equidistant pairs, three or four feet apart, the right and left foot of each pair being exactly opposite one another.
``Straight on!'' (Coggan/Jan Coggan/Jan)
Jan exclaimed. ``Tracks like that mean a stiff gallop. No wonder we don't hear him (Coggan). And the horse is harnessed -- look at the ruts. Ay, ``How do you know?'' ``Old Jimmy Harris only shoed her (They) last week, and I'd swear to his (Harris) make among ten thousand.'' ``The rest of the gipsies must ha
'' gone on earlier, or some other way.'' (the gipsies)
said Oak.
``You saw there were no other tracks?'' (unknown)
``True.'' (unknown)
They rode along silently for a long weary time. Coggan carried an old pinchbeck repeater which he (Coggan) had inherited from some genius in his (Coggan) family; and it now struck one. He (Coggan) lighted another match, and ex- amined the ground again.
''`Tis a canter now.'' (He)
he (Coggan) said, throwing away the light.
``A twisty, rickety pace for a gig. The fact is, they over- drove her (They) at starting, we shall catch 'em yet.'' (Blackmore)
Again they hastened on, and entered Blackmore Vale. Coggan's watch struck one. When they looked again the hoof-marks were so spaced as to form a sort of zigzag if united, like the lamps along a street.
``That's a trot, I know.'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
said Gabriel.
``Only a trot now.'' (Coggan/Jan Coggan/Jan)
said Coggan, cheerfully.
``We shall overtake him (Harris) in time.'' (unknown)
They pushed rapidly on for yet two or three miles.
``Ah! a moment.'' (unknown)
said Jan. ``Let's see how she (They) was driven up this hill. ``Twill help us.'' A light was promptly struck upon his (Gabriel) gaiters as before, and the ex- amination made, ``Hurrah!'' said Coggan. ``She (They) walked up here -- and well she (They) might. We shall get them in two miles, for a crown.'' They rode three, and listened. No sound was to be heard save a millpond trickling hoarsely through a hatch, and suggesting gloomy possibilities of drowning by jumping in. Gabriel dismounted when they came to a turning. The tracks were absolutely the only guide as to the direction that they now had, and great caution was necessary to avoid confusing them with some others which had made their appearance lately. ``What does this mean? -- though I guess.'' said Gabriel, looking up at Coggan as he (Coggan) moved the match over the ground about the turning. Coggan, who, no less than the panting horses, had latterly shown signs of weariness, again scrutinized the mystic characters. This time only three were of the regular horseshoe shape. Every fourth was a dot. He (Coggan) screwed up his (Coggan) face and emitted a long ``Whew-w-w!'' ``Lame.'' said Oak. ``Yes Dainty is lamed; the near-foot-afore.'' said Coggan slowly staring still at the footprints. ``We'll push on.'' said Gabriel, remounting his (Gabriel) humid steed. Although the road along its greater part had been as good as any turnpike-road in the country, it was nomin- ally only a byway. The last turning had brought them into the high road leading to Bath. Coggan recollected himself. ``We shall have him (Harris) now!'' he (Coggan) exclaimed. ``Where?'' ``Sherton Turnpike. The keeper of that gate is the sleepiest man between here and London -- Dan Randall. that's his (Randall) name -- knowed en for years, when he (Randall) was at Casterbridge gate. Between the lameness and the gate `tis a done job.'' ``Twas said until, against a shady background of foliage, five white bars were visible, crossing their route a little way ahead.
``Hush -- we are almost close!'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
said Gabriel.
``Amble on upon the grass.'' (Coggan/Jan Coggan/Jan)
said Coggan. The white bars were blotted out in the midst by a dark shape in front of them. The silence of this lonely time was pierced by an exclamation from that quarter.
``Hoy-a-hoy! Gate!'' (the keeper)
It appeared that there had been a previous call which they had not noticed, for on their close approach the door of the turnpike-house opened, and the keeper came out half-dressed, with a candle in his (keeper) hand. The rays illumined the whole group.
``Keep the gate close!'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
shouted Gabriel.
``He (Randall) has stolen the horse!'' (unknown)
Who?'' said the turnpike-man. Gabriel looked at the driver of the gig, and saw a woman -- Bathsheba, his (Gabriel) mistress. On hearing his (Gabriel) voice she (mistress) had turned her (mistress) face away from the light. Coggan had, however, caught sight of her (mistress) in the meanwhile. ``Why, `tis mistress-i'll take my oath!'' he (Coggan) said, amazed. Bathsheba it certainly was, and she (mistress) had by this time done the trick she (mistress) could do so well in crises not of love, namely, mask a surprise by coolness of manner. ``Well, Gabriel.
'' she (mistress) inquired quietly,'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
where are you going?'' ``We thought -- --'' began Gabriel. ``Bath.'' she (mistress) said, taking for her (mistress) own use the assurance that Gabriel lacked. ``An important matter made it necessary for me to give up my visit to liddy, and go off at once. What, then, were you following me?'' ``We thought the horse was stole.'' ``Well-what a thing! How very foolish of you not to know that I had taken the trap and horse. I could neither wake Maryann nor get into the house, though I hammered for ten minutes against her (Maryann) window-sill. Fortunately, I could get the key of the coach-house, so I troubled no one further. Didn't you think it might be me?'' ``Why should we, miss?'' ``Perhaps not Why, those are never Farmer Bold- wood's horses! Goodness mercy! what have you been doing bringing trouble upon me in this way? What! mustn't a lady move an inch from her (lady) door without being dogged like a thief?'' ``But how was we to know, if you left no account of your doings?'' expostulated Coggan, ``and ladies don't drive at these hours, miss, as a jineral rule of society.'' ``I did leave an account -- and you would have seen it in the morning. I wrote in chalk on the coach-house doors that I had come back for the horse and gig, and driven off; that I could arouse nobody, and should return soon.'' ``But you'll consider, ma'am, that we couldn't see that till it got daylight.'' ``True.
'' she (mistress) said, and though vexed at first she (mistress) had too much sense to blame them long or seriously for a devotion to her (mistress) that was as valuable as it was rare. She (mistress) added with a very pretty grace,'' (I)
Well, I really thank you heartily for taking all this trouble; but I wish you had borrowed anybody's horses but Mr. Boldwood's.'' ``Dainty is lame, miss.'' said Coggan. ``Can ye go on?'' ``lt was only a stone in her (we) shoe. I got down and pulled it out a hundred yards back. I can manage very well, thank you. I shall be in Bath by daylight. Will you now return, please?'' She (mistress) turned her (mistress) head -- the gateman's candle shimmering upon her (mistress) quick, clear eyes as she (mistress) did so -- passed through the gate, and was soon wrapped in the embowering shades of mysterious summer boughs. Coggan and Gabriel put about their horses, and, fanned by the velvety air of this July night, retraced the road by which they had come. ``A strange vagary, this of hers, isn't it, Oak?'' said Coggan, curiously. ``Yes.'' said Gabriel, shortly. ``She (we) won't be in Bath by no daylight!'' ``Coggan, suppose we keep this night's work as quiet as we can?'' ``I am of one and the same mind.''
``Very well. We shall be home by three o'clock or so, and can creep into the parish like lambs.'' (unknown)
Bathsheba's perturbed meditations by the roadside had ultimately evolved a conclusion that there were only two remedies for the present desperate state of affairs. The first was merely to keep Troy away from Weather- bury till Boldwood's indignation had cooled; the second to listen to Oak's entreaties, and Boldwood's denuncia- tions, and give up Troy altogether. Alas! Could she (Troy) give up this new love -- induce him (Boldwood) to renounce her (Troy) by saying she (Troy) did not like him (Boldwood) -- could no more speak to him (Boldwood), and beg him (Boldwood), for her (Troy) good, to end his (Boldwood) furlough in Bath, and see her (Troy) and Weather- bury no more? It was a picture full of misery, but for a while she (Troy) contemplated it firmly, allowing herself, nevertheless, as girls will, to dwell upon the happy life she (Troy) would have enjoyed had Troy been Boldwood, and the path of love the path of duty -- inflicting upon herself gratuit- ous tortures by imagining him (Boldwood) the lover of another woman after forgetting her (woman); for she (woman) had penetrated Troy's nature so far as to estimate his (Boldwood) tendencies pretty accurately, hut unfortunately loved him (Boldwood) no less in thinking that he (Boldwood) might soon cease to love her (Troy) -- indeed, considerably more. She (Troy) jumped to her (Troy) feet. She (Troy) would see him (Boldwood) at once. Yes, she (Troy) would implore him (Boldwood) by word of mouth to assist her (Troy) in this dilemma. A letter to keep him (Boldwood) away could not reach him (Boldwood) in time, even if he (Boldwood) should be disposed to listen to it. Was Bathsheba altogether blind to the obvious fact that the support of a lover's arms is not of a kind best calculated to assist a resolve to renounce him (lover)? Or was she (Troy) sophistically sensible, with a thrill of pleasure, that by adopting this course for getting rid of him (lover) she (Troy) was ensuring a meeting with him (lover), at any rate, once more? It was now dark, and the hour must have been nearly ten. The only way to accomplish her (Troy) purpose was to give up her (Troy) idea of visiting Liddy at Yalbury, return to Weatherbury Farm, put the horse into the gig, and drive at once to Bath. The scheme seemed at first impossible: the journey was a fearfully heavy one, even for a strong horse, at her (Troy) own estimate; and she (Troy) much underrated the distance. It was most venturesome for a woman, at night, and alone. But could she (woman) go on to Liddy's and leave things to take their course? No, no; anything but that. Bath- sheba was full of a stimulating turbulence, beside which caution vainly prayed for a hearing. she (woman) turned back towards the village. Her (woman) walk was slow, for she (woman) wished not to enter Weatherbury till the cottagers were in bed, and, par- ticularly, till Boldwood was secure. Her (woman) plan was now to drive to Bath during the night, see Sergeant Troy in the morning before he (Sergeant) set out to come to her (woman), bid him (Sergeant) farewell, and dismiss him (Sergeant): then to rest the horse thoroughly -LRB-herself to weep the while, she (woman) thought-RRB-, starting early the next morning on her (woman) return journey. By this arrangement she (woman) could trot Dainty gently all the day, reach Liddy at Yalbury in the evening, and come home to Weatherbury with her (woman) whenever they chose -- so nobody would know she (woman) had been to Bath at all. Such was Bathsheba's scheme. But in her (woman) topo- graphical ignorance as a late comer to the place, she (woman) misreckoned the distance of her (woman) journey as not much more than half what it really was. Her (woman) idea, however, she (woman) proceeded to carry out, with what initial success we have already seen.

CHAPTER XXXIII

IN THE SUN -- A HARBINGER

A WEEK passed, and there were no tidings of Bath- sheba; nor was there any explanation of her (woman) Gilpin's rig. Then a note came for Maryann, stating that the business which had called her (Maryann) mistress to Bath still detained her (Maryann) there; but that she (Maryann) hoped to return in the course of another week. Another week passed. The oat-harvest began, and all the men were a-field under a monochromatic Lammas sky, amid the trembling air and short shadows of noon. Indoors nothing was to be heard save the droning of blue-bottle flies; out-of-doors the whetting of scythes and the hiss of tressy oat-ears rubbing together as their perpendicular stalks of amber-yellow fell heavily to each swath. Every drop of moisture not in the men's bottles and flagons in the form of cider was raining as perspira- tion from their foreheads and cheeks. Drought was everywhere else. They were about to withdraw for a while into the charitable shade of a tree in the fence, when Coggan saw a figure in a blue coat and brass buttons running to them across the field.

``I wonder who that is?'' (he)
he (Coggan) said.
``I hope nothing is wrong about mistress.'' (Maryann/Maryann Money)
said Maryann, who with some other women was tying the bundles -LRB-oats being always sheafed on this farm-RRB-,
``but an unlucky token came to me indoors this morning. l went to unlock the door and dropped the key, and it fell upon the stone floor and broke into two pieces. Breaking a key is a dreadful bodement. I wish mis`ess was home.'' (some women)
''`Tis Cain Ball.'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
said Gabriel, pausing from whetting his (Gabriel) reaphook. Oak was not bound by his (Gabriel) agreement to assist in the corn-field; but the harvest month is an anxious time for a farmer, and the corn was Bathsheba's, so he (farmer) lent a hand.
``He (it)'s dressed up in his (it) best clothes.'' (Matthew Moon/Matthew/Moon)
said Matthew Moon.
``He (it) hev been away from home for a few days, since he (it)'s had that felon upon his (it) finger; for 'a said, since I can't work I'll have a hollerday.'' (unknown)
``A good time for one -- a excellent time.'' (Joseph/Joseph Poorgrass/Poorgrass)
said Joseph Poorgrass, straightening his (Moon) back; for he (Moon), like some of the others, had a way of resting a while from his (Moon) labour on such hot days for reasons preternaturally small; of which Cain Pall's advent on a week-day in his (Cain) Sunday- clothes was one of the first magnitude.
``Twas a bad leg allowed me to read the Pilgrim's Progress, and Mark Clark learnt AliFours in a whitlow.'' (unknown)
``Ay, and my father put his (father) arm out of joint to have time to go courting.'' (Coggan/Jan Coggan/Jan)
said Jan Coggan, in an eclipsing tone, wiping his (Coggan) face with his (Coggan) shirt-sleeve and thrusting back his (Coggan) hat upon the nape of his (Coggan) neck. By this time Cainy was nearing the group of harvesters, and was perceived to be carrying a large slice of bread and ham in one hand, from which he (ham) took mouthfuls as he (ham) ran, the other being wrapped in a bandage. When he (ham) came close, his (ham) mouth assumed the bell shape, and he (ham) began to cough violently.
``Now, Cainy!'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
said Gabriel, sternly.
``How many more times must I tell you to keep from running so fast when you be eating? You'll choke yourself some day, that's what you'll do, Cain Ball.'' (unknown)
``Hok-hok-hok!'' (Cain/Cain Ball)
replied Cain.
``A crumb of my victuals went the wrong way -- hok-hok!, That's what `tis, Mister Oak! And I've been visiting to Bath because I had a felon on my thumb; yes, and l've seen -- ahok-hok!'' (Cain/Cain Ball)
Directly Cain mentioned Bath, they all threw down their hooks and forks and drew round him (Cain). Un- fortunately the erratic crumb did not improve his (Cain) narrative powers, and a supplementary hindrance was that of a sneeze, jerking from his (Cain) pocket his (Cain) rather large watch, which dangled in front of the young man pendulum-wise.
``Yes.'' (he)
he (Cain) continued, directing his (Cain) thoughts to Bath and letting his (Cain) eyes follow,
``l've seed the world at last -- yes -- and I've seed our mis`ess -- ahok-hok-hok!'' (he)
``Bother the boy!'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
said Gabriel.
'' Something is always going the wrong way down your throat, so that you can't tell what's necessary to be told.'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
``Ahok! there! Please, Mister Oak, a gnat have just fleed into my stomach and brought the cough on again!'' (unknown)
``Yes, that's just it. Your mouth is always open, you young rascal!'' (unknown)
''`Tis terrible bad to have a gnat fly down yer throat, pore boy!'' (Matthew Moon/Matthew/Moon)
said Matthew Moon.
``Well, at Bath you saw -- --'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
prompted Gabriel.
``I saw our mistress.'' (the shepherd)
continued the junior shepherd,
``and a sojer, walking along. And bymeby they got closer and closer, and then they went arm-in-crook, like courting complete -- hok-hok! like courting complete -- hok! -- courting complete -- -- '' (the shepherd)
Losing the thread of his (Gabriel) narrative at this point simultaneously with his (Gabriel) loss of breath, their informant looked up and down the field apparently for some clue to it.
``Well, I see our mis`ess and a soldier -- a-ha-a-wk!'' (unknown)
``Damn the boy!'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
said Gabriel.
''`Tis only my manner, Mister Oak, if ye'll excuse it,'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
said Cain Ball, looking reproachfully at Oak, with eyes drenched in their own dew. !Here's some cider for him (Oak) -- that'll cure his (Oak) throat,'' said Jan Coggan, lifting a flagon of cider, pulling out the cork, and applying the hole to Cainy's mouth; Joseph Poorgrass in the meantime beginning to think apprehensively of the serious consequences that would follow Cainy Ball's strangulation in his (Poorgrass) cough, and the history of his (Poorgrass) Bath adventures dying with him (Poorgrass). ``For my poor self, I always say
``please God'' (I)
afore I do anything.'' said Joseph, in an unboastful voice; ``and so should you, Cain Ball.
''`Tis a great safeguard, and might perhaps save you from being choked to death some day.'' (Cain/Cain Ball)
Mr. Coggan poured the liquor with unstinted liber- ality at the suffering Cain's circular mouth; half of it running down the side of the flagon, and half of what reached his (Cain) mouth running down outside his (Cain) throat, and half of what ran in going the wrong way, and being coughed and sneezed around the persons of the gathered reapers in the form of a cider fog, which for a moment hung in the sunny air like a small exhalation.
``There's a great clumsy sneeze! Why can't ye have better manners, you young dog!'' (Coggan/Jan Coggan/Jan)
said Coggan, with- drawing the flagon.
``The cider went up my nose!'' (Cainy/Cainy Ball)
cried Cainy, as soon as he (Coggan) could speak;
``and now `tis gone down my neck, and into my poor dumb felon, and over my shiny buttons and all my best cloze!'' (he)
``The poor lad's cough is terrible unfortunate.'' (Matthew Moon/Matthew/Moon)
said Matthew Moon.
``And a great history on hand, too. Bump his (lad) back, shepherd.'' (unknown)
''`Tis my nater.'' (Cain/Cain Ball)
mourned Cain.
``Mother says I always was so excitable when my feelings were worked up to a point!'' (unknown)
``True, true.'' (Joseph/Joseph Poorgrass/Poorgrass)
said Joseph Poorgrass. ``The Balls were always a very excitable family. I knowed the boy's grandfather -- a truly nervous and modest man, even to genteel refinery. ``Twas blush, blush with him (man), almost as much as `tis with me -- not but that `tis a fault in me!'' ``Not at all, Master Poorgrass.
'' said Coggan. '' (Master)
`Tis a very noble quality in ye.'' ``Heh-heh! well, I wish to noise nothing abroad -- nothing at all.'' murmured Poorgrass, diffidently. ``But we be born to things -- that's true. Yet I would rather my trifle were hid; though, perhaps, a high nater is a little high, and at my birth all things were possible to my Maker, and he (Master) may have begrudged no gifts... But under your bushel, Joseph! under your bushel with
``ee! A strange desire, neighbours, this desire to hide, and no praise due. Yet there is a Sermon on the Mount with a calendar of the blessed at the head, and certain meek men may be named therein.'' (unknown)
``Cainy's grandfather was a very clever man.'' (Matthew Moon/Matthew/Moon)
said Matthew Moon.
``Invented a' apple-tree out of his (grandfather) own head, which is called by his (grandfather) name to this day -- the Early Ball. You know 'em, Jan? A Quarrenden grafted on a Tom Putt, and a Rathe-ripe upon top o' that again. '' (a woman)
`Tis trew 'a used to bide about in a public-house wi' a woman in a way he (Moon) had no business to by rights, but there -- 'a were a clever man in the sense of the term.'' ``Now then.
'' said Gabriel, impatiently, '' (Cain/Cain Ball)
what did you see, Cain?'' ``I seed our mis`ess go into a sort of a park place, where there's seats, and shrubs and flowers, arm-in-crook with a sojer.'' continued Cainy, firmly, and with a dim sense that his (Cain) words were very effective as regarded Gabriel's emotions. ``And I think the sojer was Sergeant Troy. And they sat there together for more than half-an-hour, talking moving things, and she (Jan) once was crying a`most to death. And when they came out her (Jan) eyes were shining and she (Jan) was as white as a lily; and they looked into one another's faces, as far-gone friendly as a man and woman can be.'' Gabriel's features seemed to get thinner. ``Well, what did you see besides?'' ``Oh, all sorts.'' ``White as a lily? You are sure 'twas she (woman)?
``Yes.'' (unknown)
``Well, what besides?'' (unknown)
``Great glass windows to the shops, and great clouds in the sky, full of rain, and old wooden trees in the country round.'' (unknown)
``You stun-poll! What will ye say next?'' (Coggan/Jan Coggan/Jan)
said Coggan.
``Let en alone.'' (Joseph/Joseph Poorgrass/Poorgrass)
interposed Joseph Poorgrass. ``The boy's meaning is that the sky and the earth in the kingdom of Bath is not altogether different from ours here. ``Tis for our good to gain knowledge of strange cities, and as such the boy's words should be suffered, so to speak it.'' ``And the people of Bath.'' continued Cain, ``never need to light their fires except as a luxury, for the water springs up out of the earth ready boiled for use.
'' '' (unknown)
`Tis true as the light.
'' testified Matthew Moon.'' (I)
I've heard other navigators say the same thing.'' ``They drink nothing else there.
'' said Cain,'' (unknown)
and seem to enjoy it, to see how they swaller it down.'' ``Well, it seems a barbarian practice enough to us, but I daresay the natives think nothing o' it.'' said Matthew. ``And don't victuals spring up as well as drink?'' asked Coggan, twirling his (Matthew) eye. ``No-i own to a blot there in Bath -- a true blot. God didn't provide 'em with victuals as well as -LRB-- and 'twas a drawback I couldn't get over at all.'' ``Well, `tis a curious place, to say the least.'' observed Moon; ``and it must be a curious people that live therein. '' ``Miss Everdene and the soldier were walking about together, you say?'' said Gabriel, returning to the group. ``Ay, and she ('em) wore a beautiful gold-colour silk gown, trimmed with black lace, that would have stood alone `ithout legs inside if required.
``Twas a very winsome sight; and her ('em) hair was brushed splendid. And when the sun shone upon the bright gown and his (soldier) red coat -- my! how handsome they looked. You could see 'em all the length of the street.'' (unknown)
``And what then?'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
murmured Gabriel.
``And then I went into Griffin's to hae my boots hobbed, and then I went to Riggs's batty-cake shop, and asked 'em for a penneth of the cheapest and nicest stales, that were all but blue-mouldy, but not quite. And whilst I was chawing 'em down I walked on and seed a clock with a face as big as a baking trendle -- -- '' (unknown)
``But that's nothing to do with mistress!'' (unknown)
``I'm coming to that, if you'll leave me alone, Mister Oak!'' (unknown)
remonstrated Cainy.
``If you excites me, perhaps you'll bring on my cough, and then I shan't be able to tell ye nothing.'' (unknown)
``Yes-let him (my) tell it his (my) own way.'' (Coggan/Jan Coggan/Jan)
said Coggan. Gabriel settled into a despairing attitude of patience, and Cainy went on: --
``And there were great large houses, and more people all the week long than at Weatherbury club- walking on White Tuesdays. And I went to grand churches and chapels. And how the parson would pray! Yes; he (parson) would kneel down and put up his (parson) hands together, and make the holy gold rings on his (parson) fingers gleam and twinkle in yer eyes, that he (parson)'d earned by praying so excellent well! -- Ah yes, I wish I lived there.'' (Cainy/Cainy Ball)
``Our poor Parson Thirdly can't get no money to buy such rings.'' (Matthew Moon/Matthew/Moon)
said Matthew Moon, thoughtfully.
``And as good a man as ever walked. I don't believe poor Thirdly have a single one, even of humblest tin or copper. Such a great ornament as they'd be to him (man) on a dull afternoon, when he (man)'s up in the pulpit lighted by the wax candles! But `tis impossible, poor man. Ah, to think how unequal things be.'' (unknown)
``Perhaps he (man)'s made of different stuff than to wear ``em.
'' said Gabriel, grimly.'' (unknown)
Well, that's enough of this. Go on, Cainy -- quick.'' ``Oh -- and the new style of parsons wear moustaches and long beards.'' continued the illustrious traveller, ``and look like Moses and Aaron complete, and make we fokes in the congregation feel all over like the children of Israel.'' ``A very right feeling -- very.'' said Joseph Poorgrass. ``And there's two religions going on in the nation now -- High Church and High Chapel. And, thinks I, I'll play fair; so I went to High Church in the morning, and High Chapel in the afternoon.'' ``A right and proper boy.'' said Joseph Poorgrass. ``Well, at High Church they pray singing, and worship all the colours of the rainbow; and at High Chapel they pray preaching, and worship drab and whitewash only. And then-i didn't see no more of Miss Everdene at all.'' ``Why didn't you say so afore, then?'' exclaimed Oak, with much disappointment. ``Ah.
'' said Matthew Moon, `she (Gabriel)'ll wish her (Gabriel) cake dough if so be she (Gabriel)'s over intimate with that man.'' (unknown)
``She (they)'s not over intimate with him (boy).'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
said Gabriel, indignantly.
``She (they) would know better.'' (Coggan/Jan Coggan/Jan)
said Coggan.
``Our mis`ess has too much sense under they knots of black hair to do such a mad thing.'' (unknown)
``You see, he (boy)'s not a coarse, ignorant man, for he (boy) was well brought up.'' (Matthew Moon/Matthew/Moon)
said Matthew, dubiously.
'''Twas only wildness that made him (Coggan) a soldier, and maids rather like your man of sin.'' (Matthew Moon/Matthew/Moon)
``Now, Cain Ball.'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
said Gabriel restlessly,
``can you swear in the most awful form that the woman you saw was Miss Everdene?'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
``Cain Ball, you be no longer a babe and suckling,'' (Joseph/Joseph Poorgrass/Poorgrass)
said Joseph in the sepulchral tone the circumstances demanded, ``and you know what taking an oath is. ``Tis a horrible testament mind ye, which you say and seal with your blood-stone, and the prophet Matthew tells us that on whomsoever it shall fall it will grind him (Matthew) to powder. Now, before all the work-folk here assembled, can you swear to your words as the shep- herd asks ye?'' ``Please no, Mister Oak!'' said Cainy, looking from one to the other with great uneasiness at the spiritual magnitude of the position. ``I don't mind saying `tis true, but I don't like to say `tis damn true, if that's what you mane.'' ``Cain, Cain, how can you!'' asked Joseph sternly. ``You be asked to swear in a holy manner, and you swear like wicked Shimei, the son of Gera, who cursed as he (son) came. Young man, fie!'' ``No, I don't!
``Tis you want to squander a pore boy's soul, Joseph Poorgrass -- that's what `tis!'' (Cain/Cain Ball)
said Cain, beginning to cry.
``All I mane is that in common truth 'twas Miss Everdene and Sergeant Troy, but in the horrible so-help-me truth that ye want to make of it perhaps 'twas somebody else!'' (unknown)
``There's no getting at the rights of it.'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
said Gabriel, turning to his (Gabriel) work.
``Cain Ball, you'll come to a bit of bread!'' (Joseph/Joseph Poorgrass/Poorgrass)
groaned Joseph Poorgrass. Then the reapers' hooks were flourished again, and the old sounds went on. Gabriel, without making any pretence of being lively, did nothing to show that he (Gabriel) was particularly dull. However, Coggan knew pretty nearly how the land lay, and when they were in a nook together he (Coggan) said --
``Don't take on about her (it), Gabriel. What difference does it make whose sweetheart she (sweetheart) is, since she (sweetheart) can't be yours?'' (he)
``That's the very thing I say to myself.'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
said Gabriel.

CHAPTER XXXIV

HOME AGAIN -- A TRICKSTER

THAT same evening at dusk Gabriel was leaning over Coggan's garden-gate, taking an up-and-down survey before retiring to rest. A vehicle of some kind was softly creeping along the grassy margin of the lane. From it spread the tones of two women talking. The tones were natural and not at all suppressed. Oak instantly knew the voices to he (Gabriel) those of Bathsheba and Liddy. The carriage came opposite and passed by. It was Miss Everdene's gig, and Liddy and her (Bathsheba) mistress were the only occupants of the seat. Liddy was asking questions about the city of Bath, and her (Bathsheba) companion was answering them listlessly and unconcernedly. Both Bathsheba and the horse seemed weary. The exquisite relief of finding that she (Bathsheba) was here again, safe and sound, overpowered all reflection, and Oak could only luxuriate in the sense of it. All grave reports were forgotten. He (Oak) lingered and lingered on, till there was no difference between the eastern and western expanses of sky, and the timid hares began to limp courageously round the dim hillocks. Gabriel might have been there an additional half-hour when a dark form walked slowly by.

``Good-night, Gabriel.'' (the passer)
the passer said. It was Boldwood.
``Good-night, sir.'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
said Gabriel. Boldwood likewise vanished up the road, and Oak shortly afterwards turned indoors to bed. Farmer Boldwood went on towards Miss Everdene's house. He (Boldwood) reached the front, and approaching the entrance, saw a light in the parlour. The blind was not drawn down, and inside the room was Bathsheba, looking over some papers or letters. Her (passer) back was towards Boldwood. He (Boldwood) went to the door, knocked, and waited with tense muscles and an aching brow. Boldwood had not been outside his (Boldwood) garden since his (Boldwood) meeting with Bathsheba in the road to Yalbury. Silent and alone, he (Boldwood) had remained in moody medita- tion on woman's ways, deeming as essentials of the whole sex the accidents of the single one of their number he (Boldwood) had ever closely beheld. By degrees a more charitable temper had pervaded him (Boldwood), and this was the reason of his (Boldwood) sally to-night. He (Boldwood) had come to apologize and beg forgiveness of Bathsheba with some- thing like a sense of shame at his (Boldwood) violence, having but just now learnt that she (woman) had returned -- only from a visit to Liddy, as he (Liddy) supposed, the Bath escapade being quite unknown to him (Liddy). He (Liddy) inquired for Miss Everdene. Liddy's manner was odd, but he (Liddy) did not notice it. She (woman) went in, leaving him (Liddy) standing there, and in her (woman) absence the blind of the room containing Bathsheba was pulled down. Bold- wood augured ill from that sign. Liddy came out.
``My mistress cannot see you, sir.'' (she)
she (woman) said. The farmer instantly went out by the gate. He (Liddy) as unforgiven -- that was the issue of it all. He (Liddy) had seen her (woman) who was to him (Liddy) simultaneously a delight and a torture, sitting in the room he (Liddy) had shared with her (woman) as a peculiarly privileged guest only a little earlier in he (Liddy) summer, and she (woman) had denied him (Liddy) an entrance there now. Boldwood did not hurry homeward. It was ten o'clock at least, when, walking deliberately through the lower part of Weatherbury, he (Boldwood) heard the carrier's spring van entering the village. The van ran to and from a town in a northern direction, and it was owned and driven by a Weatherbury man, at the door of whose house it now pulled up. The lamp fixed to the head of the hood illuminated a scarlet and gilded form, who was the first to alight.
``Ah!'' (Boldwood/Mr. Boldwood/BOLDWOOD)
said Boldwood to himself,
``come to see her (mistress) again.'' (Boldwood/Mr. Boldwood/BOLDWOOD)
Troy entered the carrier's house, which had been the place of his (Boldwood) lodging on his (Boldwood) last visit to his (Boldwood) native place. Boldwood was moved by a sudden determina- tion. He (Boldwood) hastened home. In ten minutes he (Boldwood) was back again, and made as if he (Boldwood) were going to call upon Troy at the carrier's. But as he (Boldwood) approached, some one opened the door and came out. He (Boldwood) heard this person say
'' Good-night'' (this person)
to the inmates, and the voice was Troy's. ``This was strange, coming so immediately after his (Gabriel) arrival. Boldwood, however, hastened up to him (Boldwood). Troy had what appeared to be a carpet-bag in his (Boldwood) hand -- the same that he (Boldwood) had brought with him (Boldwood). It seemed as if he (Boldwood) were going to leave again this very night. Troy turned up the hill and quickened his (Boldwood) pace. Boldwood stepped forward. ``Sergeant Troy?'' ``Yes-i'm Sergeant Troy.'' ``Just arrived from up the country, I think?
``Just arrived from Bath.'' (unknown)
``I am William Boldwood.'' (unknown)
``Indeed.'' (Boldwood/Mr. Boldwood/BOLDWOOD)
The tone in which this word was uttered was all that had been wanted to bring Boldwood to the point.
``I wish to speak a word with you.'' (he)
he (Boldwood) said.
``What about?'' (unknown)
``About her (Boldwood) who lives just ahead there -- and about a woman you have wronged.'' (unknown)
``I wonder at your impertinence.'' (unknown)
said Troy, moving on.
``Now look here.'' (Boldwood/Mr. Boldwood/BOLDWOOD)
said Boldwood, standing in front of him (Boldwood),
'' wonder or not, you are going to hold a conver- sation with me.'' (him)
Troy heard the dull determination in Boldwood's voice, looked at his (Boldwood) stalwart frame, then at the thick cudgel he (Boldwood) carried in his (Boldwood) hand. He (Boldwood) remembered it was past ten o'clock. It seemed worth while to be civil to Boldwood.
``Very well, I'll listen with pleasure.'' (unknown)
said Troy, placing his (Boldwood) bag on the ground,
``only speak low, for somebody or other may overhear us in the farmhouse there.'' (unknown)
``Well then -- I know a good deal concerning your Fanny Robin's attachment to you. I may say, too, that I believe I am the only person in the village, excepting Gabriel Oak, who does know it. You ought to marry her (Robin).'' (unknown)
``I suppose I ought. Indeed, l wish to, but I cannot.'' (unknown)
``Why?'' (Troy/Mrs. Troy)
Troy was about to utter something hastily; he (Boldwood) then checked himself and said,
``I am too poor.'' (he)
His (Boldwood) voice was changed. Previously it had had a devil-may-care tone. It was the voice of a trickster now. Boldwood's present mood was not critical enough to notice tones. He (Boldwood) continued,
``I may as well speak plainly; and understand, I don't wish to enter into the questions of right or wrong, woman's honour and shame, or to express any opinion on your conduct. I intend a business transaction with you.'' (He)
``I see.'' (unknown)
said Troy.
``Suppose we sit down here.'' (unknown)
An old tree trunk lay under the hedge immediately opposite, and they sat down. The tone in which this word was uttered was all Troy heard the dull determination in Boldwood's voice, looked at his (Boldwood) stalwart frame, then at the thick plainly; and understand, I don't wish to enter into the
``I was engaged to be married to Miss Everdene,'' (I)
said Boldwood,
``but you came and -- -- '' (Boldwood/Mr. Boldwood/BOLDWOOD)
``Not engaged.'' (Boldwood/Mr. Boldwood/BOLDWOOD)
said Troy.
``As good as engaged.'' (unknown)
``If I had not turned up she (woman) might have become en- gaged to you.'' (unknown)
``Hang might!``Would, then.'' ``If you had not come I should certainly -- yes, certainly -- have been accepted by this time. If you had not seen her (woman) you might have been married to Fanny. Well, there's too much difference between Miss Ever- dene's station and your own for this flirtation with her (woman) ever to benefit you by ending in marriage. So all I ask is, don't molest her (woman) any more. Marry Fanny. make it worth your while.'' ``How will you?'' ``I'll pay you well now, I'll settle a sum of money upon her (woman), and I'll see that you don't suffer from poverty in the future. I'll put it clearly. Bathsheba is only playing with you: you are too poor for her (woman) as I said; so give up wasting your time about a great match you'll never make for a moderate and rightful match you may make to-morrow; take up your carpet-bag, turn about, leave Weatherbury now, this night, and you shall take fifty pounds with you. Fanny shall have fifty to enable her (Fanny) to prepare for the wedding, when you have told me where she (Fanny) is living, and she (Fanny) shall have five hundred paid down on her (Fanny) wedding-day.'' In making this statement Boldwood's voice revealed only too clearly a consciousness of the weakness of his (Boldwood) position, his (Boldwood) aims, and his (Boldwood) method. His (Boldwood) manner had lapsed quite from that of the firm and dignified Bold- wood of former times; and such a scheme as he (Boldwood) had now engaged in he (Boldwood) would have condemned as childishly imbecile only a few months ago. We discern a grand force in the lover which he (lover) lacks whilst a free man; but there is a breadth of vision in the free man which in the lover we vainly seek. Where there is much bias there must be some narrowness, and love, though added emotion, is subtracted capacity. Boldwood exemplified this to an abnormal degree: he (Boldwood) knew nothing of Fanny Robin's circumstances or whereabouts, he (Boldwood) knew nothing of Troy's possibilities, yet that was what he (Boldwood) said. ``I like Fanny best.'' said Troy; ``and if, as you say, Miss Everdene is out of my reach, why I have all to gain by accepting your money, and marrying Fan. But she (Fanny)'s only a servant.'' ``Never mind -- do you agree to my arrangement?'' ``I do.'' ``Ah!'' said Boldwood, in a more elastic voice. ``O, Troy, if you like her (Fanny) best, why then did you step in here and injure my happiness?'' ``I love Fanny best now.'' said Troy. ``But Bathsh -- -- Miss Everdene inflamed me, and displaced Fanny for a time. It is over now.'' ``Why should it be over so soon? And why then did you come here again?'' ``There are weighty reasons. Fifty pounds at once, you said!'' ``I did.
'' said Boldwood, '' (I)
and here they are -- fifty sovereigns.'' He (Boldwood) handed Troy a small packet. ``You have everything ready -- it seems that you calculated on my accepting them.'' said the sergeant, taking the packet. ``I thought you might accept them.'' said Boldwood. ``You've only my word that the programme shall be adhered to, whilst I at any rate have fifty pounds.'' ``l had thought of that, and l have considered that if I can't appeal to your honour I can trust to your -- well, shrewdness we'll call it -- not to lose five hundred pounds in prospect, and also make a bitter enemy of a man who is willing to be an extremely useful friend.'' ``Stop, listen!'' said Troy in a whisper. A light pit-pat was audible upon the road just above them. ``By George -- `tis she (I).'' he (Boldwood) continued. ``I must go on and meet her (I).'' ``She (I) -- who?'' ``Bathsheba.'' ``Bathsheba -- out alone at this time o' night!
'' said Boldwood in amazement, and starting up.'' (Bathsheba)
Why must you meet her (Robin)?'' ``She (I) was expecting me to-night -- and I must now speak to her (I), and wish her (I) good-bye, according to your wish. '' ``I don't see the necessity of speaking.'' ``It can do no harm -- and she (I)'ll be wandering about looking for me if I don't. You shall hear all I say to her (I). It will help you in your love-making when I am gone.'' ``Your tone is mocking.'' ``O no. And remember this, if she (I) does not know what has become of me, she (I) will think more about me than if I tell her (I) flatly I have come to give her (I) up.'' ``Will you confine your words to that one point? -- Shall I hear every word you say?'' ``Every word. Now sit still there, and hold my
'' carpet bag for me, and mark what you hear.'' (the walker)
The light footstep came closer, halting occasionally, as if the walker listened for a sound. Troy whistled a double note in a soft, fluty tone.
``Come to that, is it!'' (Boldwood/Mr. Boldwood/BOLDWOOD)
murmured Boldwood, uneasily.
``You promised silence.'' (unknown)
said Troy.
``I promise again.'' (unknown)
Troy stepped forward.
``Frank, dearest, is that you?'' (Bathsheba/Bathsheba Everdene/BATHSHEBA)
The tones were Bathsheba's.
``O God!'' (Boldwood/Mr. Boldwood/BOLDWOOD)
said Boldwood.
``Yes.'' (her)
said Troy to her (Robin).
``How late you are.'' (she)
she (Robin) continued, tenderly.
``Did you come by the carrier? I listened and heard his (God) wheels entering the village, but it was some time ago, and I had almost given you up, Frank.'' (unknown)
``I was sure to come.'' (Frank)
said Frank.
``You knew I should, did you not?'' (unknown)
``Well, I thought you would.'' (she)
she (Robin) said, playfully;
