The next day, which was Sunday, passed nearly in the same manner as regarded their taciturnity, Bathsheba going to church both morning and afternoon. This was the day before the Budmouth races. In the evening Troy said, suddenly --

``Bathsheba, could you let me have twenty pounds?'' (Troy/Mrs. Troy)
Her (Troy) countenance instantly sank.'' Twenty pounds? she (Troy) said. ``The fact is, I want it badly.'' The anxiety upon Troy's face was unusual and very marked. lt was a culmination of the mood he (husband) had been in all the day. ``Ah! for those races to-morrow.'' Troy for the moment made no reply. Her (Troy) mistake had its advantages to a man who shrank from having his (man) mind inspected as he (man) did now. ``Well, suppose I do want it for races?'' he (man) said, at last. ``O, Frank!'' Bathsheba replied, and there was such a volume of entreaty in the words. ``Only such a few weeks ago you said that I was far sweeter than all your other pleasures put together, and that you would give them all up for me; and now, won't you give up this one, which is more a worry than a pleasure? Do, Frank. Come, let me fascinate you by all I can do -- by pretty words and pretty looks, and everything I can think of -- to stay at home. Say yes to your wife -- say yes!'' The tenderest and softest phases of Bathsheba's nature were prominent now -- advanced impulsively for his (man) acceptance, without any of the disguises and defences which the wariness of her (Troy) character when she (Troy) was cool too frequently threw over them. Few men could have resisted the arch yet dignified entreaty of the beautiful face, thrown a little back and sideways in the well known attitude that expresses more than the words it accompanies, and which seems to have been designed for these special occasions. Had the woman not been his (man) wife, Troy would have succumbed instantly; as it was, he (man) thought he (man) would not deceive her (Troy) longer. ``The money is not wanted for racing debts at all,'' he (man) said. ``What is it for?'' she (Troy) asked. ``You worry me a great deal by these mysterious responsibilities, Frank.'' Troy hesitated. He (man) did not now love her (Troy) enough to allow himself to be carried too far by her (Troy) ways. Yet it was necessary to be civil. ``You wrong me by such a suspicious manner, he (Frank) said.
``Such strait-waistcoating as you treat me to is not becoming in you at so early a date.'' (unknown)
``I think that I have a right to grumble a little if I pay.'' (she)
she (Troy) said, with features between a smile and a pout. Exactly; and, the former being done, suppose we proceed to the latter. Bathsheba, fun is all very well, but don't go too far, or you may have cause to regret something.'' She (Troy) reddened. ``I do that already.'' she (Troy) said, quickly ``What do you regret?'' SUSPICION ``That my romance has come to an end.'' ``All romances end at marriage.'' ``I wish you wouldn't talk like that. You grieve me to my soul by being smart at my expense.'' ``You are dull enough at mine. I believe you hate me.'' ``Not you -- only your faults. I do hate them.
'' '' (I)
`Twould be much more becoming if you set your- self to cure them. Come, let's strike a balance with the twenty pounds, and be friends.'' She (Troy) gave a sigh of resignation. ``I have about that sum here for household expenses. If you must have it, take it.'' ``Very good. Thank you. I expect I shall have gone away before you are in to breakfast to-morrow.'' ``And must you go? Ah! there was a time, Frank, when it would have taken a good many promises to other people to drag you away from me. You used to call me darling, then. But it doesn't matter to you how my days are passed now.'' ``I must go, in spite of sentiment.'' Troy, as he (Troy) spoke, looked at his (Troy) watch, and, apparently actuated by NON LUCENDO principles, opened the case at the back, revealing, snugly stowed within it, a small coil of hair. Bathsheba's eyes had been accidentally lifted at that moment, and she (Troy) saw the action and saw the hair. She (Troy) flushed in pain and surprise, and some words escaped her (Troy) before she (Troy) had thought whether or not it was wise to utter them. ``A woman's curl of hair!'' she (Troy) said. ``O, Frank, whose is that?
'' Troy had instantly closed his (Troy) watch. He (Troy) carelessly replied, as one who cloaked some feelings that the sight had stirred.'' (Frank)
Why, yours, of course. Whose should it be? I had quite forgotten that I had it.'' ``What a dreadful fib, Frank!'' ``I tell you I had forgotten it!'' he (Troy) said, loudly. ``I don't mean that -- it was yellow hair.'' ``Nonsense.'' ``That's insulting me. I know it was yellow. Now whose was it? I want to know.'' ``Very well I'll tell you, so make no more ado. It is the hair of a young woman I was going to marry before I knew you.'' ``You ought to tell me her (woman) name, then.'' ``I cannot do that.'' ``Is she (woman) married yet?'' ``No.'' ``Is she (woman) alive?'' ``Yes.'' ``Is she (woman) pretty?'' ``Yes.'' ``It is wonderful how she (woman) can be, poor thing, under such an awful affliction!'' ``Affliction -- what affliction?'' he (Troy) inquired, quickly. ``Having hair of that dreadful colour.'' ``Oh -- ho-i like that!'' said Troy, recovering him (Troy)- self. ``Why, her (woman) hair has been admired by everybody who has seen her (woman) since she (woman) has worn it loose, which has not been long. It is beautiful hair. People used to turn their heads to look at it, poor girl!'' ``Pooh! that's nothing -- that's nothing!'' she (Troy) ex- claimed, in incipient accents of pique. ``If I cared for your love as much as I used to I could say people had turned to look at mine.'' ``Bathsheba, don't be so fitful and jealous. You knew what married life would be like, and shouldn't have entered it if you feared these contingencies.'' Troy had by this time driven her (Troy) to bitterness: her (Troy) heart was big in her (Troy) throat, and the ducts to her (Troy) eyes were painfully full. Ashamed as she (Troy) was to show emotion, at last she (Troy) burst out: -- ``This is all I get for loving you so well! Ah! when I married you your life was dearer to me than my own. I would have died for you -- how truly I can say that I would have died for you! And now you sneer at my foolishness in marrying you. O! is it kind to me to throw my mistake in my face? Whatever opinion you may have of my wisdom, you should not tell me of it so mercilessly, now that I am in your power.'' ``I can't help how things fall out.'' said Troy; ``upon my heart, women will be the death of me!'' ``Well you shouldn't keep people's hair. You'll burn it, won't you, Frank?'' Frank went on as if he (Frank) had not heard her (Troy). ``There are considerations even before my consideration for you; reparations to be made -- ties you know nothing of If you repent of marrying, so do I.'' Trembling now, she (Troy) put her (Troy) hand upon his (Frank) arm, saying, in mingled tones of wretchedness and coaxing, ``I only repent it if you don't love me better than any woman in the world! I don't otherwise, Frank. You don't repent because you already love somebody better than you love me, do you?'' ``I don't know. Why do you say that?'' ``You won't burn that curl. You like the woman who owns that pretty hair -- yes; it is pretty -- more beautiful than my miserable black mane! Well, it is no use; I can't help being ugly. You must like her (woman) best, if you will!'' ``Until to-day, when I took it from a drawer, I have never looked upon that bit of hair for several months -- that I am ready to swear.'' ``But just now you said
``ties;'' (woman)
and then -- that woman we met?
'' '' (woman)
'Twas the meeting with her (woman) that reminded me of the hair.'' ``Is it hers, then?'' ``Yes. There, now that you have wormed it out of me, I hope you are content.'' ``And what are the ties?'' ``Oh! that meant nothing -- a mere jest.'' ``A mere jest!'' she (woman) said, in mournful astonishment. ``Can you jest when I am so wretchedly in earnest? Tell me the truth, Frank. I am not a fool, you know, although I am a woman, and have my woman's moments. Come! treat me fairly.'' she (woman) said, looking honestly and fearlessly into his (Frank) face. ``I don't want much; bare justice -- that's all! Ah! once I felt I could be content with nothing less than the highest homage from the husband I should choose. Now, anything short of cruelty will content me. Yes! the independent and spirited Bathsheba is come to this!'' ``For Heaven's sake don't be so desperate!``Troy said, snappishly, rising as he (husband) did so, and leaving the room. Directly he (husband) had gone, Bathsheba burst into great sobs -- dry-eyed sobs, which cut as they came, without any softening by tears. But she (husband) determined to repress all evidences of feeling. She (husband) was conquered; but she (husband) would never own it as long as she (husband) lived. Her (husband) pride was indeed brought low by despairing discoveries of her (husband) spoliation by marriage with a less pure nature than her (husband) own. She (husband) chafed to and fro in rebelliousness, like a caged leopard; her (husband) whole soul was in arms, and the blood fired her (husband) face. Until she (husband) had met Troy, Bath- sheba had been proud of her (husband) position as a woman; it had been a glory to her (husband) to know that her (husband) lips had been touched by no man's on earth -- that her (husband) waist had never been encircled by a lover's arm. She (husband) hated herself now. In those earlier days she (husband) had always nourished a secret contempt for girls who were the slaves of the first goodlooking young fellow who should choose to salute them. She (husband) had never taken kindly to the idea of marriage in the abstract as did the majority of women she (husband) saw about her (husband). In the turmoil of her (husband) anxiety for her (husband) lover she (husband) had agreed to marry him (lover); but the perception that had accompanied her (husband) happiest hours on this account was rather that of self-sacrifice than of promotion and honour. Although she (husband) scarcely knew the divinity's name, Diana was the goddess whom Bathsheba instinctively adored. That she (Diana) had never, by look, word, or sign, encouraged a man to approach her (Diana) -- that she (Diana) had felt herself sufficient to herself, and had in the independence of her (Diana) girlish heart fancied there was a certain degradation in renouncing the simplicity of a maiden existence to become the humbler half of an indifferent matrimonial whole -- were facts now bitterly remembered. O, if she (Diana) had never stooped to folly of this kind, respectable as it was, and could only stand again, as she (Diana) had stood on the hill at Norcombe, and dare Troy or any other man to pollute a hair of her (Diana) head by his (man) interference! The next morning she (Diana) rose earlier than usual, and had the horse saddled for her (Diana) ride round the farm in the customary way. When she (Diana) came in at half-past eight -- their usual hour for breakfasting -- she (Diana) was in- formed that her (Diana) husband had risen, taken his (husband) breakfast, and driven off to Casterbridge with the gig and Poppet. After breakfast she (Diana) was cool and collected -- quite herself in fact -- and she (Diana) rambled to the gate, intending to walk to another quarter of the farm, which she (Diana) still personally superintended as well as her (Diana) duties in the house would permit, continually, however, finding her (Diana)- self preceded in forethought by Gabriel Oak, for whom she (Diana) began to entertain the genuine friendship of a sister. Of course, she (Diana) sometimes thought of him (Oak) in the light of an old lover, and had momentary imaginings of what life with him (lover) as a husband would have been like; also of life with Boldwood under the same conditions. But Bathsheba, though she (Diana) could feel, was not much given to futile dreaming, and her (Diana) musings under this head were short and entirely confined to the times when Troy's neglect was more than ordinarily evident. She (Troy) saw coming up the road a man like Mr. Boldwood. It was Mr. Boldwood. Bathsheba blushed painfully, and watched. The farmer stopped when still a long way off, and held up his (farmer) hand to Gabriel Oak, who was in a footpath across the field. The two men then approached each other and seemed to engage in earnest conversation. Thus they continued for a long time. Joseph Poor- grass now passed near them, wheeling a barrow of apples up the hill to Bathsheba's residence. Boldwood and Gabriel called to him (Boldwood), spoke to him (Boldwood) for a few minutes, and then all three parted, Joseph immediately coming up the hill with his (Joseph) barrow. Bathsheba, who had seen this pantomime with some surprise, experienced great relief when Boldwood turned back again. ``Well, what's the message, Joseph?'' she (woman) said. He (Frank) set down his (Frank) barrow, and, putting upon himself the refined aspect that a conversation with a lady re- quired, spoke to Bathsheba over the gate. ``You'll never see Fanny Robin no more -- use nor principal -- ma'am.'' ``Why?'' ``Because she (Robin)'s dead in the Union.'' ``Fanny dead -- never!'' ``Yes, ma'am.'' ``What did she (Fanny) die from?'' ``I don't know for certain; but I should be inclined to think it was from general weakness of constitution. She (Fanny) was such a limber maid that 'a could stand no hardship, even when I knowed her (Fanny), and 'a went like a candle-snoff, so `tis said. She (Fanny) was took bad in the morning, and, being quite feeble and worn out, she (Fanny) died in the evening. She (Fanny) belongs by law to our parish; and Mr. Boldwood is going to send a waggon at three this afternoon to fetch her (Fanny) home here and bury her (Fanny).'' ``Indeed I shall not let Mr. Boldwood do any such thing-i shall do it! Fanny was my uncle's servant, and, although I only knew her (Fanny) for a couple of days, FANNY IS SENT FOR she (FANNY) belongs to me. How very, very sad this is! -- the idea of Fanny being in a workhouse.'' Bathsheba had begun to know what suffering was, and she (lady) spoke with real feeling... ``Send across to Mr. Boldwood's, and say that Mrs. Troy will take upon herself the duty of fetching an old servant of the family... We ought not to put her (Troy) in a waggon; we'll get a hearse.'' ``There will hardly be time, ma'am, will there?'' ``Perhaps not.'' she (lady) said, musingly. ``When did you say we must be at the door -- three o'clock?'' ``Three o'clock this afternoon, ma'am, so to speak it.'' ``Very well-you go with it. A pretty waggon is better than an ugly hearse, after all. Joseph, have the new spring waggon with the blue body and red wheels, and wash it very clean. And, Joseph -- -- '' ``Yes, ma'am.'' ``Carry with you some evergreens and flowers to put upon her (it) coffin -- indeed, gather a great many, and completely bury her (it) in them. Get some boughs of laurustinus, and variegated box, and yew, and boy`siove; ay, and some hunches of chrysanthemum. And let old Pleasant draw her (it), because she (it) knew him (boy) so well.
``I will, ma'am. I ought to have said that the Union, in the form of four labouring men, will meet me when I gets to our churchyard gate, and take her (it) and bury her (it) according to the rites of the Board of Guardians, as by law ordained.'' (unknown)
``Dear me -- Casterbridge Union -- and is Fanny come to this?'' (Bathsheba/Bathsheba Everdene/BATHSHEBA)
said Bathsheba, musing.
``I wish I had known of it sooner. I thought she (Fanny) was far away. How long has she (Fanny) lived there?'' (unknown)
``On'y been there a day or two.'' (unknown)
``Oh! -- then she (Fanny) has not been staying there as a regular inmate?'' (unknown)
``No. She (Fanny) first went to live in a garrison-town t`other side o' Wessex, and since then she (Fanny)'s been picking up a living at seampstering in Melchester for several months, at the house of a very respectable widow-woman who takes in work of that sort. She (Fanny) only got handy the Union-house on Sunday morning 'a b`lieve, and `tis sup- posed here and there that she (Fanny) had traipsed every step of the way from Melchester. Why she (Fanny) left her (Fanny) place, I can't say, for I don't know; and as to a lie, why, I wouldn't tell it. That's the short of the story, ma'am.'' (unknown)
``Ah-h!'' (the wife)
No gem ever flashed from a rosy ray to a white one more rapidly than changed the young wife's counten- ance whilst this word came from her (wife) in a long-drawn breath.
``Did she (Fanny) walk along our turnpike-road?'' (she)
she (wife) said, in a suddenly restless and eager voice.
``I believe she (Fanny) did... Ma'am, shall I call Liddy? You bain't well, ma'am, surely? You look like a lily -- so pale and fainty!'' (unknown)
``No; don't call her (Fanny); it is nothing. When did she (Fanny) pass Weatherbury?'' (unknown)
``Last Saturday night.'' (unknown)
``That will do, Joseph; now you may go.'' (unknown)
Certainly, ma'am.'' ``Joseph, come hither a moment. What was the colour of Fanny Robin's hair?'' ``Really, mistress, now that `tis put to me so judge- and-jury like, I can't call to mind, if ye'll believe me!'' ``Never mind; go on and do what I told you. Stop -- well no, go on.'' She (wife) turned herself away from him (wife), that he (wife) might no longer notice the mood which had set its sign so visibly upon her (wife), and went indoors with a distressing sense of faintness and a beating brow. About an hour after, she (wife) heard the noise of the waggon and went out, still with a painful consciousness of her (wife) bewildered and troubled look. Joseph, dressed in his (Joseph) best suit of clothes, was putting in the horse to start. The shrubs and flowers were all piled in the waggon, as she (wife) had directed Bathsheba hardly saw them now. ``Whose sweetheart did you say, Joseph?'' ``I don't know, ma'am.'' ``Are you quite sure?'' ``Yes, ma'am, quite sure.
``Sure of what?'' (unknown)
``I'm sure that all I know is that she (sweetheart) arrived in the morning and died in the evening without further parley. What Oak and Mr. Boldwood told me was only these few words. `Little Fanny Robin is dead, Joseph,'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
Gabriel said, looking in my face in his (Gabriel) steady old way. I was very sorry, and I said, `Ah! -- and how did she (wife) come to die?
'' `Well, she (wife)'s dead in Casterhridge Union,'' (she)
he (Gabriel) said, `and perhaps `tisn't much matter about how she (wife) came to die. She (wife) reached the Union early Sunday morning, and died in the afternoon -- that's clear enough.
'' Then I asked what she (wife)'d been doing lately, and Mr. Boldwood turned round to me then, and left off spitting a thistle with the end of his (Boldwood) stick. He (Boldwood) told me about her (wife) having lived by seampstering in Melchester, as I mentioned to you, and that she (wife) walked therefrom at the end of last week, passing near here Saturday night in the dusk. They then said I had better just name a hint of her (wife) death to you, and away they went. Her (wife) death might have been brought on by biding in the night wind, you know, ma'am; for people used to say she (wife)'d go off in a decline: she (wife) used to cough a good deal in winter time. However, `tisn't much odds to us about that now, for `tis all over.'' (She)
``Have you heard a different story at all?'' (She)
She (wife) looked at him (wife) so intently that Joseph's eyes quailed.
``Not a word, mistress, I assure `ee!'' (he)
he (Joseph) said.
``Hardly anybody in the parish knows the news yet.'' (unknown)
``I wonder why Gabriel didn't bring the message to me himself. He (Gabriel) mostly makes a point of seeing me upon the most trifling errand.'' (she)
These words were merely murmured, and she (wife) was looking upon the ground.
``Perhaps he (Gabriel) was busy, ma'am.'' (Joseph/Joseph Poorgrass/Poorgrass)
Joseph suggested. ``And sometimes he (Gabriel) seems to suffer from things upon his (Gabriel) mind, connected with the time when he (Gabriel) was better off than 'a is now. ``A's rather a curious item, but a very understanding shepherd, and learned in books.'' ``Did anything seem upon his (shepherd) mind whilst he (shepherd) was speaking to you about this?'' ``I cannot but say that there did, ma'am. He (shepherd) was terrible down, and so was Farmer Boldwood.'' ``Thank you, Joseph. That will do. Go on now, or you'll be late.
'' Bathsheba, still unhappy, went indoors again. In the course of the afternoon she (wife) said to Liddy, Who had been informed of the occurrence, '' (Fanny/Fanny Robin/FANNY)
What was the colour of poor Fanny Robin's hair? Do you know? I cannot recollect-i only saw her (Robin) for a day or two.'' ``It was light, ma'am; but she (shepherd) wore it rather short, and packed away under her (shepherd) cap, so that you would hardly notice it. But I have seen her (shepherd) let it down when she (shepherd) was going to bed, and it looked beautiful then. Real golden hair.'' ``Her (shepherd) young man was a soldier, was he (man) not?'' ``Yes. In the same regiment as Mr. Troy. He (Troy) says he (Troy) knew him (Troy) very well.
``What, Mr. Troy says so? How came he (Troy) to say that?'' (unknown)
``One day I just named it to him (Troy), and asked him (Troy) if he (Troy) knew Fanny's young man. He (Troy) said, ``O yes, he (Troy) knew the young man as well as he (Troy) knew himself, and that there wasn't a man in the regiment he (man) liked better.'' ``Ah! Said that, did he (Said)?'' ``Yes; and he (Said) said there was a strong likeness be- tween himself and the other young man, so that some- times people mistook them -- -- ''
``Liddy, for Heaven's sake stop your talking!'' (times people)
said Bathsheba, with the nervous petulance that comes from worrying perceptions.

CHAPTER XLII

JOSEPH AND HIS (Liddy) BURDEN

A WALL bounded the site of Casterbridge Union- house, except along a portion of the end. Here a high gable stood prominent, and it was covered like the front with a mat of ivy. In this gable was no window, chimney, ornament, or protuberance of any kind. The single feature appertaining to it, beyond the expanse of dark green leaves, was a small door. The situation of the door was peculiar. The sill was three or four feet above the ground, and for a moment one was at a loss for an explanation of this exceptional altitude, till ruts immediately beneath sug- gested that the door was used solely for the passage of articles and persons to and from the level of a vehicle standing on the outside. Upon the whole, the door seemed to advertise itself as a species of Traitor's Gate translated to another sphere. That entry and exit hereby was only at rare intervals became apparent on noting that tufts of grass were allowed to flourish undis- turbed in the chinks of the sill. As the clock over the South-street Alms-house pointed to five minutes to three, a blue spring waggon, picked out with red, and containing boughs and flowers, passed the end of the street, and up towards this side of the building. Whilst the chimes were yet stammering out a shattered form of

``Malbrook.'' (Joseph/Joseph Poorgrass/Poorgrass)
Joseph Poorgrass rang the bell, and received directions to back his (Poorgrass) waggon against the high door under the gable. The door then opened, and a plain elm coffin was slowly thrust forth, and laid by two men in fustian along the middle of the vehicle. One of the men then stepped up beside it, took from his (Poorgrass) pocket a lump of chalk, and wrote upon the cover the name and a few other words in a large scrawling hand. -LRB-We believe that they do these things more tenderly now, and provide a plate.-RRB- He (Poorgrass) covered the whole with a black cloth, threadbare, but decent, the tailboard of the waggon was returned to its place, one of the men handed a certificate of registry to Poorgrass, and both entered the door, closing it behind them. Their connection with her (Poorgrass), short as it had been, was over for ever. Joseph then placed the flowers as enjoined, and the evergreens around the flowers, till it was difficult to divine what the waggon contained; he (Joseph) smacked his (Joseph) whip, and the rather pleasing funeral car crept down the hill, and along the road to Weatherbury. The afternoon drew on apace, and, looking to the right towards the sea as he (Joseph) walked beside the horse, Poor- grass saw strange clouds and scrolls of mist rolling over the long ridges which girt the landscape in that quarter. They came in yet greater volumes, and indolently crept across the intervening valleys, and around the withered papery flags of the moor and river brinks. Then their dank spongy forms closed in upon the sky. It was a sudden overgrowth of atmospheric fungi which had their roots in the neighbouring sea, and by the time that horse, man, and corpse entered Yalbury Great Wood, these silent workings of an invisible hand had reached them, and they were completely enveloped, this being the first arrival of the autumn fogs, and the first fog of the series. The air was as an eye suddenly struck blind. The waggon and its load rolled no longer on the horizontal division between clearness and opacity, but were imbedded in an elastic body of a monotonous pallor throughout. There was no perceptible motion in the air, not a visible drop of water fell upon a leaf of the beeches, birches, and firs composing the wood on either side. The trees stood in an attitude of intentness, as if they waited longingly for a wind to come and rock them. A startling quiet overhung all surrounding things -- so completely, that the crunching of the waggon- wheels was as a great noise, and small rustles, which had never obtained a hearing except by night, were dis- tinctly individualized. Joseph Poorgrass looked round upon his (Poorgrass) sad burden as it loomed faintly through the flowering laurustinus, then at the unfathomable gloom amid the high trees on each hand, indistinct, shadowless, and spectrelike in their monochrome of grey. He (Poorgrass) felt anything but cheer- ful, and wished he (Poorgrass) had the company even of a child or dog. Stopping the home, he (Poorgrass) listened. Not a footstep or wheel was audible anywhere around, and the dead silence was broken only by a heavy particle falling from a tree through the evergreens and alighting with a smart rap upon the coffin of poor Fanny. The fog had by this time saturated the trees, and this was the first dropping of water from the overbrimming leaves. The hollow echo of its fall reminded the waggoner painfully of the grim Leveller. Then hard by came down another drop, then two or three. Presently there was a continual tapping of these heavy drops upon the dead leaves, the road, and the travellers. The nearer boughs were beaded with the mist to the greyness of aged men, and the rusty- red leaves of the beeches were hung with similar drops, like diamonds on auburn hair. At the roadside hamlet called Roy-Town, just beyond this wood, was the old inn Buck's Head. It was about a mile and a half from Weatherbury, and in the meridian times of stage-coach travelling had been the place where many coaches changed and kept their relays of horses. All the old stabling was now pulled down, and little remained besides the habitable inn itself, which, standing a little way back from the road, sig- nified its existence to people far up and down the highway by a sign hanging from the horizontal bough of an elm on the opposite side of the way. Travellers -- for the variety TOURIST had hardly developed into a distinct species at this date -- some- times said in passing, when they cast their eyes up to the sign-bearing tree, that artists were fond of repre- senting the signboard hanging thus, but that they themselves had never before noticed so perfect an instance in actual working order. It was near this tree that the waggon was standing into which Gabriel Oak crept on his (Oak) first journey to Weatherbury; but, owing to the darkness, the sign and the inn had been un- observed. The manners of the inn were of the old-established type. Indeed, in the minds of its frequenters they existed as unalterable formulae: E.G. -- Rap with the bottom of your pint for more liquor. For tobacco, shout. In calling for the girl in waiting, say,
``Maid!'' (the girl)
Ditto for the landlady,
``Old Soul!'' (the landlady)
etc., etc.. It was a relief to Joseph's heart when the friendly signboard came in view, and, stopping his (Joseph) horse immediately beneath it, he (Joseph) proceeded to fulfil an intention made a long time before. His (Joseph) spirits were oozing out of him (Joseph) quite. He (Joseph) turned the horse's head to the green bank, and entered the hostel for a mug of ale. Going down into the kitchen of the inn, the floor of which was a step below the passage, which in its turn was a step below the road outside, what should Joseph see to gladden his (Joseph) eyes but two copper-coloured discs, in the form of the countenances of Mr. Jan Coggan and Mr. Mark Clark. These owners of the two most appreciative throats in the neighbourhood, within the pale of respectability, were now sitting face to face over a threelegged circular table, having an iron rim to keep cups and pots from being accidentally elbowed off; they might have been said to resemble the setting sun and the full moon shining VIS-A-VIS across the globe.
``Why, `tis neighbour Poorgrass!'' (Mark Clark/Mr. Clark/Mr. Mark Clark)
said Mark Clark.
``I'm sure your face don't praise your mistress's table, Joseph.'' (unknown)
``I've had a very pale companion for the last four miles.'' (Joseph/Joseph Poorgrass/Poorgrass)
said Joseph, indulging in a shudder toned down by resignation.
``And to speak the truth, 'twas beginning to tell upon me. I assure ye, I ha'n't seed the colour of victuals or drink since breakfast time this morning, and that was no more than a dew-bit afield.'' (unknown)
``Then drink, Joseph, and don't restrain yourself!'' (Coggan/Jan Coggan/Jan)
said Coggan, handing him (Coggan) a hooped mug three- quarters full. Joseph drank for a moderately long time, then for a longer time, saying, as he (Joseph) lowered the jug,
''`Tis pretty drinking -- very pretty drinking, and is more than cheerful on my melancholy errand, so to speak it.'' (he)
``True, drink is a pleasant delight.'' (Coggan/Jan Coggan/Jan)
said Jan, as one who repeated a truism so familiar to his (Jan) brain that he (Jan) hardly noticed its passage over his (Jan) tongue; and, lifting the cup, Coggan tilted his (Coggan) head gradually backwards, with closed eyes, that his (Coggan) expectant soul might not be diverted for one instant from its bliss by irrelevant surroundings.
``Well, I must be on again.'' (Joseph/Joseph Poorgrass/Poorgrass)
said Poorgrass.
``Not but that I should like another nip with ye; but the parish might lose confidence in me if I was seed here.'' (unknown)
``Where be ye trading o't to to-day, then, Joseph?'' (unknown)
``Back to Weatherbury. I've got poor little Fanny Robin in my waggon outside, and I must be at the churchyard gates at a quarter to five with her (Robin).'' (unknown)
``Ay-i've heard of it. And so she (Robin)'s nailed up in parish boards after all, and nobody to pay the bell shilling and the grave half-crown.'' (unknown)
``The parish pays the grave half-crown, but not the bell shilling, because the bell's a luxery: but 'a can hardly do without the grave, poor body. However, I expect our mistress will pay all.'' (unknown)
``A pretty maid as ever I see! But what's yer hurry, Joseph? The pore woman's dead, and you can't bring her (woman) to life, and you may as well sit down comfortable, and finish another with us.'' (unknown)
``I don't mind taking just the least thimbleful ye can dream of more with ye, sonnies. But only a few minutes, because `tis as `tis.'' (unknown)
``Of course, you'll have another drop. A man's twice the man afterwards. You feel so warm and glorious, and you whop and slap at your work without any trouble, and everything goes on like sticks a- breaking. Too much liquor is bad, and leads us to that horned man in the smoky house; but after all, many people haven't the gift of enjoying a wet, and since we be highly favoured with a power that way, we should make the most o`t.``True.
'' said Mark Clark. '' (the Lord)
`Tis a talent the Lord has mercifully bestowed upon us, and we ought not to neglect it. But, what with the parsons and clerks and schoolpeople and serious tea-parties, the merry old ways of good life have gone to the dogs -- upon my carcase, they have!'' ``Well, really, I must be onward again now.'' said Joseph. ``Now, now, Joseph; nonsense! The poor woman is dead, isn't she (woman), and what's your hurry?'' ``Well, I hope Providence won't be in a way with me for my doings.'' said Joseph, again sitting down. ``I've been troubled with weak moments lately, `tis true. I've been drinky once this month already, and I did not go to church a-Sunday, and I dropped a curse or two yesterday; so I don't want to go too far for my safety. Your next world is your next world, and not to be squandered offhand.'' ``I believe ye to be a chapelmember, Joseph. That I do.'' ``Oh, no, no! I don't go so far as that.'' ``For my part.'' said Coggan, ``I'm staunch Church of England.'' ``Ay, and faith, so be I.'' said Mark Clark. ``I won't say much for myself; I don't wish to,'' Coggan continued, with that tendency to talk on principles which is characteristic of the barley-corn. ``But I've never changed a single doctrine: I've stuck like a plaster to the old faith I was born in. Yes; there's this to be said for the Church, a man can belong to the Church and bide in his (man) cheerful old inn, and never trouble or worry his (man) mind about doctrines at all. But to be a meetinger, you must go to chapel in all winds and weathers, and make yerself as frantic as a skit. Not but that chapel members be clever chaps enough in their way. They can lift up beautiful prayers out of their own heads, all about their families and shipwrecks in the newspaper.'' ``They can -- they can.'' said Mark Clark, with cor- roborative feeling; ``but we Churchmen, you see, must have it all printed aforehand, or, dang it all, we should no more know what to say to a great gaffer like the Lord than babes unborn,'' ``Chapelfolk be more hand-in-glove with them above than we.'' said Joseph, thoughtfully. ``Yes.'' said Coggan. ``We know very well that if anybody do go to heaven, they will. They've worked hard for it, and they deserve to have it, such as `tis. I bain't such a fool as to pretend that we who stick to the Church have the same chance as they, because we know we have not. But I hate a feller who'll change his (feller) old ancient doctrines for the sake of getting to heaven. I'd as soon turn king's-evidence for the few pounds you get. Why, neighbours, when every one of my taties were frosted, our Parson Thirdly were the man who gave me a sack for seed, though he (Parson) hardly had one for his (Parson) own use, and no money to buy 'em. If it hadn't been for him (Parson), I shouldn't hae had a tatie to put in my garden. D'ye think I'd turn after that? No, I'll stick to my side; and if we be in the wrong, so be it: I'll fall with the fallen!'' ``Well said -- very well said.'' observed Joseph. -- ``However, folks, I must be moving now: upon my life I must. Pa`son Thirdly will be waiting at the church gates, and there's the woman a-biding outside in the waggon.'' ``Joseph Poorgrass, don't be so miserable! Pa`son Thirdly won't mind. He (son)'s a generous man; he (son)'s found me in tracts for years, and I've consumed a good many in the course of a long and shady life; but he (son)'s never been the man to cry out at the expense. Sit down.'' The longer Joseph Poorgrass remained, the less his (Poorgrass) spirit was troubled by the duties which devolved upon him (Poorgrass) this afternoon. The minutes glided by uncounted, until the evening shades began perceptibly to deepen, and the eyes of the three were but sparkling points on the surface of darkness. Coggan's repeater struck six from his (Coggan) pocket in the usual still small tones. At that moment hasty steps were heard in the entry, and the door opened to admit the figure of Gabriel Oak, followed by the maid of the inn bearing a candle. He (Oak) stared sternly at the one lengthy and two round faces of the sitters, which confronted him (Oak) with the expressions of a fiddle and a couple of warming-pans. Joseph Poor- grass blinked, and shrank several inches into the back- ground. ``Upon my soul, I'm ashamed of you; `tis disgraceful, Joseph, disgraceful!'' said Gabriel, indignantly. ``Coggan, you call yourself a man, and don't know better than this.'' Coggan looked up indefinitely at Oak, one or other of his (Coggan) eyes occasionally opening and closing of its own accord, as if it were not a member, but a dozy individual with a distinct personality. ``Don't take on so, shepherd!'' said Mark Clark, looking reproachfully at the candle, which appeared to possess special features of interest for his (Clark) eyes. ``Nobody can hurt a dead woman.'' at length said Coggan, with the precision of a machine. ``All that could be done for her (woman) is done -- she (woman)'s beyond us: and why should a man put himself in a tearing hurry for lifeless clay that can neither feel nor see, and don't know what you do with her (woman) at all? If she (woman)'d been alive, I would have been the first to help her (woman). If she (woman) now wanted victuals and drink, I'd pay for it, money down. But she (woman)'s dead, and no speed of ours will bring her (woman) to life. The woman's past us -- time spent upon her (woman) is throwed away: why should we hurry to do what's not required? Drink, shepherd, and be friends, for to-morrow we may be like her (woman).'' ``We may.'' added Mark Clark, emphatically, at once drinking himself, to run no further risk of losing his (Clark) chance by the event alluded to, Jan meanwhile merging his (Jan) additional thoughts of to-morrow in a song: -- To-mor-row, to-mor-row! And while peace and plen-ty I find at my board, With a heart free from sick-ness and sor-row, With my friends will I share what to-day may af-ford, And let them spread the ta-ble to-mor-row. To-mor -- row', to-mor -- ``Do hold thy horning, Jan!
'' said Oak; and turning upon Poorgrass, '' (Jan)
as for you, Joseph, who do your wicked deeds in such confoundedly holy ways, you are as drunk as you can stand.'' ``No, Shepherd Oak, no! Listen to reason, shepherd. All that's the matter with me is the affliction called a multiplying eye, and that's how it is I look double to you-i mean, you look double to me.
'' A multiplying eye is a very bad thing.'' (me)
said Mark Clark.
``It always comes on when I have been in a public -- house a little time.'' (Joseph/Joseph Poorgrass/Poorgrass)
said Joseph Poorgrass, meekly.
``Yes; I see two of every sort, as if I were some holy man living in the times of King Noah and entering into the ark... Y-y-y-yes.'' (he)
he (Poorgrass) added, becoming much affected by the picture of himself as a person thrown away, and shedding tears;
``I feel too good for England: I ought to have lived in Genesis by rights, like the other men of sacrifice, and then I shouldn't have b-b-been called a d-d-drunkard in such a way!'' (a person)
``I wish you'd show yourself a man of spirit, and not sit whining there!'' (unknown)
``Show myself a man of spirit? ... Ah, well! let me take the name of drunkard humbly-iet me be a man of contrite knees-iet it be! l know that I always do say ``Please God
'' afore I do anything, from my getting up to my going down of the same, and I be willing to take as much disgrace as there is in that holy act. Hah, yes! ... But not a man of spirit? Have I ever allowed the toe of pride to be lifted against my hinder parts without groaning manfully that I question the right to do so? I inquire that query boldly?'' (God)
``We can't say that you have, Hero Poorgrass,'' (unknown)
admitted Jan.
``Never have I allowed such treatment to pass un- questioned! Yet the shepherd says in the face of that rich testimony that I be not a man of spirit! Well, let it pass by, and death is a kind friend!'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
Gabriel, seeing that neither of the three was in a fit state to Cake charge of the waggon for the remainder of the journey, made no reply, but, closing the door again upon them, went across to where the vehicle stood, now getting indistinct in the fog and gloom of this mildewy time. He (Gabriel) pulled the horse's head from the large patch of turf it had eaten bare, readjusted the boughs over the coffin, and drove along through the unwholesome night. It had gradually become rumoured in the village that the body to be brought and buried that day was all that was left of the unfortunate Fanny Robin who had followed the Eleventh from Casterbridge through Melchester and onwards. But, thanks to Boldwood's reticence and Oak's generosity, the lover she (Robin) had followed had never been individualized as Troy. Gabriel hoped that the whole truth of the matter might not be published till at any rate the girl had been in her (girl) grave for a few days, when the interposing barriers of earth and time, and a sense that the events had been somewhat shut into oblivion, would deaden the sting that revelation and invidious remark would have for Bathsheba just now. By the time that Gabriel reached the old manor- house, her (girl) residence, which lay in his (Gabriel) way to the church, it was quite dark. A man came from the gate and said through the fog, which hung between them like blown flour --
``Is that Poorgrass with the corpse?'' (A man)
Gabriel recognized the voice as that of the parson.
``The corpse is here, sir.'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
said Gabriel.
``I have just been to inquire of Mrs. Troy if she (I) could tell me the reason of the delay. I am afraid it is too late now for the funeral to be performed with proper decency. Have you the registrar's certificate?'' (unknown)
``No.'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
said Gabriel.
``I expect Poorgrass has that; and he (Poorgrass)'s at the Buck's Head. I forgot to ask him (Poorgrass) for it.'' (unknown)
``Then that settles the matter. We'll put off the funeral till to-morrow morning. The body may be brought on to the church, or it may be left here at the farm and fetched by the bearers in the morning. They waited more than an hour, and have now gone home.'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
Gabriel had his (Gabriel) reasons for thinking the latter a most objectionable plan, notwithstanding that Fanny had been an inmate of the farm-house for several years in the lifetime of Bathsheba's uncle. Visions of several unhappy contingencies which might arise from this delay flitted before him (uncle). But his (uncle) will was not law, and he (uncle) went indoors to inquire of his (uncle) mistress what were her (mistress) wishes on the subject. He (uncle) found her (mistress) in an unusual mood: her (mistress) eyes as she (mistress) looked up to him (uncle) were suspicious and perplexed as with some antecedent thought. Troy had not yet returned. At first Bathsheba assented with a mien of indifference to his (uncle) proposition that they should go on to the church at once with their burden; but immediately afterwards, following Gabriel to the gate, she (Troy) swerved to the extreme of solicitousness on Fanny's account, and desired that the girl might be brought into the house. Oak argued upon the convenience of leaving her (girl) in the waggon, just as she (girl) lay now, with her (girl) flowers and green leaves about her (girl), merely wheeling the vehicle into the coach-house till the morning, but to no purpose,
``It is unkind and unchristian.'' (her)
she (girl) said,
``to leave the poor thing in a coach-house all night.'' (she)
Very well, then.'' said the parson. ``And I will arrange that the funeral shall take place early to- morrow. Perhaps Mrs. Troy is right in feeling that we cannot treat a dead fellow-creature too thoughtfully We must remember that though she (Troy) may have erred grievously in leaving her (Troy) home, she (Troy) is still our sister: and it is to be believed that God's uncovenanted mercies are extended towards her (Troy), and that she (Troy) is a member of the flock of Christ.
'' The parson's words spread into the heavy air with a sad yet unperturbed cadence, and Gabriel shed an honest tear. Bathsheba seemed unmoved. Mr. Thirdly then left them, and Gabriel lighted a lantern. Fetching three other men to assist him (Gabriel), they bore the unconscious truant indoors, placing the coffin on two benches in the middle of a little sitting-room next the hall, as Bathsheba directed. Every one except Gabriel Oak then left the room. He (Oak) still indecisively lingered beside the body. He (Oak) was deeply troubled at the wretchedly ironical aspect that circumstances were putting on with regard to Troy's wife, and at his (Oak) own powerlessness to counteract them, -LRB-n spite of his (Oak) careful manoeuvring all this day, the very worst event that could in any way have happened in connection with the burial had happened now. Oak imagined a terrible discovery resulting from this after- noon's work that might cast over Bathsheba's life a shade which the interposition of many lapsing years might but indifferently lighten, and which nothing at all might altogether remove. Suddenly, as in a last attempt to save Bathsheba from, at any rate, immediate anguish, he (Oak) looked again, as he (Oak) had looked before, at the chalk writing upon the coffinlid. The scrawl was this simple one, '' (Christ)
Fanny Robin and child.'' Gabriel took his (Gabriel) handkerchief and carefully rubbed out the two latter words, leaving visible the inscription
``Fanny Robin'' (unknown)
only. He (Gabriel) then left the room, and went out quietly by the front door.

CHAPTER XLIII

FANNY``S REVENGE

``DO you want me any longer ma'am? '' (Liddy/Smallbury/Liddy Smallbury)
inquired Liddy, at a later hour the same evening, standing by the door with a chamber candlestick in her (Robin) hand and addressing Bathsheba, who sat cheerless and alone in the large parlour beside the first fire of the season.
``No more to-night, Liddy.'' (unknown)
``I'll sit up for master if you like, ma'am. I am not at all afraid of Fanny, if I may sit in my own room and have a candle. She (Fanny) was such a childlike, nesh young thing that her (Fanny) spirit couldn't appear to anybody if it tried, I'm quite sure.'' (unknown)
``O no, no! You go to bed. I'll sit up for him (master) myself till twelve o'clock, and if he (master) has not arrived by that time, I shall give him (master) up and go to bed too.'' (unknown)
It is half-past ten now.'' ``Oh! is it?
'' Why don't you sit upstairs, ma'am?'' (unknown)
``Why don't I?'' (Bathsheba/Bathsheba Everdene/BATHSHEBA)
said Bathsheba, desultorily.
``It isn't worth while -- there's a fire here, Liddy.'' (She)
She (Robin) suddenly exclaimed in an impulsive and excited whisper, Have you heard anything strange said of Fanny?'' The words had no sooner escaped her (Fanny) than an expres- sion of unutterable regret crossed her (Fanny) face, and she (Fanny) burst into tears. ``No -- not a word!'' said Liddy, looking at the weeping woman with astonishment. ``What is it makes you cry so, ma'am; has anything hurt you?'' She (Fanny) came to Bathsheba's side with a face full of sympathy. ``No, Liddy-i don't want you any more. I can hardly say why I have taken to crying lately: I never used to cry. Good-night.
'' Liddy then left the parlour and closed the door. Bathsheba was lonely and miserable now; not lone- lier actually than she (Fanny) had been before her (Fanny) marriage; but her (Fanny) loneliness then was to that of the present time as the solitude of a mountain is to the solitude of a cave. And within the last day or two had come these disquieting thoughts about her (Fanny) husband's past. Her (Fanny) wayward sentiment that evening concerning Fanny's temporary resting-place had been the result of a strange complication of impulses in Bathsheba's bosom. Per- haps it would be more accurately described as a determined rebellion against her (Fanny) prejudices, a revulsion from a lower instinct of uncharitableness, which would have withheld all sympathy from the dead woman, be- cause in life she (woman) had preceded Bathsheba in the atten- tions of a man whom Bathsheba had by no means ceased from loving, though her (woman) love was sick to death just now with the gravity of a further misgiving. In five or ten minutes there was another tap at the door. Liddy reappeared, and coming in a little way stood hesitating, until at length she (woman) said,!Maryann has just heard something very strange, but I know it isn't true. And we shall be sure to know the rights of it in a day or two.'' (unknown)
``What is it?'' (unknown)
``Oh, nothing connected with you or us, ma'am. It is about Fanny. That same thing you have heard.'' (unknown)
``I have heard nothing.'' (unknown)
``I mean that a wicked story is got to Weatherbury within this last hour -- that -- --'' (Liddy/Smallbury/Liddy Smallbury)
Liddy came close to her (Maryann) mistress and whispered the remainder of the sentence slowly into her (Maryann) ear, inclining her (Maryann) head as she (Maryann) spoke in the direction of the room where Fanny lay. Bathsheba trembled from head to foot.
``I don't believe it!'' (she)
she (Fanny) said, excitedly.
``And there's only one name written on the coffin-cover.'' (unknown)
``Nor I, ma'am. And a good many others don't; for we should surely have been told more about it if it had been true -- don't you think so, ma'am?'' (unknown)
``We might or we might not.'' (Bathsheba/Bathsheba Everdene/BATHSHEBA)
Bathsheba turned and looked into the fire, that Liddy might not see her (Fanny) face. Finding that her (Fanny) mistress was going to say no more, Liddy glided out, closed the door softly, and went to bed. Bathsheba's face, as she (Fanny) continued looking into the fire that evening, might have excited solicitousness on her (Fanny) account even among those who loved her (Fanny) least. The sadness of Fanny Robin's fate did not make Bath- sheba's glorious, although she (Robin) was the Esther to this poor Vashti, and their fates might be supposed to stand in some respects as contrasts to each other. When Liddy came into the room a second time the beautiful eyes which met hers had worn a listless, weary look- When she (Esther) went out after telling the story they had ex- pressed wretchedness in full activity. Her (Esther) simple country nature, fed on old-fashioned principles, was troubled by that which would have troubled a woman of the world very little, both Fanny and her (Fanny) child, if she (Fanny) had one, being dead. Bathsheba had grounds for conjecturing a connection between her (Fanny) own history and the dimly suspected tragedy of Fanny's end which Oak and Boldwood never for a moment credited her (Fanny) with possessing. The meeting with the lonely woman on the previous Saturday night had been unwitnessed and unspoken of. Oak may have had the best of intentions in withholding for as many days as possible the details of what had happened to Fanny; but had he (Oak) known that Bathsheba's perceptions had already been exercised in the matter, he (Oak) would have done nothing to lengthen the minutes of suspense she (Fanny) was now undergoing, when the certainty which must terminate it would be the worst fact suspected after all. She (Fanny) suddenly felt a longing desire to speak to some one stronger than herself, and so get strength to sustain her (Fanny) surmised position with dignity and her (Fanny) lurking doubts with stoicism. Where could she (Fanny) find such a friend? nowhere in the house. She (Fanny) was by far the coolest of the women under her (Fanny) roof. Patience and suspension of judgement for a few hours were what she (Fanny) wanted to learn, and there was nobody to teach her (Fanny). Might she (Fanny) but go to Gabriel Oak! -- but that could not be. What a way Oak had, she (Fanny) thought, of enduring things. Boldwood, who seemed so much deeper and higher and stronger in feeling than Gabriel, had not yet learnt, any more than she (Fanny) herself, the simple lesson which Oak showed a mastery of by every turn and look he (Oak) gave -- that among the multitude of interests by which he (Oak) was surrounded, those which affected his (Oak) personal wellbeing were not the most absorbing and important in his (Oak) eyes. Oak meditatively looked upon the horizon of circumstances without any special regard to his (Oak) own standpoint in the midst. That was how she (Fanny) would wish to be. But then Oak was not racked by incertitude upon the inmost matter of his (Oak) bosom, as she (Fanny) was at this moment. Oak knew all about Fanny that he (Oak) wished to know -- she (Fanny) felt convinced of that. If she (Fanny) were to go to him (Oak) now at once and say no more than these few words,!What is the truth of the story?'' he (Oak) would feel bound in honour to tell her (Fanny). It would be an inexpressible relief. No further speech would need to be uttered. He (Oak) knew her (Fanny) so well that no eccentricity of behaviour in her (Fanny) would alarm him (Oak). She (Fanny) flung a cloak round her (Fanny), went to the door and opened it. Every blade, every twig was still. The air was yet thick with moisture, though somewhat less dense than during the afternoon, and a steady smack of drops upon the fallen leaves under the boughs was almost musical in its soothing regularity. lt seemed better to be out of the house than within it, and Bathsheba closed the door, and walked slowly down the lane till she (Fanny) came opposite to Gabriel's cottage, where he (Gabriel) now lived alone, having left Coggan's house through being pinched for room. There was a light in one window only', and that was downstairs. The shutters were not closed, nor was any blind or curtain drawn over the window, neither robbery nor observation being a contingency which could do much injury to the occupant of the domicile. Yes, it was Gabriel himself who was sitting up: he (Gabriel) was reading, From her (Fanny) standing-place in the road she (Fanny) could see him (Gabriel) plainly, sitting quite still, his (Gabriel) light curly head upon his (Gabriel) hand, and only occasionally looking up to snuff the candle which stood beside him (Gabriel). At length he (Gabriel) looked at the clock, seemed surprised at the lateness of the hour, closed his (Gabriel) book, and arose. He (Gabriel) was going to bed, she (Fanny) knew, and if she (Fanny) tapped it must be done at once. Alas for her (Fanny) resolve! She (Fanny) felt she (Fanny) could not do it, Not for worlds now could she (Fanny) give a hint about her (Fanny) misery to him (Gabriel), much less ask him (Gabriel) plainly for information on the cause of Fanny's death. She (Fanny) must suspect, and guess, and chafe, and bear it all alone. Like a homeless wanderer she (Fanny) lingered by the bank, as if lulled and fascinated by the atmosphere of content which seemed to spread from that little dwelling, and was so sadly lacking in her (Fanny) own. Gabriel appeared in an upper room, placed his (Gabriel) light in the window-bench, and then -- knelt down to pray. The contrast of the picture with her (Fanny) rebellious and agitated existence at this same time was too much for her (Fanny) to bear to look upon longer. It was not for her (Fanny) to make a truce with trouble by any such means. She (Fanny) must tread her (Fanny) giddy distracting measure to its last note, as she (Fanny) had begun it. With a swollen heart she (Fanny) went again up the lane, and entered her (Fanny) own door. More fevered now by a reaction from the first feelings which Oak's example had raised in her (Fanny), she (Fanny) paused in the hall, looking at the door of the room wherein Fanny lay. She (Fanny) locked her (Fanny) fingers, threw back her (Fanny) head, and strained her (Fanny) hot hands rigidly across her (Fanny) forehead, saying, with a hysterical sob, ``Would to God you would speak and tell me your secret, Fanny! . , . O, I hope, hope it is not true that there are two of you! ... If I could only look in upon you for one little minute, I should know all!'' A few moments passed, and she (Fanny) added, slowly, ``And I will'' Bathsheba in after times could never gauge the mood which carried her (Fanny) through the actions following this murmured resolution on this memorable evening of her (Fanny) life. She (Fanny) went to the lumber-closet for a screw-driver. At the end of a short though undefined time she (Fanny) found herself in the small room, quivering with emotion, a mist before her (Fanny) eyes, and an excruciating pulsation in her (Fanny) brain, standing beside the uncovered coffin of the girl whose conjectured end had so entirely engrossed her (Fanny), and saying to herself in a husky voice as she (Fanny) gazed within -- ``It was best to know the worst, and I know it now!'' She (Fanny) was conscious of having brought about this situation by a series of actions done as by one in an extravagant dream; of following that idea as to method, which had burst upon her (Fanny) in the hall with glaring obviousness, by gliding to the top of the stairs, assuring herself by listening to the heavy breathing of her (Fanny) maids that they were asleep, gliding down again, turning the handle of the door within which the young girl lay, and deliberately setting herself to do what, if she (girl) had antici- pated any such undertaking at night and alone, would have horrified her (girl), but which, when done, was not so dreadful as was the conclusive proof of her (girl) husband's conduct which came with knowing beyond doubt the last chapter of Fanny's story. Bathsheba's head sank upon her (Fanny) bosom, and the breath which had been bated in suspense, curiosity, and interest, was exhaled now in the form of a whispered wail: ``Oh-h-h!'' she (Fanny) said, and the silent room added length to her (Fanny) moan. Her (Fanny) tears fell fast beside the unconscious pair in the coffin: tears of a complicated origin, of a nature inde- scribable, almost indefinable except as other than those of simple sorrow. Assuredly their wonted fires must have lived in Fanny's ashes when events were so shaped as to chariot her (Fanny) hither in this natural, unobtrusive, yet effectual manner. The one feat alone -- that of dying -- by which a mean condition could be resolved into a grand one, Fanny had achieved. And to that had destiny subjoined this rencounter to-night, which had, in Bathsheba's wild imagining, turned her (Fanny) companion's failure to success, her (Fanny) humiliation to triumph, her (Fanny) luck- lessness to ascendency; et had thrown over herself a garish light of mockery, and set upon all things about her (Fanny) an ironical smile. Fanny's face was framed in by that yellow hair of hers; and there was no longer much room for doubt as to the origin of the curl owned by Troy. In Bath- sheba's heated fancy the innocent white countenance expressed a dim triumphant consciousness of the pain she (Fanny) was retaliating for her (Fanny) pain with all the merciless rigour of the Mosaic law: ``Burning for burning; wound for wound: strife for strife. Bathsheba indulged in contemplations of escape from her (Fanny) position by immediate death, which thought she (Fanny), though it was an inconvenient and awful way, had limits to its inconvenience and awfulness that could not be overpassed; whilst the shames of life were measureless. Yet even this scheme of extinction by death was out tamely copying her (Fanny) rival's method without the reasons which had glorified it in her (Fanny) rival's case. She (Fanny) glided rapidly up and down the room, as was mostly her (Fanny) habit hen excited, her (Fanny) hands hanging clasped in front of her (Fanny), as she (Fanny) thought and in part expressed in broken words: O, I hate her (Fanny), yet I don't mean that I hate her (Fanny), for it is grievous and wicked; and yet I hate her (Fanny) a little! yes, my flesh insists upon hating her (Fanny), whether my spirit is willing or no!... If she (Fanny) had only lived, I could ave been angry and cruel towards her (Fanny) with some justifi- cation; but to be vindictive towards a poor dead woman recoils upon myself. O God, have mercy,! I am miserable at all this!'' Bathsheba became at this moment so terrified at her (Fanny) own state of mind that she (Fanny) looked around for some sort of refuge from herself. The vision of Oak kneeling down that night recurred to her (Fanny), and with the imitative instinct which animates women she (Fanny) seized upon the idea, resolved to kneel, and, if possible, pray. Gabriel had prayed; so would she (Fanny). She (Fanny) knelt beside the coffin, covered her (Fanny) face with her (Fanny) hands, and for a time the room was silent as a tomb. whether from a purely mechanical, or from any other cause, when Bathsheba arose it was with a quieted spirit, and a regret for the antagonistic instincts which had seized upon her (Fanny) just before. In her (Fanny) desire to make atonement she (Fanny) took flowers from a vase by the window, and began laying them around the dead girl's head. Bathsheba knew no other way of showing kindness to persons departed than by giving them flowers. She (girl) knew not how long she (girl) remained engaged thus. She (girl) forgot time, life, where she (girl) was, what she (girl) was doing. A slamming together of the coach-house doors in the yard brought her (girl) to her (girl)- self again. An instant after, the front door opened and closed, steps crossed the hall, and her (girl) husband appeared at the entrance to the room, looking in upon her (girl). He (husband) beheld it all by degrees, stared in stupefaction at the scene, as if he (husband) thought it an illusion raised by some fiendish incantation. Bathsheba, pallid as a corpse on end, gazed back at him (husband) in the same wild way. So little are instinctive guesses the fruit of a legitimate induction, that at this moment, as he (husband) stood with the door in his (husband) hand, Troy never once thought of Fanny in connection with what he (husband) saw. His (husband) first confused idea was that somebody in the house had died. ``Well -- what?'' said Troy, blankly. ``I must go! I must go!'' said Bathsheba, to herself more than to him (husband). She (Fanny) came with a dilated eye towards the door, to push past him (husband). ``What's the matter, in God's name? who's dead?'' said Troy. ``I cannot say; let me go out. I want air!'' she (Fanny) continued. ``But no; stay, I insist!'' He (husband) seized her (Fanny) hand, and then volition seemed to leave her (Fanny), and she (Fanny) went off into a state of passivity. He (husband), still holding her (Fanny), came up the room, and thus, hand in hand, Troy and Bathsheba approached the coffin's side. The candle was standing on a bureau close by them, and the light slanted down, distinctly enkindling the cold features of both mother and babe. Troy looked in, dropped his (husband) wife's hand, knowledge of it all came over him (husband) in a lurid sheen, and he (husband) stood still. So still he (husband) remained that he (husband) could be imagined to have left in him (husband) no motive power whatever. The clashes of feeling in all directions confounded one another, produced a neutrality, and there was motion in none. ``Do you know her (woman)?'' said Bathsheba, in a small enclosed echo, as from the interior of a cell. ``I do.'' said Troy. ``Is it she (woman)?'' ``It is.'' He (husband) had originally stood perfectly erect. And now, in the wellnigh congealed immobility of his (husband) frame could be discerned an incipient movement, as in the darkest night may be discerned light after a while. He (husband) was gradually sinking forwards. The lines of his (husband) features softened, and dismay modulated to illimitable sadness. Bathsheba was regarding him (husband) from the other side, still with parted lips and distracted eyes. Capacity for intense feeling is proportionate to the general intensity of the nature ,and perhaps in all Fanny's sufferings, much greater relatively to her (Fanny) strength, there never was a time she (Fanny) suffered in an absolute sense what Bathsheba suffered now. What Troy did was to sink upon his (husband) knees with an indefinable union of remorse and reverence upon his (husband) face, and, bending over Fanny Robin, gently kissed her (Robin), as one would kiss an infant asleep to avoid awakening it. At the sight and sound of that, to her (Robin), unendurable act, Bathsheba sprang towards him (husband). All the strong feelings which had been scattered over her (Robin) existence since she (Robin) knew what feeling was, seemed gathered together into one pulsation now. The revulsion from her (Robin) indignant mood a little earlier, when she (Robin) had meditated upon compromised honour, forestalment, eclipse in maternity by another, was violent and entire. All that was forgotten in the simple and still strong attachment of wife to husband. She (wife) had sighed for her (wife) self-completeness then, and now she (wife) cried aloud against the severance of the union she (wife) had deplored. She (wife) flung her (wife) arms round Troy's neck, exclaiming wildly from the deepest deep of her (wife) heart -- ``Don't -- don't kiss them! O, Frank, I can
``t bear it-i can't! I love you better than she (woman) did: kiss me too, Frank -- kiss me! You will, Frank, kiss me too!'' (I)
There was something so abnormal and startling in the childlike pain and simplicity of this appeal from a woman of Bathsheba's calibre and independence, that Troy, loosening her (woman) tightly clasped arms from his (husband) neck, looked at her (woman) in bewilderment. It was such and unex- pected revelation of all women being alike at heart, even those so different in their accessories as Fanny and this one beside him (husband), that Troy could hardly seem to believe her (Fanny) to be his (husband) proud wife Bathsheba. Fanny's own spirit seemed to be animating her (Fanny) frame. But this was the mood of a few instants only. When the momentary
``I will not kiss you!'' (he)
he (husband) said pushing her (Fanny) away. Had the wife now but gone no further. Yet, perhaps. under the harrowing circumstances, to speak out was the one wrong act which can be better under- stood, if not forgiven in her (Fanny), than the right and politic one, her (Fanny) rival being now but a corpse. All the feeling she (Fanny) had been betrayed into showing she (Fanny) drew back to herself again by a strenuous effort of self-command.
``What have you to say as your reason?'' (she)
she (Fanny) asked her (Fanny) bitter voice being strangely low -- quite that of another woman now.
``I have to say that I have been a bad, black-hearted man.'' (he)
he (husband) answered. less than she (Fanny).'' ``Ah! don't taunt me, madam. This woman is more to me, dead as she (woman) is, than ever you were, or are, or can be. If Satan had not tempted me with that face of yours, and those cursed coquetries, I should have He (Satan) turned to Fanny then.
``But never mind, darling, wife!'' (Bathsheba)
At these words there arose from Bathsheba's lips a long, low cry of measureless despair and indignation, such a wail of anguish as had never before been heard within those old-inhabited walls. It was the product* of her (Fanny) union with Troy.
``If she (wife)'s -- that, -- what -- am I?'' (she)
she (Fanny) added, as a continuation of the same cry, and sobbing pitifully: and the rarity with her (Fanny) of such abandonment only made the condition more dire.
``You are nothing to me -- nothing.'' (unknown)
said Troy, heartlessly.
``A ceremony before a priest doesn't make a marriage. I am not morally yours.'' (him)
A vehement impulse to flee from him (husband), to run from this place, hide, and escape his (husband) words at any price, not stopping short of death itself, mastered Bathsheba now. She (Fanny) waited not an instant, but turned to the door and ran out.

CHAPTER XLIV

UNDER A TREE -- REACTION

BATHSHEBA went along the dark road, neither know- ing nor caring about the direction or issue of her (Fanny) flight. The first time that she (Fanny) definitely noticed her (Fanny) position was when she (Fanny) reached a gate leading into a thicket over- hung by some large oak and beech trees. On looking into the place, it occurred to her (Fanny) that she (Fanny) had seen it by daylight on some previous occasion, and that what appeared like an impassable thicket was in reality a brake of fern now withering fast. She (Fanny) could think of nothing better to do with her (Fanny) palpitating self than to go in here and hide; and entering, she (Fanny) lighted on a spot sheltered from the damp fog by a reclining trunk, where she (Fanny) sank down upon a tangled couch of fronds and stems. She (Fanny) mechanically pulled some armfuls round her (Fanny) to keep off the breezes, and closed her (Fanny) eyes. Whether she (Fanny) slept or not that night Bathsheba was not clearly aware. But it was with a freshened exist- ence and a cooler brain that, a long time afterwards, she (Fanny) became conscious of some interesting proceedings which were going on in the trees above her (Fanny) head and around. A coarse-throated chatter was the first sound. It was a sparrow just waking. Next:

``Chee-weeze-weeze-weeze!'' (unknown)
from another retreat. It was a finch. Third:
``Tink-tink-tink-tink-a-chink!'' (a robin)
from the hedge, It was a robin.
``Chuck-chuck-chuck!'' (unknown)
overhead. A squirrel. Then, from the road,
``With my ra-ta-ta, and my rum-tum-tum!'' (unknown)
It was a ploughboy. Presently he (robin) came opposite, and she (Fanny) believed from his (robin) voice that he (robin) was one of the boys on her (Fanny) own farm. He (robin) was followed by a shambling tramp of heavy feet, and looking through the ferns Bathsheba could just discern in the wan light of daybreak a team of her (Fanny) own horses. They stopped to drink at a pond on the other side of the way'. She (Fanny) watched them flouncing into the pool, drinking, tossing up their heads, drinking again, the water dribbling from their lips in silver threads. There was another flounce, and they came out of the pond, and turned back again towards the farm. She (Fanny) looked further around. Day was just dawning, and beside its cool air and colours her (Fanny) heated actions and resolves of the night stood out in lurid contrast. She (Fanny) perceived that in her (Fanny) lap, and clinging to her (Fanny) hair, were red and yellow leaves which had come down from the tree and settled silently upon her (Fanny) during her (Fanny) partial sleep. Bathsheba shook her (Fanny) dress to get rid of them, when multitudes of the same family lying round about her (Fanny) rose and fluttered away in the breeze thus created, like ghosts from an enchanter fleeing.'' There was an opening towards the east, and the glow from the as yet unrisen sun attracted her (Fanny) eyes thither. From her (Fanny) feet, and between the beautiful yellowing ferns with their feathery arms, the ground sloped downwards to a hollow, in which was a species of swamp, dotted with fungi. A morning mist hung over it now -- a fulsome yet magnificent silvery veil, full of light from the sun, yet semi-opaque -- the hedge behind it being in some measure hidden by its hazy luminousness. Up the sides of this depression grew sheaves of the common rush, and here and there a peculiar species of flag, the blades of which glistened in the emerging sun, like scythes. But the general aspect of the swamp was malignant. From its moist and poisonous coat seemed to be exhaled the essences of evil things in the earth, and in the waters under the earth. The fungi grew in all manner of positions from rotting leaves and tree stumps, some exhibiting to her (its) listless gaze their clammy tops, others their oozing gills. Some were marked with great splotches, red as arterial blood, others were saffron yellow, and others tall and attenuated, with stems like macaroni. Some were leathery and of richest browns. The hollow seemed a nursery of pestilences small and great, in the immediate neighbourhood of comfort and health, and Bathsheba arose with a tremor at the thought of having passed the night on the brink of so dismal a place. ``There were now other footsteps to be heard along the road. Bathsheba's nerves were still unstrung: she (wife) crouched down out of sight again, and the pedes- trian came into view. He (priest) was a schoolboy, with a bag slung over his (priest) shoulder containing his (priest) dinner, and a hook in his (priest) hand. He (priest) paused by the gate, and, without looking up, continued murmuring words in tones quite loud enough to reach her (wife) ears.
``O Lord, O Lord, O Lord, O Lord, O Lord'' (I)
: -- that I know out o' book.
``Give us, give us, give us, give us, give us'' (I)
: -- that I know.
``Grace that, grace that, grace that, grace that'' (I)
: -- that I know.'' Other words followed to the same effect. The boy was of the dunce class apparently; the book was a psalter, and this was his (boy) way of learning the collect. In the worst attacks of trouble there appears to be always a super- ficial film of consciousness which is left disengaged and open to the notice of trifles, and Bathsheba was faintly amused at the boy's method, till he (boy) too passed on. By this time stupor had given place to anxiety, and anxiety began to make room for hunger and thirst. A form now appeared upon the rise on the other side of the swamp, half-hidden by the mist, and came towards Bathsheba. The woman -- for it was a woman -- approached with her (woman) face askance, as if looking earnestly on all sides of her (woman). When she (woman) got a little further round to the left, and drew nearer, Bathsheba could see the newcomer's profile against the sunny sky', and knew the wavy sweep from forehead to chin, with neither angle nor decisive line anywhere about it, to be the familiar contour of Liddy Smallbury. Bathsheba's heart bounded with gratitude in the thought that she (woman) was not altogether deserted, and she (woman) jumped up. ``O, Liddy!'' she (woman) said, or attempted to say; but the words had only been framed by her (woman) lips; there came no sound. She (woman) had lost her (woman) voice by exposure to the clogged atmosphere all these hours of night. ``O, ma'am! I am so glad I have found you.'' said the girl, as soon as she (girl) saw Bathsheba. ``You can't come across.'' Bathsheba said in a whisper, which she (girl) vainly endeavoured to make loud enough to reach Liddy's ears. Liddy, not knowing this, stepped down upon the swamp, saying, as she (girl) did so, ``It will bear me up, I think.'' Bathsheba never forgot that transient little picture of Liddy crossing the swamp to her (girl) there in the morning light. Iridescent bubbles of dank subter- ranean breath rose from the sweating sod beside the waiting maid's feet as she (maid) trod, hissing as they burst and expanded away to join the vapoury firmament above. Liddy did not sink, as Bathsheba had anticipated. She (maid) landed safely on the other side, and looked up at the beautiful though pale and weary face of her (maid) young mistress. ``Poor thing!
'' said Liddy, with tears in her (maid) eyes, Do hearten yourself up a little, ma'am. However did -- -- '' (unknown)
``I can't speak above a whisper -- my voice is gone for the present.'' (Bathsheba/Bathsheba Everdene/BATHSHEBA)
said Bathsheba, hurriedly.
'' I suppose the damp air from that hollow has taken it away Liddy, don't question me, mind. Who sent you -- anybody?'' (Bathsheba/Bathsheba Everdene/BATHSHEBA)
``Nobody. I thought, when I found you were not at home, that something cruel had happened. I fancy I heard his (Liddy) voice late last night; and so, knowing something was wrong -- -- '' (unknown)
``Is he (Liddy) at home?'' (unknown)
``No; he (Liddy) left just before I came out.'' (unknown)
``Is Fanny taken away?'' (unknown)
``Not yet. She (Fanny) will soon be -- at nine o'clock.'' (unknown)
``we won't go home at present, then. Suppose we walk about in this wood?'' (Liddy/Smallbury/Liddy Smallbury)
Liddy, without exactly understanding everything, or anything, in this episode, assented, and they walked together further among the trees.
``But you had better come in, ma'am, and have something to eat. You will die of a chill!'' (unknown)
``I shall not come indoors yet -- perhaps never.'' (unknown)
``Shall I get you something to eat, and something else to put over your head besides that little shawl?'' (unknown)
``If you will, Liddy.'' (Liddy/Smallbury/Liddy Smallbury)
Liddy vanished, and at the end of twenty minutes returned with a cloak, hat, some slices of bread and butter, a tea-cup, and some hot tea in a little china jug
``Is Fanny gone?'' (Liddy/Smallbury/Liddy Smallbury)
said Bathsheba.
``No.'' (companion)
said her (Bathsheba) companion, pouring out the tea. Bathsheba wrapped herself up and ate and drank sparingly. Her (Bathsheba) voice was then a little clearer, and trifling colour returned to her (Bathsheba) face.
``Now we'll walk about again.'' (she)
she (Bathsheba) said. They wandered about the wood for nearly two hours, Bathsheba replying in monosyllables to Liddy's prattle, for her (Bathsheba) mind ran on one subject, and one only. She (Bathsheba) interrupted with --
``l wonder if Fanny is gone by this time?'' (She)
``I will go and see.'' (She)
She (Bathsheba) came back with the information that the men were just taking away the corpse; that Bathsheba had been inquired for; that she (Bathsheba) had replied to the effect that her (Bathsheba) mistress was unwell and could not be seen.
``Then they think I am in my bedroom?'' (unknown)
``Yes.'' (Liddy/Smallbury/Liddy Smallbury)
Liddy then ventured to add:
'' You said when I first found you that you might never go home again -- you didn't mean it, ma'am?'' (Liddy/Smallbury/Liddy Smallbury)
``No; I've altered my mind. It is only women with no pride in them who run away from their husbands. There is one position worse than that of being found dead in your husband's house from his (husband) ill usage, and that is, to be found alive through having gone away to The house of somebody else. I've thought of it all this morning, and I've chosen my course. A runaway wife is an encumbrance to everybody, a burden to herself and a byword -- all of which make up a heap of misery greater than any that comes by staying at home -- though this may include the trifling items of insult, beating, and starvation. Liddy, if ever you marry -- God forbid that you ever should! -- you'll find yourself in a fearful situation; but mind this, don't you flinch. Stand your ground, and be cut to pieces. That's what I'm going to do.'' (unknown)
``O, mistress, don't talk so!'' (unknown)
said Liddy,-taking her (Bathsheba) hand;
``but I knew you had too much sense to bide away. May I ask what dreadful thing it is that has happened between you and him (God)?'' (unknown)
``You may ask; but I may not tell.'' (unknown)
In about ten minutes they returned to the house by a circuitous route, entering at the rear. Bathsheba glided up the back stairs to a disused attic, and her (Bathsheba) companion followed.
``Liddy.'' (she)
she (Bathsheba) said, with a lighter heart, for youth and hope had begun to reassert themselves;
