'' you are to be my confidante for the present -- somebody must be -- and I choose you. Well, I shall take up my abode here for a while. Will you get a fire lighted, put down a piece of carpet, and help me to make the place comfortable. Afterwards, I want you and Maryann to bring up that little stump bedstead in the small room, and the be belonging to it, and a table, and some other things. What shall I do to pass the heavy time away?'' (youth hope)
``Hemming handkerchiefs is a very good thing.'' (Liddy/Smallbury/Liddy Smallbury)
said Liddy.
``O no, no! I hate needlework-i always did.'' (unknown)
``knitting?'' (unknown)
``And that, too.'' (unknown)
``You might finish your sampler. Only the carna- tions and peacocks want filling in; and then it could be framed and glazed, and hung beside your aunt'' (unknown)
ma'am.'' ``Samplers are out of date -- horribly countrified. No Liddy, I'll read. Bring up some books -- not new ones. I haven't heart to read anything new.'' ``Some of your uncle's old ones, ma'am?'' ``Yes. Some of those we stowed away in boxes.'' A faint gleam of humour passed over her (Maryann) face as she (Maryann) said: ``Bring Beaumont and Fletcher's Maid's Tragedy, and the Mourning Bride, and let me see -- Night Thoughts, and the Vanity of Human Wishes.'' ``And that story of the black man, who murdered his (man) wife Desdemona? It is a nice dismal one that would suit you excellent just now.'' ``Now, Liddy, you've been looking into my book without telling me; and I said you were not to! How do you know it would suit me? It wouldn't suit me a all.'' ``But if the others do -- -- '' ``No, they don't; and I won't read dismal books. Why should I read dismal books, indeed? Bring me Love in a Village, and Maid of the Mill, and Doctor Syntax, and some volumes of the Spectator.'' All that day Bathsheba and Liddy lived in the attic in a state of barricade; a precaution which proved to be needless as against Troy, for he (Liddy) did not appear in the neighbourhood or trouble them at all. Bathsheba sat at the window till sunset, sometimes attempting to read, at other times watching every movement outside without much purpose, and listening without much interest to every sound. The sun went down almost blood-red that night, and a livid cloud received its rays in the east. Up against this dark background the west front of the church tower -- the only part of the edifice visible from the farm-house windows -- rose distinct and lustrous, the vane upon the summit bristling with rays. Hereabouts, at six o'clock, the young men of the village gathered, as was their custom, for a game of Prisoners' base. The spot had been consecrated to this ancient diversion from time immemorial, the old stocks conveniently forming a base facing the boundary of the churchyard, in front of which the ground was trodden hard and bare as a pavement by the players. She (players) could see the brown and black heads of the young lads darting about right and left, their white shirt-sleeves gleaming in the sun; whilst occasionally a shout and a peal of hearty laughter varied the stillness of the evening air. They continued playing for a quarter of an hour or so, when the game concluded abruptly, and the players leapt over the wall and vanished round to the other side behind a yew-tree, which was also half behind a beech, now spreading in one mass of golden foliage, on which the branches traced black lines. ``Why did the base-players finish their game so suddenly?'' Bathsheba inquired, the next time that Liddy entered the room. ``I think 'twas because two men came just then from Casterbridge and began putting up grand carved tombstone.'' said Liddy. ``The lads went to see whose it was.'' ``Do you know?'' Bathsheba asked.
``I don't.'' (unknown)
said Liddy.

CHAPTER XLV

TROY``S ROMANTICISM

WHEN Troy's wife had left the house at the previous midnight his (Doctor) first act was to cover the dead from sight. This done he (Doctor) ascended the stairs, and throwing himself down upon the bed dressed as he (Doctor) was, he (Doctor) waited miser- ably for the morning. Fate had dealt grimly with him (Doctor) through the last four- and-twenty hours. His (Doctor) day had been spent in a way which varied very materially from his (Doctor) intentions regard- ing it. There is always an inertia to be overcome in striking out a new line of conduct -- not more in our- selves, it seems, than in circumscribing events, which appear as if leagued together to allow no novelties in the way of amelioration. Twenty pounds having been secured from Bathsheba, he (Doctor) had managed to add to the sum every farthing he (Doctor) could muster on his (Doctor) own account, which had been seven pounds ten. With this money, twenty-seven pounds ten in all, he (Doctor) had hastily driven from the gate that morning to keep his (Doctor) appointment with Fanny Robin. On reaching Casterbridge he (Doctor) left the horse and trap at an inn, and at five minutes before ten came back to the bridge at the lower end of the town, and sat himself upon the parapet. The clocks struck the hour, and no Fanny appeared. In fact, at that moment she (Fanny) was being robed in her (Fanny) grave-clothes by two attendants at the Union poorhouse -- the first and last tiring-women the gentle creature had ever been honoured with. The quarter went, the half hour. A rush of recollection came upon Troy as he (Doctor) waited: this was the second time she (Fanny) had broken a serious engagement with him (Doctor) In anger he (Doctor) vowed it should be the last, and at eleven o'clock, when he (Doctor) had lingered and watched the stone of the bridge till he (Doctor) knew every lichen upon their face and heard the chink of the ripples underneath till they oppressed him (Doctor), he (Doctor) jumped from his (Doctor) seat, went to the inn for his (Doctor) gig, and in a bitter mood of indifference con- cerning the past, and recklessness about the future, drove on to Budmouth races. He (Doctor) reached the race-course at two o'clock, and re- mained either there or in the town till nine, But Fanny's image, as it had appeared to him (Doctor) in the sombre shadows of that Saturday evening, returned to his (Doctor) mind, backed up by Bathsheba's reproaches. He (Doctor) vowed he (Doctor) would not bet, and he (Doctor) kept his (Doctor) vow, for on leaving the town at nine o'clock in the evening he (Doctor) had diminish his (Doctor) cash only to the extent of a few shillings. He (Doctor) trotted slowly homeward, and it was now that was struck for the first time with a thought that Fanny had been really prevented by illness from keeping her (Fanny) promise. This time she (Fanny) could have made no mistake He (Doctor) regretted that he (Doctor) had not remained in Casterbridge and made inquiries. Reaching home he (Doctor) quietly un- harnessed the horse and came indoors, as we have seen, to the fearful shock that awaited him (Doctor). As soon as it grew light enough to distinguish objects, Troy arose from the coverlet of the bed, and in a mood of absolute indifference to Bathsheba's whereabouts, a almost oblivious of her (Troy) existence, he (Doctor) stalked downstairs and left the house by the back door. His (Doctor) walk was towards the churchyard, entering which he (Doctor) searched around till he (Doctor) found a newly dug unoccupied grave -- the grave dug the day before for Fanny. The position of this having been marked, he (Doctor) hastened on to Caster- bridge, only pausing whereon he (Doctor) had last seen Fanny alive. Reaching the town, Troy descended into a side street and entered a pair of gates surmounted by a board bearing the words,

``Lester, stone and marble mason.'' (Troy/Mrs. Troy)
Within were lying about stones of all sizes and designs, inscribed as being sacred to the memory of unnamed persons who had not yet died. Troy was so unlike himself now in look, word, and deed, that the want of likeness was perceptible even to his (Liddy) own consciousness. His (Liddy) method of engaging himself in this business of purchasing a tomb was that of an absolutely unpractised man. He (man) could not bring him (man)- self to consider, calculate, or economize. He (man) waywardly wished for something, and he (man) set about obtaining it like a child in a nursery.
``I want a good tomb.'' (he)
he (man) said to the man who stood in a little office within the yard.
``I want as good a one as you can give me for twenty- seven pounds,'' (he)
It was all the money he (man) possessed.
``That sum to include everything?'' (unknown)
``Everything. Cutting the name, carriage to Weather- bury, and erection. And I want it now at once .'' (unknown)
``We could not get anything special worked this week. ``If you would like one of these in stock it could be got ready immediately.'' ``Very well.'' said Troy, impatiently. ``Let's see what you have.'' ``The best I have in stock is this one,
'' said the stone- cutter, going into a shed.'' (I)
Here's a marble headstone beautifully crocketed, with medallions beneath of typical subjects; here's the footstone after the same pattern, and here's the coping to enclose the- grave. The slabs are the best of their kind, and I can warrant them ``Well, I could add the name, and put it up at visitor who wore not a shred of mourning. Troy then settled the account and went away. In the afternoon almost done. He (visitor) waited in the yard till the tomb was way to Weatherbury, giving directions to the two men the grave of the person named in the inscription. bridge. He (visitor) carried rather a heavy basket upon his (visitor) occasionally at bridges and gates, whereon he (visitor) deposited returning in the darkness, the men and the waggon the work was done, and, on being assured that it was, Troy entered Weatherbury churchyard about ten had marked the vacant grave early in the morning. It extent from the view of passers along the road -- a spot and bushes of alder, but now it was cleared and made the ground elsewhere. Here now stood the tomb as the men had stated, snow- white and shapely in the gloom, consisting of head and foot-stone, and enclosing border of marble-work uniting them. In the midst was mould, suitable for plants. Troy deposited his (midst) basket beside the tomb, and vanished for a few minutes. When he (midst) returned he (midst) carried a spade and a lantern, the light of which he (midst) directed for a few moments upon the marble, whilst he (midst) read the inscription. He (midst) hung his (midst) lantern on the lowest bough of the yew-tree, and took from his (midst) basket flower- roots of several varieties. There were bundles of snow- drop, hyacinth and crocus bulbs, violets and double daisies, which were to bloom in early spring, and of carnations, pinks, picotees, lilies of the valley, forget-me- not, summer's-farewell, meadow-saffron and others, for the later seasons of the year. Troy laid these out upon the grass, and with an im- passive face set to work to plant them. The snowdrops were arranged in a line on the outside of the coping, the remainder within the enclosure of the grave. The crocuses and hyacinths were to grow in rows; some of the summer flowers he (them) placed over her (them) head and feet, the lilies and forget-me-nots over her (them) heart. The remainder were dispersed in the spaces between these. Troy, in his (them) prostration at this time, had no percep- tion that in the futility of these romantic doings, dictated by a remorseful reaction from previous indifference, there was any element of absurdity. Deriving his (them) idiosyn- crasies from both sides of the Channel, he (them) showed at such junctures as the present the inelasticity of the Englishman, together with that blindness to the line where sentiment verges on mawkishness, characteristic of the French. lt was a cloudy, muggy, and very dark night, and the rays from Troy's lantern spread into the two old yews with a strange illuminating power, flickering, as it seemed, up to the black ceiling of cloud above. He (Englishman) felt a large drop of rain upon the back of his (Englishman) hand, and presently one came and entered one of the holes of the lantern, whereupon the candle sputtered and went out- Troy was weary and it being now not far from midnight, and the rain threatening to increase, he (Englishman) resolved to leave the finishing touches of his (Englishman) labour until the day should break. He (Englishman) groped along the wall and over the graves in the dark till he (Englishman) found himself round at the north side. Here he (Englishman) entered the porch, and, reclining upon the bench within, fell asleep.

CHAPTER XLVI

THE GURGOYLE: ITS DOINGS

THE tower of Weatherbury Church was a square erection of fourteenth-century date, having two stone gurgoyles on each of the four faces of its parapet. Of these eight carved protuberances only two at this time continued to serve the purpose of their erection -- that of spouting the water from the lead roof within. One mouth in each front had been closed by bygone church- wardens as superfluous, and two others were broken away and choked -- a matter not of much consequence to the wellbeing of the tower, for the two mouths which still remained open and active were gaping enough to do all the work. It has been sometimes argued that there is no truer criterion of the vitality of any given art-period than the power of the master-spirits of that time in grotesque; and certainly in the instance of Gothic art there is no disputing the proposition. Weatherbury tower was a somewhat early instance of the use of an ornamental parapet in parish as distinct from cathedral churches, and the gurgoyles, which are the necessary correlatives of a parapet, were exceptionally prominent -- of the boldest cut that the hand could shape, and of the most original design that a human brain could conceive. There was, so to speak, that symmetry in their distortion which is less the characteristic of British than of Continental grotesques of the period. All the eight were different from each other. A beholder was con- vinced that nothing on earth could be more hideous than those he (their) saw on the north side until he (their) went round to the south. Of the two on this latter face, only that at the south-eastern corner concerns the story. It was too human to be called like a dragon, too impish to be like a man, too animal to be like a fiend, and not enough like a bird to be called a griffin. This horrible stone entity was fashioned as if covered with a wrinkled hide; it had short, erect ears, eyes starting from their sockets, and its fingers and hands were seizing the corners of its mouth, which they thus seemed to pull open to give free passage to the water it vomited. The lower row of teeth was quite washed away, though the upper still remained. Here and thus, jutting a couple of feet from the wall against which its feet rested as a support, the creature had for four hundred years laughed at the surrounding landscape, voicelessly in dry weather, and in wet with a gurgling and snorting sound. Troy slept on in the porch, and the rain increased outside. Presently the gurgoyle spat. In due time a small stream began to trickle through the seventy feet of aerial space between its mouth and the ground, which the water-drops smote like duckshot in their accelerated velocity. The stream thickened in substance, and in- creased in power, gradually spouting further and yet further from the side of the tower. When the rain fell in a steady and ceaseless torrent the stream dashed downward in volumes. We follow its course to the ground at this point of time. The end of the liquid parabola has come forward from the wall, has advanced over the plinth mouldings, over a heap of stones, over the marble border, into the midst of Fanny Robin's grave. The force of the stream had, until very lately, been received upon some loose stones spread thereabout, which had acted as a shield to the soil under the onset. These during the summer had been cleared from the ground, and there was now nothing to resist the down- fall but the bare earth. For several years the stream had not spouted so far from the tower as it was doing on this night, and such a contingency had been over- looked. Sometimes this obscure corner received no inhabitant for the space of two or three years, and then it was usually but a pauper, a poacher, or other sinner of undignified sins. The persistent torrent from the gurgoyle's jaws directed all its vengeance into the grave. The rich tawny mould was stirred into motion, and boiled like chocolate. The water accumulated and washed deeper down, and the roar of the pool thus formed spread into the night as the head and chief among other noises of the kind created by the deluging rain. The flowers so carefully planted by Fanny's repentant lover began to move and writhe in their bed. The winter-violets turned slowly upside down, and became a mere mat of mud. Soon the snowdrop and other bulbs danced in the boiling mass like ingredients in a cauldron. Plants of the tufted species were loosened, rose to the surface, and floated of. Troy did not awake from his (lover) comfortless sleep till it was broad day. Not having been in bed for two nights his (lover) shoulders felt stiff his (lover) feet tender, and his (lover) head heavy. He (lover) remembered his (lover) position, arose, shivered, took the spade, and again went out. The rain had quite ceased, and the sun was shining through the green, brown, and yellow leaves, now sparkling and varnished by the raindrops to the bright- ness of similar effects in the landscapes of Ruysdael and Hobbema, and full of all those infinite beauties that arise from the union of water and colour with high lights. The air was rendered so transparent by the heavy fall of rain that the autumn hues of the middle distance were as rich as those near at hand, and the remote fields intercepted by the angle of the tower ap- peared in the same plane as the tower itself. He (itself) entered the gravel path which would take him (itself) behind the tower. The path, instead of being stony as it had been the night before, was browned over with a thin coating of mud. At one place in the path he (itself) saw a tuft of stringy roots washed white and clean as a bundle of tendons. He (itself) picked it up -- surely it could not be one of the primroses he (itself) had planted? He (itself) saw a bulb, another, and another as he (itself) advanced. Beyond doubt they were the crocuses. With a face of perplexed dismay Troy turned the corner and then beheld the wreck the stream had made. The pool upon the grave had soaked away into the ground, and in its place was a hollow. The disturbed earth was washed over the grass and pathway in the guise of the brown mud he (itself) had already seen, and it spotted the marble tombstone with the same stains. Nearly all the flowers were washed clean out of the ground, and they lay, roots upwards, on the spots whither they had been splashed by the stream. Troy's brow became heavily contracted. He (itself) set his (itself) teeth closely, and his (itself) compressed lips moved as those of one in great pain. This singular accident, by a strange confluence of emotions in him (itself), was felt as the sharpest sting of all. Troy's face was very expressive, and any observer who had seen him (itself) now would hardly have believed him (itself) to be a man who had laughed, and sung, and poured love-trifles into a woman's ear. To curse his (itself) miserable lot was at first his (itself) impulse, but even that lowest stage of rebellion needed an activity whose absence was necessarily antecedent to the existence of the morbid misery which wrung him (itself). The sight, coming as it did, superimposed upon the other dark scenery of the previous days, formed a sort of climax to the whole panorama, and it was more than he (itself) could endure. Sanguine by nature, Troy had a power of eluding grief by simply adjourning it. He (itself) could put off the consideration of any particular spectre till the matter had become old and softened by time. The planting of flowers on Fanny's grave had been perhaps but a species of elusion of the primary grief, and now it was as if his (itself) intention had been known and circumvented. Almost for the first time in his (itself) life, Troy, as he (itself) stood by this dismantled grave, wished himself another man. lt is seldom that a person with much animal spirit does not feel that the fact of his (itself) life being his (itself) own is the one qualification which singles it out as a more hopeful life than that of others who may actually resemble him (itself) in every particular. Troy had felt, in his (itself) transient way, hundreds of times, that he (itself) could not envy other people their condition, because the possession of that condition would have necessitated a different personality, when he (itself) desired no other than his (itself) own. He (itself) had not minded the peculiarities of his (itself) birth, the vicissitudes of his (itself) life, the meteorlike uncertainty of all that related to him (itself), because these appertained to the hero of his (hero) story, without whom there would have been no story at all for him (hero); and it seemed to be only in the nature of things that matters would right themselves at some proper date and wind up well. This very morning the illusion completed its disappearance, and, as it were, all of a sudden, Troy hated himself. The suddenness was probably more apparent than real. A coral reef which just comes short of the ocean surface is no more to the horizon than if it had never been begun, and the mere finishing stroke is what often appears to create an event which has long been potentially an accomplished thing. He (himself) stood and mediated -- a miserable man. Whither should he (himself) go?

'' He (man) that is accursed, let him (man) be accursed still.'' (he)
was the pitiless anathema written in this spoliated effort of his (man) new-born solicitousness. A man who has spent his (man) primal strength in journeying in one direction has not much spirit left for reversing his (man) course. Troy had, since yesterday, faintly reversed his (man); but the merest opposition had disheartened him (man). To turn about would have been hard enough under the greatest providential encouragement; but to find that Providence, far from helping him (man) into a new course, or showing any wish that he (man) might adopt one, actually jeered his (man) first trembling and critical attempt in that kind, was more than nature could bear. He (man) slowly withdrew from the grave. He (man) did not attempt to fill up the hole, replace the flowers, or do anything at all. He (man) simply threw up his (man) cards and forswore his (man) game for that time and always. Going out of the churchyard silently and unobserved -- none of the villagers having yet risen -- he (man) passed down some fields at the back, and emerged just as secretly upon the high road. Shortly afterwards he (man) had gone from the village. Meanwhile, Bathsheba remained a voluntary prisoner in the attic. The door was kept locked, except during the entries and exits of Liddy, for whom a bed had been arranged in a small adjoining room. The light of Troy's lantern in the churchyard was noticed about ten o'clock by the maid-servant, who casually glanced from the window in that direction whilst taking her (Liddy) supper, and she (Liddy) called Bathsheba's attention to it. They looked curiously at the phenomenon for a time, until Liddy was sent to bed. bathsheba did not sleep very heavily that night. When her (Liddy) attendant was unconscious and softly breath- ing in the next room, the mistress of the house was still looking out of the window at the faint gleam spreading from among the trees -- not in a steady shine, but blinking like a revolving coastlight, though this appearance failed to suggest to her (mistress) that a person was passing and repassing in front of it. Bathsheba sat here till it began to rain, and the light vanished, when she (mistress) withdrew to lie restlessly in her (mistress) bed and re-enact in a worn mind the lurid scene of yesternight. Almost before the first faint sign of dawn appeared she (mistress) arose again, and opened the window to obtain a full breathing of the new morning air, the panes being now wet with trembling tears left by the night rain, each one rounded with a pale lustre caught from primrose- hued slashes through a cloud low down in the awaken- ing sky. From the trees came the sound of steady dripping upon the drifted leaves under them, and from the direction of the church she (mistress) could hear another noise -- peculiar, and not intermittent like the rest, the purl of water falling into a pool. Liddy knocked at eight o'clock, and Bathsheba un- locked the door.
``What a heavy rain we've had in the night, ma'am!'' (Liddy/Smallbury/Liddy Smallbury)
said Liddy, when her (mistress) inquiries about breakfast had been made.
``Yes, very heavy.'' (unknown)
``Did you hear the strange noise from the church yard?'' (unknown)
``I heard one strange noise. I've been thinking it must have been the water from the tower spouts.'' (unknown)
``Well, that's what the shepherd was saying, ma'am. He (shepherd)'s now gone on to see.'' (unknown)
``Oh! Gabriel has been here this morning!'' (unknown)
``Only just looked in in passing -- quite in his (Gabriel) old way, which I thought he (Gabriel) had left off lately. But the tower spouts used to spatter on the stones, and we are puzzled, for this was like the boiling of a pot.'' (Bathsheba)
Not being able to read, think, or work, Bathsheba asked Liddy to stay and breakfast with her (mistress). The tongue of the more childish woman still ran upon recent events.
``Are you going across to the church, ma'am?'' (she)
she (woman) asked.
``Not that I know of.'' (Bathsheba/Bathsheba Everdene/BATHSHEBA)
said Bathsheba.
``I thought you might like to go and see where they have put Fanny. The trees hide the place from your window.'' (Bathsheba/Bathsheba Everdene/BATHSHEBA)
Bathsheba had all sorts of dreads about meeting her (woman) husband.
``Has Mr. Troy been in to-night?'' (she)
she (woman) said ``No, ma'am; I think he (Troy)'s gone to Budmouth. Budmouth! The sound of the word carried with it a much diminished perspective of him (Troy) and his (Troy) deeds; there were thirteen miles interval betwixt them now. She (Fanny) hated questioning Liddy about her (Fanny) husband's movements, and indeed had hitherto sedulously avoided doing so; but now all the house knew that there had been some dreadful disagreement between them, and it was futile to attempt disguise. Bathsheba had reached a stage at which people cease to have any appreciative regard for public opinion. ``What makes you think he (Liddy) has gone there?'' she (woman) said. ``Laban Tall saw him (Liddy) on the Budmouth road this morning before breakfast.'' Bathsheba was momentarily relieved of that wayward heaviness of the past twenty-four hours which had quenched the vitality of youth in her (woman) without sub- stituting the philosophy of maturer years, and the resolved to go out and walk a little way. So when breakfast was over, she (woman) put on her (woman) bonnet, and took a direction towards the church. It was nine o'clock, and the men having returned to work again from their first meal, she (woman) was not likely to meet many of them in the road. Knowing that Fanny had been laid in the reprobates' quarter of the graveyard, called in the parish ``behind church.'' which was invisible from the road, it was impossible to resist the impulse to enter and look upon a spot which, from nameless feelings, she (Fanny) at the same time dreaded to see. She (Fanny) had been unable to overcome an impression that some connection existed between her (Fanny) rival and the light through the trees. Bathsheba skirted the buttress, and beheld the hole and the tomb, its delicately veined surface splashed and stained just as Troy had seen it and left it two hours earlier. On the other side of the scene stood Gabriel. His (Gabriel) eyes, too, were fixed on the tomb, and her (Troy) arrival having been noiseless, she (Troy) had not as yet attracted his (Gabriel) attention. Bathsheba did not at once perceive that the grand tomb and the disturbed grave were Fanny's, and she (Fanny) looked on both sides and around for some humbler mound, earthed up and clodded in the usual way. Then her (Fanny) eye followed Oak's, and she (Fanny) read the words with which the inscription opened: --
``Erected by Francis Troy in Beloved Memory of Fanny Robin.'' (unknown)
Oak saw her (Fanny), and his (Oak) first act was to gaze inquiringly and learn how she (Fanny) received this knowledge of the authorship of the work, which to himself had caused considerable astonishment. But such discoveries did not much affect her (Fanny) now. Emotional convulsions seemed to have become the commonplaces of her (Fanny) history, and she (Fanny) bade him (Oak) good morning, and asked him (Oak) to fill in the hole with the spade which was standing by. Whilst Oak was doing as she (Fanny) desired, Bathsheba collected the flowers, and began planting them with that sympathetic manipulation of roots and leaves which is so conspicuous in a woman's gardening, and which flowers seem to understand and thrive upon. She (woman) requested Oak to get the churchwardens to turn the leadwork at the mouth of the gurgoyle that hung gaping down upon them, that by this means the stream might be directed sideways, and a repetition of the accident prevented. Finally, with the superfluous magnanimity of a woman whose narrower instincts have brought down bitterness upon her (woman) instead of love, she (woman) wiped the mud spots from the tomb as if she (woman) rather liked its words than otherwise,

CHAPTER XLVII

ADVENTURES BY THE SHORE

TROY wandered along towards the south. A composite feeling, made up of disgust with the, to him (churchwardens), humdrum tediousness of a farmer's life, gloomily images of her (woman) who lay in the churchyard, remorse, and a general averseness to his (churchwardens) wife's society, impelled him (churchwardens) to seek a home in any place on earth save Weatherbury. The sad accessories of Fanny's end confronted him (churchwardens) as vivid pictures which threatened to be indelible, and made life in Bathsheba's house intolerable. At three in the afternoon he (churchwardens) found himself at the foot of a slope more than a mile in length, which ran to the ridge of a range of hills lying parallel with the shore, and forming a monotonous barrier between the basin of cultivated country inland and the wilder scenery of the coast. Up the hill stretched a road nearly straight and perfectly white, the two sides approaching each other in a gradual taper till they met the sky at the top about two miles off. Through- out the length of this narrow and irksome inclined plane not a sign of life was visible on this garish afternoon Troy toiled up the road with a languor and depression greater than any he (they) had experienced for many a day and year before. The air was warm and muggy, and the top seemed to recede as he (they) approached. At last he (they) reached the summit, and a wide and novel prospect burst upon him (they) with an effect almost like that of the Pacific upon Balboa's gaze. The broad steely sea, marked only by faint lines, which had a semblance of being etched thereon to a degree not deep enough to disturb its general evenness, stretched the whole width of his (they) front and round to the right, where, near the town and port of Budmouth, the sun bristled down upon it, and banished all colour, to substitute in its place a clear oily polish. Nothing moved in sky, land, or sea, except a frill of milkwhite foam along the nearer angles of the shore, shreds of which licked the contiguous stones like tongues. He (they) descended and came to a small basin of sea enclosed by the cliffs. Troy's nature freshened within him (they); he (they) thought he (they) would rest and bathe here before going farther. He (they) undressed and plunged in. Inside the cove the water was uninteresting to a swimmer, being smooth as a pond, and to get a little of the ocean swell, Troy presently swam between the two projecting spurs of rock which formed the pillars of Hercules to this miniature Mediterranean. Unfortunately for Troy a current unknown to him (Hercules) existed outside, which, un- important to craft of any burden, was awkward for a swimmer who might be taken in it unawares. Troy found himself carried to the left and then round in a swoop out to sea. He (swimmer) now recollected the place and its sinister character. Many bathers had there prayed for a dry death from time to time, and, like Gonzalo also, had been unanswered; and Troy began to deem it possible that he (Gonzalo) might be added to their number. Not a boat of any kind was at present within sight, but far in the distance Budmouth lay upon the sea, as it were quietly regarding his (Gonzalo) efforts, and beside the town the harbour showed its position by a dim meshwork of ropes and spars. After wellnigh exhausting himself in attempts to get back to the mouth of the cove, in his (Gonzalo) weakness swimming several inches deeper than was his (Gonzalo) wont, keeping up his (Gonzalo) breathing entirely by his (Gonzalo) nostrils, turning upon his (Gonzalo) back a dozen times over, swimming EN PAPILLON and so on, Troy resolved as a last resource to tread water at a slight incline, and so endeavour to reach the shore at any point, merely giving himself a gentle impetus inwards whilst carried on in the general direc- tion of the tide. This, necessarily a slow process, he (Gonzalo) found to be not altogether so difficult, and though there was no choice of a landing-place -- the objects on shore passing by him (Gonzalo) in a sad and slow procession -- he (Gonzalo) per- ceptibly approached the extremity of a spit of land yet further to the right, now well defined against the sunny portion of the horizon. While the swimmer's eye's were fixed upon the spit as his (swimmer) only means of salvation on this side of the Unknown, a moving object broke the outline of the extremity, and immediately a ship's boat appeared manned with several sailor lads, her (Gonzalo) bows towards the sea. All Troy's vigour spasmodically revived to prolong the struggle yet a little further. Swimming with his (sailor) right arm, he (sailor) held up his (sailor) left to hail them, splashing upon the waves, and shouting with all his (sailor) might. From the position of the setting sun his (sailor) white form was distinctly visible upon the now deep-hued bosom of the sea to the east of the boat, and the men saw him (sailor) at once. Backing their oars and putting the boat about, they pulled towards him (sailor) with a will, and in five or six minutes from the time of his (sailor) first halloo, two of the sailors hauled him (sailor) in over the stern. They formed part of a brig's crew, and had come ashore for sand. Lending him (sailor) what little clothing they could spare among them as a slight protection against late they made again towards the roadstead where their And now night drooped slowly upon the wide watery levels in front; and at no great distance from them, where the shoreline curved round, and formed a long riband of shade upon the horizon, a series of points of yellow light began to start into existence, denoting the spot to be the site of Budmouth, where the lamps were being lighted along the parade. The cluck of their oars was the only sound of any distinctness upon the sea, and as they laboured amid the thickening shades the lamplights grew larger, each appearing to send a flaming sword deep down into the waves before it, until there arose, among other dim shapes of the kind, the form of the vessel for which they were bound.

CHAPTER XLVIII

DOUBTS ARISE -- DOUBTS LINGER

BATHSHEBA underwent the enlargement of her (they) Husband's absence from hours to days with a slight feeling of surprise, and a slight feeling of relief; yet neither sensation rose at any time far above the level commonly designated as indifference. She (they) belonged to him (Husband): the certainties of that position were so well defined, and the reasonable probabilities of its issue so bounded that she (they) could not speculate on contingencies. Taking no further interest in herself as a splendid woman, she (woman) acquired the indifferent feelings of an outsider in contem- plating her (woman) probable fate as a singular wretch; for Bath- sheba drew herself and her (woman) future in colours that no reality could exceed for darkness. Her (woman) original vigorous pride of youth had sickened, and with it had declined all her (woman) anxieties about coming years, since anxiety recognizes a better and a worse alternative, and Bath- sheba had made up her (woman) mind that alternatives on any noteworthy scale had ceased for her (woman). Soon, or later -- and that not very late -- her (woman) husband would be home again. And then the days of their tenancy of the Upper Farm would be numbered. There had origin- ally been shown by the agent to the estate some distrust of Bathsheba's tenure as James Everdene's successor, on the score of her (woman) sex, and her (woman) youth, and her (woman) beauty; but the peculiar nature of her (woman) uncle's will, his (uncle) own frequent testimony before his (uncle) death to her (woman) cleverness in such a pursuit, and her (woman) vigorous marshalling of the numerous flocks and herds which came suddenly into her (woman) hands before negotiations were concluded, had won confidence in her (woman) powers, and no further objections had been raised. She (woman) had latterly been in great doubt as to what the legal effects of her (woman) marriage would be upon her (woman) position; but no notice had been taken as yet of her (woman) change of name, and only one point was clear -- that in the event of her (woman) own or her (woman) husband's inability to meet the agent at the forthcoming January rent-day, very little consideration would be shown, and, for that matter, very little would be deserved. Once out of the farm, the approach of poverty would be sure. Hence Bathsheba lived in a perception that her (woman) purposes were broken of. She (woman) was not a woman who could hope on without good materials for the process, differing thus from the less far-Sighted and energetic, though more petted ones of the sex, with whom hope goes on as a sort of clockwork which the merest food and shelter are sufficient to wind up; and perceiving clearly that her (woman) mistake had been a fatal one, she (woman) accepted her (woman) position, and waited coldly for the end. The first Saturday after Troy's departure she (woman) went to Casterbridge alone, a journey she (woman) had not before taken since her (woman) marriage. On this Saturday Bathsheba was passing slowly on foot through the crowd of rural business-men gathered as usual in front of the market- house, who were as usual gazed upon by the burghers with feelings that those healthy lives were dearly paid for by exclusion from possible aldermanship, when a man, who had apparently been following her (woman), said some words to another on her (woman) left hand. Bathsheba's ears were keen as those of any wild animal, and she (woman) dis- tinctly heard what the speaker said, though her (woman) back was towards him (speaker)

``I am looking for Mrs. Troy. Is that she (Robin) there?'' (him)
``Yes; that's the young lady, I believe.'' (the person)
said the the person addressed.
``I have some awkward news to break to her (Robin). Her (Robin) husband is drowned.'' (Bathsheba/Bathsheba Everdene/BATHSHEBA)
As if endowed with the spirit of prophecy, Bathsheba gasped out,
``No, it is not true; it cannot be true!'' (Bathsheba/Bathsheba Everdene/BATHSHEBA)
Then she (woman) said and heard no more. The ice of self- command which had latterly gathered over her (woman) was broken, and the currents burst forth again, and over whelmed her (woman). A darkness came into her (woman) eyes, and she (woman) fell. But not to the ground. A gloomy man, who had been observing her (woman) from under the portico of the old corn-exchange when she (woman) passed through the group without, stepped quickly to her (woman) side at the moment of her (woman) exclamation, and caught her (woman) in his (man) arms as she (woman) sank down.
``What is it?'' (Boldwood/Mr. Boldwood/BOLDWOOD)
said Boldwood, looking up at the bringer of the big news, as he (Boldwood) supported her (woman).
``Her (Robin) husband was drowned this week while bathing in Lulwind Cove. A coastguardsman found his (husband) clothes, and brought them into Budmouth yesterday.'' (Boldwood/Mr. Boldwood/BOLDWOOD)
Thereupon a strange fire lighted up Boldwood's eye, and his (Boldwood) face flushed with the suppressed excitement of an unutterable thought. Everybody's glance was now centred upon him (Boldwood) and the unconscious Bathsheba. He (Boldwood) lifted her (woman) bodily off the ground, and smoothed down the folds of her (woman) dress as a child might have taken a storm-beaten bird and arranged its ruffled plumes, and bore her (woman) along the pavement to the King's Arms Inn. Here he (King) passed with her (woman) under the archway into a private room; and by the time he (King) had deposited -- so lothly -- the precious burden upon a sofa, Bathsheba had opened her (woman) eyes. Remembering all that had occurred, she (woman) murmured,
``I want to go home!'' (she)
Boldwood left the room. He (Boldwood) stood for a moment in the passage to recover his (Boldwood) senses. The experience had been too much for his (Boldwood) consciousness to keep up with, and now that he (Boldwood) had grasped it it had gone again. For those few heavenly, golden moments she (woman) had been in his (Boldwood) arms. What did it matter about her (woman) not knowing it? She (woman) had been close to his (Boldwood) breast; he (Boldwood) had been close to hers. He (Boldwood) started onward again, and sending a woman to her (woman), went out to ascertain all the facts of the case. These appeared to be limited to what he (Boldwood) had already heard. He (Boldwood) then ordered her (woman) horse to be put into the gig, and when all was ready returned to inform her (woman). He (Boldwood) found that, though still pale and unwell, she (woman) had in the meantime sent for the Budmouth man who brought the tidings, and learnt from him (man) all there was to know. Being hardly in a condition to drive home as she (woman) had driven to town, Boldwood, with every delicacy of manner and feeling, offered to get her (woman) a driver, or to give her (woman) a seat in his (driver) phaeton, which was more com- fortable than her (woman) own conveyance. These proposals Bathsheba gently declined, and the farmer at once de- parted. About half-an-hour later she (woman) invigorated herself by an effort, and took her (woman) seat and the reins as usual-in external appearance much as if nothing had happened. She (woman) went out of the town by a tortuous back street, and drove slowly along, unconscious of the road and the scene. The first shades of evening were showing them- selves when Bathsheba reached home, where, silently alighting and leaving the horse in the hands of the boy, she (woman) proceeded at once upstairs. Liddy met her (woman) on the landing. The news had preceded Bathsheba to Weather- bury by half-an-hour, and Liddy looked inquiringly into her (woman) mistress's face. Bathsheba had nothing to say. She (woman) entered her (woman) bedroom and sat by the window, and thought and thought till night enveloped her (woman), and the extreme lines only of her (woman) shape were visible. Somebody came to the door, knocked, and opened it.
``Well, what is it, Liddy?'' (she)
she (woman) said.
``I was thinking there must be something got for you to wear.'' (Liddy/Smallbury/Liddy Smallbury)
said Liddy, with hesitation.
``What do you mean?'' (unknown)
``Mourning.'' (unknown)
``No, no, no.'' (Bathsheba/Bathsheba Everdene/BATHSHEBA)
said Bathsheba, hurriedly.
``But I suppose there must be something done for poor -- -- '' (unknown)
``Not at present, I think. It is not necessary.'' (unknown)
``Why not, ma'am?'' (unknown)
``Because he (Liddy)'s still alive.'' (unknown)
``How do you know that?'' (Liddy/Smallbury/Liddy Smallbury)
said Liddy, amazed.
``I don't know it. But wouldn't it have been different, or shouldn't I have heard more, or wouldn't they have found him (Liddy), Liddy? -- or-i don't know how it is, but death would have been different from how this is. I am perfectly convinced that he (Liddy) is still alive!'' (Bathsheba)
Bathsheba remained firm in this opinion till Monday, when two circumstances conjoined to shake it. The first was a short paragraph in the local newspaper, which, beyond making by a methodizing pen formidable pre- sumptive evidence of Troy's death by drowning, con- tained the important testimony of a young Mr. Barker, M.D., of Budmouth, who spoke to being an eyewitness of the accident, in a letter to the editor. In this he (editor) stated that he (editor) was passing over the cliff on the remoter side of the cove just as the sun was setting. At that time he (editor) saw a bather carried along in the current outside the mouth of the cove, and guessed in an instant that there was but a poor chance for him (editor) unless he (editor) should be possessed of unusual muscular powers. He (editor) drifted behind a projection of the coast, and Mr. Barker followed along the shore in the same direction. But by the time that he (Barker) could reach an elevation sufficiently great to command a view of the sea beyond, dusk had set in, and nothing further was to be seen. The other circumstance was the arrival of his (Barker) clothes, when it became necessary for her (editor) to examine and identify them -- though this had virtually been done long before by those who inspected the letters in his (Barker) pockets. It was so evident to her (editor) in the midst of her (editor) agitation that Troy had undressed in the full conviction of dressing again almost immediately, that the notion that anything but death could have prevented him (Barker) was a perverse one to entertain. Then Bathsheba said to herself that others were assured in their opinion; strange that she (Troy) should not be. A strange reflection occurred to her (Troy), causing her (Troy) face to flush. Suppose that Troy had followed Fanny into another world. Had he (Barker) done this intentionally, yet contrived to make his (Barker) death appear like an accident? Nevertheless, this thought of how the apparent might differ from the real-made vivid by her (Troy) bygone jealousy of Fanny, and the remorse he (Barker) had shown that night -- did not blind her (Troy) to the perception of a likelier difference, less tragic, but to herself far more disastrous. When alone late that evening beside a small fire, and much calmed down, Bathsheba took Troy's watch into her (Troy) hand, which had been restored to her (Troy) with the rest of the articles belonging to him (Barker). She (Troy) opened the case as he (Barker) had opened it before her (Troy) a week ago. There was the little coil of pale hair which had been as the fuze to this great explosion.
``He (Liddy) was hers and she (they) was his (Liddy); they should be gone together.'' (she)
she (Troy) said.
``I am nothing to either of them, and why should I keep her (they) hair?'' (She)
She (Troy) took it in her (Troy) hand, and held it over the fire.
'' No-i'll not burn it -i'll keep it in memory of her (Troy), poor thing!'' (She)
she (Troy) added, snatching back her (Troy) hand.

CHAPTER XLIX

OAK``S ADVANCEMENT -- A GREAT HOPE

THE later autumn and the winter drew on apace, and the leaves lay thick upon the turf of the glades and the mosses of the woods. Bathsheba, having previously been living in a state of suspended feeling which was not suspense, now lived in a mood of quietude which was not precisely peacefulness. While she (they) had known him (Liddy) to be alive she (they) could have thought of his (Liddy) death with equanimity; but now that it might be she (they) had lost him (Liddy), she (they) regretted that he (Liddy) was not hers still. She (they) kept the farm going, raked in her (they) profits without caring keenly about them, and expended money on ventures because she (they) had done so in bygone days, which, though not long gone by, seemed infinitely removed from her (they) present. She (they) looked back upon that past over a great gulf, as if she (they) were now a dead person, having the faculty of meditation still left in her (they), by means of which, like the mouldering gentlefolk of the poet's story, she (they) could sit and ponder what a gift life used to be. However, one excellent result of her (they) general apathy was the long-delayed installation of Oak as bailiff; but he (bailiff) having virtually exercised that function for a long time already, the change, beyond the substantial in- crease of wages it brought, was little more than a nominal one addressed to the outside world. Boldwood lived secluded and inactive. Much of his (Boldwood) wheat and all his (Boldwood) barley of that season had been spoilt by the rain. It sprouted, grew into intricate mats, and was ultimately thrown to the pigs in armfuls. The strange neglect which had produced this ruin and waste became the subject of whispered talk among all the people round; and it was elicited from one of Boldwood's men that forgetfulness had nothing to do with it, for he (Boldwood) had been reminded of the danger to his (Boldwood) corn as many times and as persistently as inferiors dared to do. The sight of the pigs turning in disgust from the rotten ears seemed to arouse Boldwood, and he (Boldwood) one evening sent for Oak. Whether it was sug- gested by Bathsheba's recent act of promotion or not, the farmer proposed at the interview that Gabriel should undertake the superintendence of the Lower Farm as well as of Bathsheba's, because of the necessity Boldwood felt for such aid, and the impossibility of discovering a more trustworthy man. Gabriel's malig- nant star was assuredly setting fast. Bathsheba, when she (it) learnt of this proposal-for Oak was obliged to consult her (it) -- at first languidly objected. She (it) considered that the two farms together were too extensive for the observation of one man. Boldwood, who was apparently determined by personal rather than commercial reasons, suggested that Oak should be furnished with a horse for his (Boldwood) sole use, when the plan would present no difficulty, the two farms lying side by side. Boldwood did not directly communicate with her (it) during these negotiations, only speaking to Oak, who was the go-between throughout. All was harmoniously arranged at last, and we now see Oak mounted on a strong cob, and daily trotting the length breadth of about two thousand acres in a cheerful spirit of surveillance, as if the crops belonged to him (Oak) -- the actual mistress of the one-half and the master of the other, sitting in their respective homes in gloomy and sad seclusion. Out of this there arose, during the spring succeeding, a talk in the parish that Gabriel Oak was feathering his (Oak) nest fast.

``Whatever d'ye think.'' (Susan Tall/Susan/Tall)
said Susan Tall,
'' Gable Oak is coming it quite the dand. He (Gable) now wears shining boots with hardly a hob in 'em, two or three times a-week, and a tall hat a-Sundays, and 'a hardly knows the name of smockfrock. When I see people strut enough to he (Gable) cut up into bantam cocks, I stand dormant with wonder, and says no more!'' (Susan Tall/Susan/Tall)
It was eventually known that Gabriel, though paid a fixed wage by Bathsheba independent of the fluctua- tions of agricultural profits, had made an engagement with Boldwood by which Oak was to receive a share of the receipts -- a small share certainly, yet it was money of a higher quality than mere wages, and capable of expansion in a way that wages were not. Some were beginning to consider Oak a
``near'' (Oak a man)
man, for though his (man) condition had thus far improved, he (man) lived in no better style than before, occupying the same cottage, paring his (man) own potatoes, mending his (man) stockings, and sometimes even making his (man) bed with his (man) own hands. But as Oak was not only provokingly indifferent to public opinion, but a man who clung persistently to old habits and usages, simply because they were old, there was room for doubt as to his (Oak) motives. A great hope had latterly germinated in Boldwood, whose unreasoning devotion to Bathsheba could only be characterized as a fond madness which neither time nor circumstance, evil nor good report, could weaken or destroy. This fevered hope had grown up again like a grain of mustard-seed during the quiet which followed the hasty conjecture that Troy was drowned. He (Oak) nourished it fearfully, and almost shunned the contemplation of it in earnest, lest facts should reveal the wildness of the dream. Bathsheba having at last been persuaded to wear mourning, her (Oak) appearance as she (Oak) entered the church in that guise was in itself a weekly addition to his (Oak) faith that a time was coming -- very far off perhaps, yet surely nearing -- when his (Oak) waiting on events should have its reward. How long he (Oak) might have to wait he (Oak) had not yet closely considered. what he (Oak) would try to recognize was that the severe schooling she (Oak) had been subjected to had made Bathsheba much more con- siderate than she (Oak) had formerly been of the feelings of others, and he (Oak) trusted that, should she (Oak) be willing at any time in the future to marry any man at all, that man would be himself. There was a substratum of good feeling in her (Oak): her (Oak) self-reproach for the injury she (Oak) had thoughtlessly done him (man) might be depended upon now to a much greater extent than before her (Oak) infatuation and disappointment. It would be possible to approach her (Oak) by the channel of her (Oak) good nature, and to suggest a friendly businesslike compact between them for fulfilment at some future day, keeping the passionate side of his (man) desire entirely out of her (Oak) sight. Such was Boldwood's hope. To the eyes of the middle-aged, Bathsheba was perhaps additionally charming just now. Her (Oak) exuber- ance of spirit was pruned down; the original phantom of delight had shown herself to be not too bright for human nature's daily food, and she (Oak) had been able to enter this second poetical phase without losing much of the first in the process. Bathsheba's return from a two months' visit to her (Oak) old aunt at Norcombe afforded the impassioned and yearning farmer a pretext for inquiring directly after her (Oak) -- now possibly in the ninth month of her (Oak) widowhood -- and endeavouring to get a notion of her (Oak) middle of the haymaking, and Boldwood contrived to
``I am glad to see you out of doors, Lydia.'' (Boldwood/Mr. Boldwood/BOLDWOOD)
he (Boldwood) said She (Oak) simpered, and wondered in her (Oak) heart why he (Boldwood) ``I hope Mrs. Troy is quite well after her (Lydia) long the coldest-hearted neighbour could scarcely say less ``She (Lydia) is quite well, sir. ``Yes, cheerful. ``Fearful, did you say?'' ``O no. I merely said she (Lydia) was cheerful.'' ``Tells you all her (Lydia) affairs?'' ``No, sir.
``Some of them?'' (unknown)
``Yes, sir. ``Mrs Troy puts much confidence in you, Lydia, and very wisely, perhaps.'' ``She (Lydia) do, sir. I've been with her (Lydia) all through her (Lydia) troubles, and was with her (Lydia) at the time of Mr. Troy's going and all. And if she (Lydia) were to marry again I expect I should bide with her (Lydia).'' ``She (Lydia) promises that you shall -- quite natural.'' said the strategic lover, throbbing throughout him (Boldwood) at the presumption which Liddy's words appeared to warrant -- that his (Liddy) darling had thought of re-marriage. ``No -- she (Lydia) doesn't promise it exactly. I merely judge on my own account.
``Yes, yes, I understand. When she (Lydia) alludes to the possibility of marrying again, you conclude -- -- '' (unknown)
``She (Lydia) never do allude to it, sir.'' (Liddy/Smallbury/Liddy Smallbury)
said Liddy, thinking how very stupid Mr. Boldwood was getting.
``Of course not.'' (he)
he (Boldwood) returned hastily, his (Boldwood) hope falling again.
'' You needn't take quite such long reaches with your rake, Lydia -- short and quick ones are best. Well, perhaps, as she (Lydia) is absolute mistress again now, it is wise of her (Lydia) to resolve never to give up her (Lydia) freedom.'' (he)
``My mistress did certainly once say, though not seriously, that she (mistress) supposed she (mistress) might marry again at the end of seven years from last year, if she (mistress) cared to risk Mr. Troy's coming back and claiming her (mistress).'' (unknown)
``Ah, six years from the present time. Said that she (mistress) might. She (mistress) might marry at once in every reasonable person's opinion, whatever the lawyers may say to the contrary.'' (unknown)
``Have you been to ask them?'' (Liddy/Smallbury/Liddy Smallbury)
said Liddy, innocently.
``Not I.'' (Boldwood/Mr. Boldwood/BOLDWOOD)
said Boldwood, growing red.
'' Liddy, you needn't stay here a minute later than you wish, so Mr, Oak says. I am now going on a little farther. Good'' (Boldwood/Mr. Boldwood/BOLDWOOD)
afternoon.'' He (Mr) went away vexed with himself, and ashamed of having for this one time in his (Mr) life done anything which could be called underhand. Poor Boldwood had no more skill in finesse than a battering-ram, and he (Boldwood) was uneasy with a sense of having made himself to appear stupid and, what was worse, mean. But he (Boldwood) had, after all, lighted upon one fact by way of repayment. It was a singularly fresh and fascinating fact, and though not without its sadness it was pertinent and real. In little more than six years from this time Bathsheba might certainly marry him (Boldwood). There was something definite in that hope, for admitting that there might have been no deep thought in her (Boldwood) words to Liddy about marriage, they showed at least her (Boldwood) creed on the matter. This pleasant notion was now continually in his (Liddy) mind. Six years were a long time, but how much shorter than never, the idea he (Liddy) had for so long been obliged to endure! Jacob had served twice seven years for Rachel: what were six for such a woman as this? He (Jacob) tried to like the notion of waiting for her (woman) better than that of winning her (woman) at once. Boldwood felt his (Boldwood) love to be so deep and strong and eternal, that it was pos- sible she (woman) had never yet known its full volume, and this patience in delay would afford him (Boldwood) an opportunity of giving sweet proof on the point. He (Boldwood) would annihilate the six years of his (Boldwood) life as if they were minutes -- so little did he (Boldwood) value his (Boldwood) time on earth beside her (woman) love. He (Boldwood) would let her (woman) see, all those six years of intangible ether- eal courtship, how little care he (Boldwood) had for anything but as it bore upon the consummation. Meanwhile the early and the late summer brought round the week in which Greenhill Fair was held. This fair was frequently attended by the folk of Weather- bury.

CHAPTER L

THE SHEEP FAIR -- TROY TOUCHES HIS (Boldwood) WIFE``S HAND

GREENHILL was the Nijni Novgorod of South Wessex; and the busiest, merriest, noisiest day of the whole statute number was the day of the sheep fair. This yearly gathering was upon the summit of a hill which retained in good preservation the remains of an ancient earthwork, consisting of a huge rampart and entrenchment of an oval form encircling the top of the hill, though somewhat broken down here and there. To each of the two chief openings on opposite sides a winding road ascended, and the level green space of ten or fifteen acres enclosed by the bank was the site of the fair. A few permanent erections dotted the spot, but the majority of visitors patronized canvas alone for resting and feeding under during the time of their sojourn here. Shepherds who attended with their flocks from long distances started from home two or three days, or even a week, before the fair, driving their charges a few miles each day -- not more than ten or twelve -- and resting them at night in hired fields by the wayside at pre- viously chosen points, where they fed, having fasted since morning. The shepherd of each flock marched behind, a bundle containing his (shepherd) kit for the week strapped upon his (shepherd) shoulders, and in his (shepherd) hand his (shepherd) crook, which he (shepherd) used as the staff of his (shepherd) pilgrimage. Several of the sheep would get worn and lame, and occasionally a lambing occurred on the road. To meet these contingencies, there was frequently provided, to accompany the flocks from the remoter points, a pony and waggon into which the weakly ones were taken for the remainder of the journey. The Weatherbury Farms, however, were no such long distance from the hill, and those arrangements were not necessary in their case. But the large united flocks of Bathsheba and Farmer Boldwood formed a valuable and imposing multitude which demanded much attention, and on this account Gabriel, in addition to Boldwood's shepherd and Cain Ball, accompanied them along the way, through the decayed old town of Kings- bere, and upward to the plateau, -- old George the dog of course behind them. When the autumn sun slanted over Greenhill this morning and lighted the dewy flat upon its crest, nebu- lous clouds of dust were to be seen floating between the pairs of hedges which streaked the wide prospect around in all directions. These gradually converged upon the base of the hill, and the flocks became individually visible, climbing the serpentine ways which led to the top. Thus, in a slow procession, they entered the opening to which the roads tended, multitude after multitude, horned and hornless -- blue flocks and red flocks, buff flocks and brown flocks, even green and salmon-tinted flocks, according to the fancy of the colourist and custom of the farm. Men were shouting, dogs were barking, with greatest animation, but the thronging travellers in so long a journey had grown nearly indifferent to such terrors, though they still bleated piteously at the unwontedness of their experi- ences, a tall shepherd rising here and there in the midst of them, like a gigantic idol amid a crowd of prostrate devotees. The great mass of sheep in the fair consisted of South Downs and the old Wessex horned breeds, to the latter class Bathsheba's and Farmer Boldwood's mainly belonged. These filed in about nine o'clock, their vermiculated horns lopping gracefully on each side of their cheeks in geometrically perfect spirals, a small pink and white ear nestling under each horn. Before and behind came other varieties, perfect leopards as to the full rich substance of their coats, and only lacking the spots. There were also a few of the Oxfordshire breed, whose wool was beginning to curl like a child's flaxen hair, though surpassed in this respect by the effeminate Leicesters, which were in turn less curly than the Cots- wolds. But the most picturesque by far was a small flock of Exmoors, which chanced to be there this year. Their pied faces and legs, dark and heavy horns, tresses of wool hanging round their swarthy foreheads, quite relieved the monotony of the flocks in that quarter. All these bleating, panting, and weary thousands had entered and were penned before the morning had far advanced, the dog belonging to each flock being tied to the corner of the pen containing it. Alleys for pedes- trians intersected the pens, which soon became crowded with buyers and sellers from far and near. In another part of the hill an altogether different scene began to force itself upon the eye towards mid- day. A circular tent, of exceptional newness and size, was in course of erection here. As the day drew on, the flocks began to change hands, lightening the shep- herd's responsibilities; and they turned their attention to this tent and inquired of a man at work there, whose soul seemed concentrated on tying a bothering knot in no time, what was going on.

``The Royal Hippodrome Performance of Turpin's Ride to York and the Death of Black Bess.'' (the man)
replied the man promptly, without turning his (Boldwood) eyes or leaving off trying. As soon as the tent was completed the band struck up highly stimulating harmonies, and the announce- ment was publicly made, Black Bess standing in a con- spicuous position on the outside, as a living proof, If proof were wanted, of the truth of the oracular utterances from the stage over which the people were to enter. These were so convinced by such genuine appeals to heart and understanding both that they soon began to crowd in abundantly, among the foremost being visible Jan Coggan and Joseph Poorgrass, who were holiday keeping here to-day,
''`That's the great ruffen pushing me!'' (Joseph/Joseph Poorgrass/Poorgrass)
screamed a woman in front of Jan over her (woman) shoulder at him (Jan) when the rush was at its fiercest.
``How can I help pushing ye when the folk behind push me?'' (Coggan/Jan Coggan/Jan)
said Coggan, in a deprecating tone, turning without turning his (Coggan) body, which was jammed as in a vice. There was a silence; then the drums and trumpets again sent forth their echoing notes. The crowd was again ecstasied, and gave another lurch in which Coggan and Poorgrass were again thrust by those behind upon the women in front.
``O that helpless feymels should be at the mercy of she (Turpin) swayed like a reed shaken by the wind. Now.'' (Coggan/Jan Coggan/Jan)
said Coggan, appealing in an earnest voice to the public at large as it stood clustered about his (Coggan) shoulder-blades.
``Did ye ever hear such onreasonable woman as that? Upon my carcase, neighbours, if I could only get out of this cheesewring, the damn women might eat the show for me!'' (unknown)
``Don't ye lose yer temper, Jan!'' (Joseph/Joseph Poorgrass/Poorgrass)
implored Joseph Poorgrass, in a whisper.
'' They might get their men to murder us, for I think by the shine of their eyes that they be a sinful form of womankind.'' (Joseph/Joseph Poorgrass/Poorgrass)
Jan held his (Jan) tongue, as if he (Jan) had no objection to be pacified to please a friend, and they gradually reached the foot of the ladder, Poorgrass being flattened like a jumping-jack, and the sixpence, for admission, which he (Poorgrass) had got ready half-an-hour earlier, having become so reeking hot in the tight squeeze of his (Poorgrass) excited hand that the woman in spangles, brazen rings set with glass diamonds, and with chalked face and shoulders, who took the money of him (Poorgrass), hastily dropped it again from a fear that some trick had been played to burn her (woman) fingers. So they all entered, and the cloth of the tent, to the eyes of an observer on the outside, became bulged into innumerable pimples such as we observe on a sack of potatoes, caused by the various human heads, backs, and elbows at high pressure within. At the rear of the large tent there were two small dressing-tents. One of these, alloted to the male per- formers, was partitioned into halves by a cloth; and in one of the divisions there was sitting on the grass, pull ing on a pair of jack-boots, a young man whom we instantly recognise as Sergeant Troy. Troy's appearance in this position may be briefly accounted for. The brig aboard which he (Sergeant) was taken in Budmouth Roads was about to start on a voyage, though somewhat short of hands. Troy read the articles and joined, but before they sailed a boat was despatched across the bay to Lulwind cove; as he (Sergeant) had half expected, his (Sergeant) clothes were gone. He (Sergeant) ultimately worked his (Sergeant) passage to the United States, where he (Sergeant) made a precarious living in various towns as Professor of Gymnastics, Sword Exercise, Fencing, and Pugilism. A few months were sufficient to give him (Professor) a distaste for this kind of life. There was a certain animal form of refinement in his (Professor) nature; and however pleasant a strange condition might be whilst privations were easily warded off, it was dis- advantageously coarse when money was short. There was ever present, too, the idea that he (Professor) could claim a home and its comforts did he (Professor) but chose to return to England and Weatherbury Farm. Whether Bathsheba thought him (Professor) dead was a frequent subject of curious conjecture. To England he (Professor) did return at last; but the but the fact of drawing nearer to Weatherbury abstracted its fascinations, and his (Professor) intention to enter his (Professor) old groove at the place became modified. It was with gloom he (Professor) con- sidered on landing at Liverpool that if he (Professor) were to go home his (Professor) reception would be of a kind very unpleasant to con- template; for what Troy had in the way of emotion was an occasional fitful sentiment which sometimes caused him (Professor) as much inconvenience as emotion of a strong and healthy kind. Bathsheba was not a women to be made a fool of, or a woman to suffer in silence; and how could he (fool) endure existence with a spirited wife to whom at first entering he (fool) would be beholden for food and lodging? Moreover, it was not at all unlikely that his (fool) wife would fail at her (wife) farming, if she (wife) had not already done so; and he (fool) would then become liable for her (wife) maintenance: and what a life such a future of poverty with her (wife) would be, the spectre of Fanny constantly be- tween them, harrowing his (fool) temper and embittering her (Fanny) words! Thus, for reasons touching on distaste, regret, and shame commingled, he (fool) put off his (fool) return from day to day, and would have decided to put it off altogether if he (fool) could have found anywhere else the ready-made establishment which existed for him (fool) there. At this time -- the July preceding the September in which we find at Greenhill Fair -- he (fool) fell in with a travelling circus which was performing in the outskirts of a northern town. Troy introduced himself to the manager by taming a restive horse of the troupe, hitting a suspended apple with pistol-- bullet fired from the animal's back when in full gallop, and other feats. For his (manager) merits in these -- all more or less based upon his (manager) ex- periences as a dragoon-guardsman -- Troy was taken into the company, and the play of Turpin was prepared with a view to his (Turpin) personation of the chief character. Troy was not greatly elated by the appreciative spirit in which he (Turpin) was undoubtedly treated, but he (Turpin) thought the engage- ment might afford him (Turpin) a few weeks for consideration. It was thus carelessly, and without having formed any definite plan for the future, that Troy found himself at Greenhill Fair with the rest of the company on this day. And now the mild autumn sun got lower, and in front of the pavilion the following incident had taken place. Bathsheba -- who was driven to the fair that day by her (Turpin) odd man Poorgrass -- had, like every one else, read or heard the announcement that Mr. Francis, the Great Cosmopolitan Equestrian and Roughrider, would enact the part of Turpin, and she (Turpin) was not yet too old and careworn to be without a little curiosity to see him (Turpin). This particular show was by far the largest and grandest in the fair, a horde of little shows grouping themselves under its shade like chickens around a hen. The crowd had passed in, and Boldwood, who had been watching all the day for an opportunity of speaking to her (Turpin), seeing her (Turpin) comparatively isolated, came up to her (Turpin) side.
``I hope the sheep have done well to-day, Mrs. Troy?'' (he)
he (Boldwood) said, nervously.
``O yes, thank you.'' (Bathsheba/Bathsheba Everdene/BATHSHEBA)
said Bathsheba, colour springing up in the centre of her (Turpin) cheeks.
``I was fortunate enough to sell them all just as we got upon the hill, so we hadn't to pen at all.'' (unknown)
``And now you are entirely at leisure?'' (unknown)
``Yes, except that I have to see one more dealer in two hours' time: otherwise I should be going home. He (dealer) was looking at this large tent and the announcement. Have you ever seen the play of ``Turpin's Ride to York?
'' Turpin was a real man, was he (Turpin) not?'' (Turpin)
``O yes, perfectly true -- all of it. Indeed, I think I've heard Jan Coggan say that a relation of his (Coggan) knew Tom King, Turpin's friend, quite well.'' (unknown)
``Coggan is rather given to strange stories connected with his (Coggan) relations, we must remember. I hope they can all be believed.'' (unknown)
``Yes, yes; we know Coggan. But Turpin is true enough. You have never seen it played, I suppose?'' (unknown)
``Never. I was not allowed to go into these places when I was young. Hark! What's that prancing? How they shout!'' (unknown)
``Black Bess just started off, I suppose. Am I right in supposing you would like to see the performance, Mrs. Troy? Please excuse my mistake, if it is one; but if you would like to, I'll get a seat for you with pleasure.'' (she)
Perceiving that she (Turpin) hesitated, he (Turpin) added,
``I myself shall not stay to see it: I've seen it before.'' (he)
Now Bathsheba did care a little to see the show, and had only withheld her (Turpin) feet from the ladder because she (Turpin) feared to go in alone. She (Turpin) had been hoping that Oak might appear, whose assistance in such cases was always accepted as an inalienable right, but Oak was nowhere to be seen; and hence it was that she (Turpin) said,
``Then if you will just look in first, to see if there's room, I think I will go in for a minute or two.'' (she)
And so a short time after this Bathsheba appeared in the tent with Boldwood at her (Turpin) elbow, who, taking her (Turpin) to a
``reserved'' (her)
seat, again withdrew. This feature consisted of one raised bench in very conspicuous part of the circle, covered with red cloth, and floored with a piece of carpet, and Bathsheba immediately found, to her (Turpin) confusion, that she (Turpin) was the single reserved individual in the tent, the rest of the crowded spectators, one and all, standing on their legs on the borders of the arena, where they got twice as good a view of the performance for half the money. Hence as many eyes were turned upon her (Turpin), enthroned alone in this place of honour, against a scarlet back- ground, as upon the ponies and clown who were engaged in preliminary exploits in the centre, Turpin not having yet appeared. Once there, Bathsheba was forced to make the best of it and remain: she (Turpin) sat down, spreading her (Turpin) skirts with some dignity over the unoccupied space on each side of her (Turpin), and giving a new and feminine aspect to the pavilion. In a few minutes she (Turpin) noticed the fat red nape of Coggan's neck among those standing just below her (Turpin), and Joseph Poor- grass's saintly profile a little further on. The interior was shadowy with a peculiar shade. The strange luminous semi-opacities of fine autumn afternoons and eves intensified into Rembrandt effects the few yellow sunbeams which came through holes and divisions in the canvas, and spirted like jets of gold-dust across the dusky blue atmosphere of haze pervading the tent, until they alighted on inner surfaces of cloth opposite, and shone like little lamps suspended there. Troy, on peeping from his (Rembrandt) dressing-tent through a slit for a reconnoitre before entering, saw his (Rembrandt) unconscious wife on high before him (Rembrandt) as described, sitting as queen of the tournament. He (Rembrandt) started back in utter confusion, for although his (Rembrandt) disguise effectually concealed his (Rembrandt) person- ality, he (Rembrandt) instantly felt that she (queen) would be sure to recognize his (Rembrandt) voice. He (Rembrandt) had several times during the day thought of the possibility of some Weatherbury person or other appearing and recognizing him (Rembrandt); but he (Rembrandt) had taken the risk carelessly. If they see me, let them, he (Rembrandt) had said. But here was Bathsheba in her (queen) own person; and the reality of the scene was so much intenser than any of his (Rembrandt) prefigurings that he (Rembrandt) felt he (Rembrandt) had not half enough considered the point. She (queen) looked so charming and fair that his (Rembrandt) cool mood about Weatherbury people was changed. He (Rembrandt) had not expected her (queen) to exercise this power over him (Rembrandt) in the twinkling of an eye. Should he (Rembrandt) go on, and care nothing? He (Rembrandt) could not bring himself to do that. Beyond a politic wish to remain unknown, there suddenly arose in him (Rembrandt) now a sense of shame at the possibility that his (Rembrandt) attractive young wife, who already despised him (Rembrandt), should despise him (Rembrandt) more by discovering him (Rembrandt) in so mean a condition after so long a time. He (Rembrandt) actually blushed at the thought, and was vexed beyond measure that his (Rembrandt) sentiments of dislike towards Weatherbury should have led him (Rembrandt) to dally about the country in this way. But Troy was never more clever than when absolutely at his (Rembrandt) wit's end. He (Rembrandt) hastily thrust aside the curtain dividing his (Rembrandt) own little dressing space from that of the manager and proprietor, who now appeared as the individual called Tom King as far down as his (King) waist, and as the aforesaid respectable manager thence to his (King) toes.
``Here's the devil to pay!'' (unknown)
said Troy.
``How's that?'' (unknown)
``Why, there's a blackguard creditor in the tent I don't want to see, who'll discover me and nab me as sure as Satan if I open my mouth. What's to be done?'' (I)
You must appear now, I think.'' ``I can't.
'' But the play must proceed.'' (I)
``Do you give out that Turpin has got a bad cold, and can't speak his (Turpin) part, but that he (Turpin)'ll perform it just the same without speaking.'' (The proprietor)
The proprietor shook his (proprietor) head. ``Anyhow, play or no play, I won't open my mouth, said Troy, firmly. ``Very well, then let me see. I tell you how we'll manage.'' said the other, who perhaps felt it would be extremely awkward to offend his (proprietor) leading man just at this time. ``I won't tell 'em anything about your keeping silence; go on with the piece and say nothing, doing what you can by a judicious wink now and then, and a few indomitable nods in the heroic places, you know. They'll never find out that the speeches are omitted.'' This seemed feasible enough, for Turpin's speeches were not many or long, the fascination of the piece lying entirely in the action; and accordingly the play began, and at the appointed time Black Bess leapt into the grassy circle amid the plaudits of the spectators.
