At the turnpike scene, where Bess and Turpin are hotly pursued at midnight by the officers, and half-awake gatekeeper in his (gatekeeper) tasselled nightcap denies that any horseman has passed, Coggan uttered a broad-chested ``Well done!'' which could be heard all over the fair above the bleating, and Poorgrass smiled delightedly with a nice sense of dramatic contrast between our hero, who coolly leaps the gate, and halting justice in the form of his (Poorgrass) enemies, who must needs pull up cumbersomely and wait to be let through. At the death of Tom King, he (King) could not refrain from seizing Coggan by the hand, and whispering, with tears in his (King) eyes, ``Of course he (you)'s not really shot, Jan -- only seemingly!'' And when the last sad scene came on, and the body of the gallant and faithful Bess had to be carried out on a shutter by twelve volunteers from among the spectators, nothing could restrain Poorgrass from lending a hand, exclaiming, as he (Bess) asked Jan to join him (Bess), ``Twill be something to tell of at Warren's in future years, Jan, and hand down to our children.
'' For many a year in Weatherbury, Joseph told, with the air of a man who had had experiences in his (Joseph) time, that he (Joseph) touched with his (Joseph) own hand the hoof of Bess as she (Bess) lay upon the board upon his (Bess) shoulder. If, as some thinkers hold, immortality consists in being enshrined in others'' (children)
memories, then did Black Bess become immortal that day if she (Bess) never had done so before. Meanwhile Troy had added a few touches to his (Bess) ordinary make-up for the character, the more effectually to disguise himself, and though he (Bess) had felt faint qualms on first entering, the metamorphosis effected by judici- ously
``lining'' (he)
his (Bess) face with a wire rendered him (Bess) safe from the eyes of Bathsheba and her (Bess) men. Nevertheless, he (Bess) was relieved when it was got through. There a second performance in the evening, and the tent was lighted up. Troy had taken his (Bess) part very quietly this time, venturing to introduce a few speeches on occasion; and was just concluding it when, whilst standing at the edge of the circle contiguous to the first row of spectators, he (Bess) observed within a yard of him (Bess) the eye of a man darted keenly into his (man) side features. Troy hastily shifted his (man) position, after having recognized in sworn enemy, who still hung about the outskirts of At first Troy resolved to take no notice and abide by circumstances. That he (man) had been recognized by this man was highly probable; yet there was room for a doubt. Then the great objection he (man) had felt to allowing news of his (man) proximity to precede him (man) to Weatherbury in the event of his (man) return, based on a feeling that knowledge of his (man) present occupation would discredit him (man) still further in his (man) wife's eyes, returned in full force. Moreover, should he (man) resolve not to return at all, a tale of his (man) being alive and being in the neighbourhood would be awkward; and he (man) was anxious to acquire a knowledge of his (man) wife's temporal affairs before deciding which to do. In this dilemma Troy at once went out to recon- noitre. It occurred to him (man) that to find Pennyways, and make a friend of him (friend) if possible, would be a very wise act. He (friend) had put on a thick beard borrowed from the establishment, and this he (friend) wandered about the fair- field. It was now almost dark, and respectable people were getting their carts and gigs ready to go home The largest refreshment booth in the fair was provided by an innkeeper from a neighbouring town. This was considered an unexceptionable place for obtaining the necessary food and rest: Host Trencher -LRB-as he (innkeeper) was jauntily called by the local newspaper-RRB- being a sub- stantial man of high repute for catering through all the county round. The tent was divided into first and second-class compartments, and at the end of the first- class division was a yet further enclosure for the most exclusive, fenced of from the body of the tent by a luncheon-bar, behind which the host himself stood bustling about in white apron and shirt-sleeves, and look- ing as if he (man) had never lived anywhere but under canvas all his (man) life. In these penetralia were chairs and a table, which, on candles being lighted, made quite a cozy and luxurious show, with an urn, plated tea and coffee pots, china teacups, and plum cakes. Troy stood at the entrance to the booth, where a gipsy-woman was frying pancakes over a little fire of sticks and selling them at a penny a-piece, and looked over the heads of the people within. He (man) could see nothing of Pennyways, but he (man) soon discerned Bathsheba through an opening into the reserved space at the further end. Troy thereupon retreated, went round the tent into the darkness, and listened. He (man) could hear Bathsheba's voice immediately inside the canvas; she (them) was conversing with a man. A warmth overspread his (man) face: surely she (them) was not so unprincipled as to flirt in a fair! He (man) wondered if, then, she (them) reckoned upon his (man) death as an absolute certainty. To get at the root of the matter, Troy took a penknife from his (man) pocket and softly made two little cuts crosswise in the cloth, which, by folding back the corners left a hole the size of a wafer. Close to this he (man) placed his (man) face, withdrawing it again in a movement of surprise; for his (man) eye had been within twelve inches of the top of Bathsheba's head. lt was too near to be convenient. He (man) made another hole a little to one side and lower down, in a shaded place beside her (Troy) chair, from which it was easy and safe to survey her (Troy) by looking horizontally'. Troy took in the scene completely now. She (Troy) was leaning back, sipping a cup of tea that she (Troy) held in her (Troy) hand, and the owner of the male voice was Boldwood, who had apparently just brought the cup to her (Troy), Bathsheba, being in a negligent mood, leant so idly against the canvas that it was pressed to the shape of her (Troy) shoulder, and she (Troy) was, in fact, as good as in Troy's arms; and he (Boldwood) was obliged to keep his (Boldwood) breast carefully backward that she (Troy) might not feel its warmth through the cloth as he (Boldwood) gazed in. Troy found unexpected chords of feeling to be stirred again within him (Boldwood) as they had been stirred earlier in the day. She (Troy) was handsome as ever, and she (Troy) was his (Boldwood). It was some minutes before he (Boldwood) could counteract his (Boldwood) sudden wish to go in, and claim her (Troy). Then he (Boldwood) thought how the proud girl who had always looked down upon him (Boldwood) even whilst it was to love him (Boldwood), would hate him (Boldwood) on dis- covering him (Boldwood) to be a strolling player. Were he (Boldwood) to make himself known, that chapter of his (Boldwood) life must at all risks be kept for ever from her (girl) and from the Weatherbury people, or his (Boldwood) name would be a byword throughout the parish. He (Boldwood) would be nicknamed
``Turpin'' (He)
as long as he (Boldwood) lived. Assuredly before he (Boldwood) could claim her (girl) these few past months of his (Boldwood) existence must be entirely blotted out.
``Shall I get you another cup before you start, ma'am?'' (Farmer Boldwood)
said Farmer Boldwood. I thank you,'' said Bathsheba. ``But I must be going at once. It was great neglect in that man to keep me waiting here till so late. I should have gone two hours ago, if it had not been for him (man). I had no idea of coming in here; but there's nothing so refreshing as a cup of tea, though I should never have got one if you hadn't helped me.'' Troy scrutinized her (girl) cheek as lit by the candles, and watched each varying shade thereon, and the white shell-like sinuosities of her (girl) little ear. She (girl) took out her (girl) purse and was insisting to Boldwood on paying for her (girl) tea for herself, when at this moment Pennyways entered the tent. Troy trembled: here was his (Boldwood) scheme for respectability endangered at once. He (Boldwood) was about to leave his (Boldwood) hole of espial, attempt to follow Pennyways, and find out if the ex-bailiff had recognized him (Boldwood), when he (Boldwood) was arrested by the conversation, and found he (Boldwood) was too late. ``Excuse me, ma'am.'' said Pennyways; ``I've some private information for your ear alone.
'' I cannot hear it now.'' (I)
she (Troy) said, coldly. That Bathsheba could not endure this man was evident; in fact, he (man) was continually coming to her (Troy) with some tale or other, by which he (man) might creep into favour at the expense of persons maligned.
``I'll write it down.'' (Pennyways)
said Pennyways, confidently. He (man) stooped over the table, pulled a leaf from a warped pocket-book, and wrote upon the paper, in a round hand --
``YOUR husband is here. I've seen him (husband). Who's the fool now?'' (He)
This he (man) folded small, and handed towards her (Troy). Bathsheba would not read it; she (Troy) would not even put out her (Troy) hand to take it. Pennyways, then, with a laugh of derision, tossed it into her (Troy) lap, and, turning away, left her (Troy). From the words and action of Pennyways, Troy, though he (man) had not been able to see what the ex-bailiff wrote, had not a moment's doubt that the note referred to him (man). Nothing that he (man) could think of could be done to check the exposure.
``Curse my luck!'' (he)
he (man) whispered, and added imprecations which rustled in the gloom like a pestilent wind. Meanwhile Boldwood said, taking up the note from her (Troy) lap --
``Don't you wish to read it, Mrs. Troy? If not, I'll destroy it.'' (Boldwood/Mr. Boldwood/BOLDWOOD)
``Oh, well.'' (Bathsheba/Bathsheba Everdene/BATHSHEBA)
said Bathsheba, carelessly,
``perhaps it is unjust not to read it; but I can guess what it is about. He (fool) wants me to recommend him (fool), or it is to tell me of some little scandal or another connected with my work- people. He (fool)'s always doing that.'' (Bathsheba/Bathsheba Everdene/BATHSHEBA)
Bathsheba held the note in her (Troy) right hand. Bold- wood handed towards her (Troy) a plate of cut bread-and- butter; when, in order to take a slice, she (Troy) put the note into her (Troy) left hand, where she (Troy) was still holding the purse, and then allowed her (Troy) hand to drop beside her (Troy) close to the canvas. The moment had come for saving his (Boldwood) game, and Troy impulsively felt that he (Boldwood) would play the card, For yet another time he (Boldwood) looked at the fair hand, and saw the pink finger-tips, and the blue veins of the wrist, encircled by a bracelet of coral chippings which she (Troy) wore: how familiar it all was to him (Boldwood)! Then, with the lightning action in which he (Boldwood) was such an adept, he (Boldwood) noiselessly slipped his (Boldwood) hand under the bottom of the tent-cloth, which was far from being pinned tightly down, lifted it a little way, keeping his (Boldwood) eye to the hole, snatched the note from her (Troy) fingers, dropped the canvas, and ran away in the gloom towards the bank and ditch, smiling at the scream of astonishment which burst from her (Troy). Troy then slid down on the outside of the rampart, hastened round in the bottom of the entrenchment to a distance of a hundred yards, ascended again, and crossed boldly in a slow walk towards the front entrance of the tent. His (Boldwood) object was now to get to Pennyways, and prevent a repetition of the announcement until such time as he (Boldwood) should choose. Troy reached the tent door, and standing among the groups there gathered, looked anxiously for Pennyways, evidently not wishing to make himself prominent by inquiring for him (Boldwood). One or two men were speaking of a daring attempt that had just been made to rob a young lady by lifting the canvas of the tent beside her (lady). It was supposed that the rogue had imagined a slip of paper which she (lady) held in her (lady) hand to he (rogue) a bank note, for he (rogue) had seized it, and made off with it, leaving her (lady) purse behind. His (rogue) chagrin and disappointment at dis- covering its worthlessness would be a good joke, it was said. However, the occurrence seemed to have become known to few, for it had not interrupted a fiddler, who had lately begun playing by the door of the tent, nor the four bowed old men with grim countenances and walking-sticks in hand, who were dancing
``Major Malley's Reel'' (men)
to the tune. Behind these stood Pennyways. Troy glided up to him (fiddler), beckoned, and whispered a few words; and with a mutual glance of concurrence the two men went into the night together.

CHAPTER LI

BATHSHEBA TALKS WITH HER OUTRIDER

THE arrangement for getting back again to Weather- bury had been that Oak should take the place of Poor- grass in Bathsheba's conveyance and drive her (fiddler) home, it being discovered late in the afternoon that Joseph was suffering from his (Joseph) old complaint, a multiplying eye, and was, therefore, hardly trustworthy as coachman and protector to a woman. But Oak had found himself so occupied, and was full of so many cares relative to those portions of Boldwood's flocks that were not disposed of, that Bathsheba, without telling Oak or anybody, resolved to drive home herself, as she (woman) had many times done from Casterbridge Market, and trust to her (woman) good angel for performing the journey un- molested. But having fallen in with Farmer Boldwood accidentally -LRB-on her (woman) part at least-RRB- at the refreshment- tent, she (woman) found it impossible to refuse his (Boldwood) offer to ride on horseback beside her (woman) as escort. It had grown twilight before she (woman) was aware, but Boldwood assured her (woman) that there was no cause for uneasiness, as the moon would be up in half-an-hour. Immediately after the incident in the tent, she (woman) had risen to go -- now absolutely alarmed and really grateful for her (woman) old lover's protection -- though regretting Gabriel's absence, whose company she (woman) would have much preferred, as being more proper as well as more pleasant, since he (Gabriel) was her (woman) own managing-man and servant. This, how- ever, could not be helped; she (woman) would not, on any consideration, treat Boldwood harshly, having once already illused him (Boldwood), and the moon having risen, and the gig being ready, she (woman) drove across the hilltop in the wending way's which led downwards -- to oblivious obscurity, as it seemed, for the moon and the hill it flooded with light were in appearance on a level, the rest of the world lying as a vast shady concave between them. Boldwood mounted his (Boldwood) horse, and followed in close attendance behind. Thus they descended into the lowlands, and the sounds of those left on the hill came like voices from the sky, and the lights were as those of a camp in heaven. They soon passed the merry stragglers in the immediate vicinity of the hill, traversed Kingsbere, and got upon the high road. The keen instincts of Bathsheba had perceived that the farmer's staunch devotion to herself was still un- diminished, and she (They) sympathized deeply. The sight had quite depressed her (They) this evening; had reminded her (They) of her (They) folly; she (They) wished anew, as she (They) had wished many months ago, for some means of making repara- tion for her (They) fault. Hence her (They) pity for the man who so persistently loved on to his (man) own injury and per- manent gloom had betrayed Bathsheba into an injudi- cious considerateness of manner, which appeared almost like tenderness, and gave new vigour to the exquisite dream of a Jacob's seven years service in poor Boldwood's mind. He (Boldwood) soon found an excuse for advancing from his (Boldwood) position in the rear, and rode close by her (They) side. They had gone two or three miles in the moonlight, speaking desultorily across the wheel of her (They) gig concerning the fair, farming, Oak's usefulness to them both, and other indifferent subjects, when Boldwood said suddenly and simply --

``Mrs. Troy, you will marry again some day?'' (Boldwood/Mr. Boldwood/BOLDWOOD)
This point-blank query unmistakably confused her (They), it was not till a minute or more had elapsed that she (They) said,
``I have not seriously thought of any such subject.'' (she)
``I quite understand that. Yet your late husband has been dead nearly one year, and -- '' (she)
``You forget that his (husband) death was never absolutely proved, and may not have taken place; so that I may not be really a widow.'' (she)
she (They) said, catching at the straw of escape that the fact afforded ``Not absolutely proved, perhaps, but it was proved circumstantially. A man saw him (man) drowning, too. No reasonable person has any doubt of his (man) death; nor have you, ma'am, I should imagine. ``O yes I have, or I should have acted differently,'' she (They) said, gently. ``From the first, I have had a strange uaccountable feeling that he (man) could not have perished, but I have been able to explain that in several ways since. Even were I half persuaded that I shall see him (man) no more, I am far from thinking of marriage with another. I should be very contemptible to indulge in such a thought.'' They were silent now awhile, and having struck into an unfrequented track across a common, the creaks of Boldwood's saddle and gig springs were all the sounds to be heard. Boldwood ended the pause. ``Do you remember when I carried you fainting in my arms into the King's Arms, in Casterbridge? Every dog has his (King) day: that was mine.'' ``I know-I know it all.'' she (They) said, hurriedly. ``I, for one, shall never cease regretting that events so fell out as to deny you to me.'' ``I, too, am very sorry.'' she (They) said, and then checked herself. ``I mean, you know, I am sorry you thought I -- '' ``I have always this dreary pleasure in thinking over those past times with you -- that I was something to you before HE (King) was anything, and that you belonged ALMOST to me. But, of course, that's nothing. You never liked me.'' ``I did; and respected you, too.
``Do you now?'' (unknown)
``Yes.'' (unknown)
``Which?'' (unknown)
``How do you mean which?'' (unknown)
``Do you like me, or do you respect me?'' (unknown)
``I don't know -- at least, I cannot tell you. It is difficult for a woman to define her (woman) feelings in language which is chiefly made by men to express theirs. My treatment of you was thoughtless, inexcusable, wicked! I shall eternally regret it. If there had been anything I could have done to make amends I would most gladly have done it -- there was nothing on earth I so longed to do as to repair the error. But that was not possible.'' (unknown)
``Don't blame yourself -- you were not so far in the wrong as you suppose. Bathsheba, suppose you had real complete proof that you are what, in fact, you are -- a widow -- would you repair the old wrong to me by marrying me?'' (unknown)
``I cannot say. I shouldn't yet, at any rate.'' (unknown)
``But you might at some future time of your life?'' (unknown)
``O yes, I might at some time.'' (unknown)
``Well, then, do you know that without further proof of any kind you may marry again in about six years from the present -- subject to nobody's objection or blame?'' (unknown)
``O yes.'' (she)
she (They) said, quickly.
``I know all that. But don't talk of it -- seven or six years -- where may we all be by that time?'' (unknown)
``They will soon glide by, and it will seem an astonishingly short time to look back upon when they are past -- much less than to look forward to now.'' (unknown)
``Yes, yes; I have found that in my own experience.'' (unknown)
``Now listen once more.'' (Boldwood/Mr. Boldwood/BOLDWOOD)
Boldwood pleaded.
``If I wait that time, will you marry me? You own that you owe me amends -- let that be your way of making them.'' (unknown)
``But, Mr. Boldwood -- six years -- '' (unknown)
``Do you want to be the wife of any other man?'' (unknown)
``No indeed! I mean, that I don't like to talk about this matter now. Perhaps it is not proper, and I ought not to allow it. Let us drop it. My husband may be living, as I said.'' (unknown)
``Of course, I'll drop the subject if you wish. But propriety has nothing to do with reasons. I am a middle-aged man, willing to protect you for the remainder of our lives. On your side, at least, there is no passion or blamable haste -- on mine, perhaps, there is. But I can't help seeing that if you choose from a feeling of pity, and, as you say, a wish to make amends, to make a bargain with me for a far-ahead time -- an agreement which will set all things right and make me happy, late though it may be -- there is no fault to be found with you as a woman. Hadn't I the first place beside you? Haven't you been almost mine once already? Surely you can say to me as much as this, you will have me back again should circumstances permit? Now, pray speak! O Bathsheba, promise -- it is only a little promise -- that if you marry again, you will marry me!'' (she)
His (Boldwood) tone was so excited that she (They) almost feared him (Boldwood) at this moment, even whilst she (They) sympathized. It was a simple physical fear -- the weak of the strong; there no emotional aversion or inner repugnance. She (They) said, with some distress in her (They) voice, for she (They) remembered vividly his (Boldwood) outburst on the Yalbury Road, and shrank from a repetition of his (Boldwood) anger: --
``I will never marry another man whilst you wish me to be your wife, whatever comes -- but to say more -- you have taken me so by surprise -- '' (she)
``But let it stand in these simple words -- that in six years' time you will be my wife? Unexpected accidents we'll not mention, because those, of course, must be given way to. Now, this time I know you will keep your word.'' (she)
``That's why I hesitate to give it.'' (unknown)
``But do give it! Remember the past, and be kind.'' (She)
She (They) breathed; and then said mournfully:
``O what shall I do? I don't love you, and I much fear that I never shall love you as much as a woman ought to love a husband. If you, sir, know that, and I can yet give you happiness by a mere promise to marry at the end of six years, if my husband should not come back, it is a great honour to me. And if you value such an act of friendship from a woman who doesn't esteem her (woman)- self as she (woman) did, and has little love left, why it will -- '' (She)
``Promise!'' (unknown)
'' -- Consider, if I cannot promise soon.'' (unknown)
``But soon is perhaps never?'' (unknown)
``O no, it is not! I mean soon. Christmas, we'll say.'' (unknown)
``Christmas!'' (He)
He (Boldwood) said nothing further till he (Boldwood) added:
``Well, I'll say no more to you about it till that time.'' (he)
Bathsheba was in a very peculiar state of mind, which showed how entirely the soul is the slave of the body, the ethereal spirit dependent for its quality upon the tangible flesh and blood. It is hardly too much to say that she (They) felt coerced by a force stronger than her (They) own will, not only into the act of promising upon this singularly remote and vague matter, but into the emo- tion of fancying that she (They) ought to promise. When the weeks intervening between the night of this conversa- tion and Christmas day began perceptibly to diminish, her (They) anxiety and perplexity increased. One day she (They) was led by an accident into an oddly confidential dialogue with Gabriel about her (They) difficulty It afforded her (They) a little relief -- of a dull and cheerless kind. They were auditing accounts, and something occurred in the course of their labours which led Oak to say, speaking of Boldwood,
'' He (Boldwood)'ll never forget you, ma'am, never.'' (Boldwood/Mr. Boldwood/BOLDWOOD)
Then out came her (They) trouble before she (They) was aware; and she (They) told him (Boldwood) how she (They) had again got into the toils; what Boldwood had asked her (They), and how he (Boldwood) was ex- pecting her (They) assent.
``The most mournful reason of all for my agreeing to it.'' (she)
she (They) said sadly,
``and the true reason why I think to do so for good or for evil, is this -- it is a thing I have not breathed to a living soul as yet-i believe that if I don't give my word, he (I)'ll go out of his (I) mind.'' (she)
``Really, do ye?'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
said Gabriel, gravely.
``I believe this.'' (she)
she (They) continued, with reckless frank- ness;
``and Heaven knows I say it in a spirit the very reverse of vain, for I am grieved and troubled to my soul about it-i believe I hold that man's future in my hand. His (man) career depends entirely upon my treatment of him (man). O Gabriel, I tremble at my responsibility, for it is terrible!'' (she)
``Well, I think this much, ma'am, as I told you years ago.'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
said Oak,
``that his (Gabriel) life is a total blank whenever he (Gabriel) isn't hoping for `ee; but I can't suppose-i hope that nothing so dreadful hangs on to it as you fancy. His (Gabriel) natural manner has always been dark and strange, you know. But since the case is so sad and oddlike, why don't ye give the conditional promise? I think I would.'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
``But is it right? Some rash acts of my past life have taught me that a watched woman must have very much circumspection to retain only a very little credit, and I do want and long to be discreet in this! And six years -- why we may all be in our graves by that BATHSHEBA TALKS WITH OAK time, even if Mr. Troy does not come back again, which he (Troy) may not impossibly do! Such thoughts give a sort of absurdity to the scheme. Now, isn't it preposterous, Gabriel? However he (Gabriel) came to dream of it, I cannot think. But is it wrong? You know -- you are older than I.'' (unknown)
``Eight years older, ma'am.'' (unknown)
``Yes, eight years -- and is it wrong?'' (unknown)
``Perhaps it would be an uncommon agreement for a man and woman to make: I don't see anything really wrong about it.'' (unknown)
said Oak, slowly.
``In fact the very thing that makes it doubtful if you ought to marry en under any condition, that is, your not caring about him (man) -- for I may suppose -- -- '' (she)
``Yes, you may suppose that love is wanting.'' (she)
she (They) said shortly.
``Love is an utterly bygone, sorry, worn- out, miserable thing with me -- for him (man) or any one else.'' (unknown)
``Well, your want of love seems to me the one thing that takes away harm from such an agreement with him (man). If wild heat had to do wi' it, making ye long to over- come the awkwardness about your husband's vanishing, it mid be wrong; but a cold-hearted agreement to oblige a man seems different, somehow. The real sin, ma'am in my mind, lies in thinking of ever wedding wi' a man you don't love honest and true.'' (unknown)
``That I'm willing to pay the penalty of.'' (unknown)
said Bath- sheba, firmly.
``You know, Gabriel, this is what I can- not get off my conscience -- that I once seriously injured him (Gabriel) in sheer idleness. If I had never played a trick upon him (Gabriel), he (Gabriel) would never have wanted to marry me. O if I could only pay some heavy damages in money to him (Gabriel) for the harm I did, and so get the sin off my soul that way!.. Well, there's the debt, which can only be discharged in one way, and I believe I am bound to do it if it honestly lies in my power, without any consideration of my own future at all. When a rake gambles away his (Gabriel) expectations, the fact that it is an inconvenient debt doesn't make him (Gabriel) the less liable. I've been a rake, and the single point I ask you is, con- sidering that my own scruples, and the fact that in the eye of the law my husband is only missing, will keep any man from marrying me until seven years have passed -- am I free to entertain such an idea, even though `tis a sort of penance -- for it will be that? I hate the act of marriage under such circumstances, and the class of women I should seem to belong to by doing it!'' (unknown)
``It seems to me that all depends upon whe'r you think, as everybody else do, that your husband is dead.'' (unknown)
``I shall get to, I suppose, because I cannot help feeling what would have brought him (husband) back long before this time if he (husband) had lived.'' (unknown)
``Well, then, in religious sense you will be as free to THINK o' marrying again as any real widow of one year's standing. But why don't ye ask Mr. Thirdly's advice on how to treat Mr. Boldwood?'' (unknown)
``No. When I want a broad-minded opinion for general enlightenment, distinct from special advice, I never go to a man who deals in the subject pro- fessionally. So I like the parson's opinion on law, the lawyer's on doctoring, the doctor's on business, and my business-man's -- that is, yours -- on morals.'' (unknown)
``And on love -- -- '' (unknown)
``My own.'' (unknown)
``I'm afraid there's a hitch in that argument.'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
said Oak, with a grave smile. She (They) did not reply at once, and then saying,
``Good evening Mr. Oak.'' (She)
went away. She (They) had spoken frankly, and neither asked nor ex- pected any reply from Gabriel more satisfactory than that she (They) had obtained. Yet in the centremost parts of her (They) complicated heart there existed at this minute a little pang of disappointment, for a reason she (They) would not allow herself to recognize. Oak had not once wished her (They) free that he (Gabriel) might marry her (They) himself -- had not once said,
``I could wait for you as well as he (Oak).'' (he)
That was the insect sting. Not that she (They) would have listened to any such hypothesis. O no -- for wasn't she (They) saying all the time that such thoughts of the future were improper, and wasn't Gabriel far too poor a man to speak sentiment to her (They)? Yet he (Gabriel) might have just hinted about that old love of his (Gabriel), and asked, in a playful off-hand way, if he (Gabriel) might speak of it. It would have seemed pretty and sweet, if no more; and then she (They) would have shown how kind and inoffensive a woman's
``No'' (a woman)
can sometimes be. But to give such cool advice -- the very advice she (They) had asked for -- it ruffled our heroine all the afternoon.

CHAPTER LII

CONVERGING COURSES

I CHRISTMAS-EVE came, and a party that Boldwood was to give in the evening was the great subject of talk in Weatherbury. It was not that the rarity of Christmas parties in the parish made this one a wonder, but that Boldwood should be the giver. The announcement had had an abnormal and incongruous sound, as if one should hear of croquet-playing in a cathedral aisle, or that some much-respected judge was going upon the stage. That the party was intended to be a truly jovial one there was no room for doubt. A large bough of mistletoe had been brought from the woods that day, and suspended in the hall of the bachelor's home. Holly and ivy had followed in armfuls. From six that morning till past noon the huge wood fire in the kitchen roared and sparkled at its highest, the kettle, the saucepan, and the threelegged pot appearing in the midst of the flames like Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego; moreover, roasting and basting operations were continually carried on in front of the genial blaze. As it grew later the fire was made up in the large long hall into which the staircase descended, and all encumbrances were cleared out for dancing. The log which was to form the back-brand of the evening fire was the uncleft trunk of a tree, so unwieldy that it could be neither brought nor rolled to its place; and accord- ingly two men were to be observed dragging and heaving it in by chains and levers as the hour of assembly drew near. II In spite of all this, the spirit of revelry was wanting In the atmosphere of the house. Such a thing had never been attempted before by its owner, and it was now done as by a wrench. Intended gaieties would insist upon appearing like solemn grandeurs, the organ- ization of the whole effort was carried out coldly, by hirelings, and a shadow seemed to move about the rooms, saying that the proceedings were unnatural to the place and the lone man who lived therein, and hence not good. Bathsheba was at this time in her (owner) room, dressing for the event. She (owner) had called for candles, and Liddy entered and placed one on each side of her (owner) mistress's glass.

``Don't go away, Liddy.'' (Bathsheba/Bathsheba Everdene/BATHSHEBA)
said Bathsheba, almost timidly.
'' I am foolishly agitated-i cannot tell why. I wish I had not been obliged to go to this dance; but there's no escaping now. I have not spoken to Mr. Boldwood since the autumn, when I promised to see him (Boldwood) at Christmas on business, but I had no idea there was to be anything of this kind.'' (Bathsheba/Bathsheba Everdene/BATHSHEBA)
``But I would go now.'' (Liddy/Smallbury/Liddy Smallbury)
said Liddy, who was going with her (owner); for Boldwood had been indiscriminate in his (Boldwood) invitations.
``Yes, I shall make my appearance, of course.'' (Bathsheba/Bathsheba Everdene/BATHSHEBA)
said Bathsheba.
'' But I am THE CAUSE of the party, and that upsets me! -- Don't tell, Liddy.'' (Bathsheba/Bathsheba Everdene/BATHSHEBA)
``O no, ma'am, You the cause of it, ma'am?'' (unknown)
``Yes. I am the reason of the party-i. If it had not been for me, there would never have been one. I can't explain any more -- there's no more to be explained. I wish I had never seen Weatherbury.'' (unknown)
``That's wicked of you -- to wish to be worse off than you are.'' (unknown)
``No, Liddy. I have never been free from trouble since I have lived here, and this party is likely to bring me more. Now, fetch my black silk dress, and see how it sits upon me.'' (unknown)
``But you will leave off that, surely, ma'am? You have been a widowlady fourteen months, and ought to brighten up a little on such a night as this.'' (unknown)
``Is it necessary? No; I will appear as usual, for if I were to wear any light dress people would say things about me, and I should seem to he (I) rejoicing when I am solemn all the time. The party doesn't suit me a bit; but never mind, stay and help to finish me off.'' (Boldwood/Mr. Boldwood/BOLDWOOD)
III Boldwood was dressing also at this hour. A tailor from Casterbridge was with him (Boldwood), assisting him (Boldwood) in the operation of trying on a new coat that had just been brought home. Never had Boldwood been so fastidious, unreasonable about the fit, and generally difficult to please. The tailor walked round and round him (tailor), tugged at the waist, pulled the sleeve, pressed out the collar, and for the first time in his (tailor) experience Boldwood was not bored- Times had been when the farmer had exclaimed against all such niceties as childish, but now no philosophic or hasty rebuke whatever was provoked by this man for attaching as much importance to a crease in the coat as to an earthquake in South America. Boldwood at last expressed himself nearly satisfied, and paid the bill, the tailor passing out of the door just as Oak came in to report progress for the day.
``Oh, Oak.'' (Boldwood/Mr. Boldwood/BOLDWOOD)
said Boldwood.
``I shall of course see you here to-night. Make yourself merry. I am deter- mined that neither expense nor trouble shall be spared.'' (unknown)
``I'll try to be here, sir, though perhaps it may not be very early.'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
said Gabriel, quietly.
``I am glad indeed to see such a change in `ee from what it used to be.'' (unknown)
``Yes-i must own it-i am bright to-night: cheerful and more than cheerful-so much so that I am almost sad again with the sense that all of it is passing away. And sometimes, when I am excessively hopeful and blithe, a trouble is looming in the distance: so that I often get to look upon gloom in me with content, and to fear a happy mood. Still this may be absurd-i feel that it is absurd. Perhaps my day is dawning at last.'' (unknown)
``I hope it `ill be a long and a fair one.'' (unknown)
``Thank you -- thank you. Yet perhaps my cheerful mess rests on a slender hope. And yet I trust my hope. It is faith, not hope. I think this time I reckon with my host. -- Oak, my hands are a little shaky, or some- thing; I can't tie this neckerchief properly. Perhaps you will tie it for me. The fact is, I have not been well lately, you know.'' (unknown)
``I am sorry to hear that, sir.'' (unknown)
``Oh, it's nothing. I want it done as well as you can, please. Is there any late knot in fashion, Oak?'' (unknown)
``I don't know, sir.'' (unknown)
said Oak. His (Boldwood) tone had sunk to sadness. Boldwood approached Gabriel, and as Oak tied the neckerchief the farmer went on feverishly --
``Does a woman keep her (woman) promise, Gabriel?'' (the farmer)
``If it is not inconvenient to her (woman) she (woman) may.'' (unknown)
''-- Or rather an implied promise.'' (unknown)
``I won't answer for her (woman) implying.'' (Gabriel/Oak/Gabriel Oak)
said Oak, with faint bitterness.
``That's a word as full o' holes as a sieve with them.'' (unknown)
Oak, don't talk like that. You have got quite cynical lately -- how is it? We seem to have shifted our positions: I have become the young and hopeful man, and you the old and unbelieving one. However, does a woman keep a promise, not to marry, but to enter on an engagement to marry at some time? Now you know women better than I -- tell me.'' ``I am afeard you honour my understanding too much. However, she (woman) may keep such a promise, if it is made with an honest meaning to repair a wrong.'' ``It has not gone far yet, but I think it will soon -- yes, I know it will.'' he (man) said, in an impulsive whisper. ``I have pressed her (woman) upon the subject, and she (woman) inclines to be kind to me, and to think of me as a husband at a long future time, and that's enough for me. How can I expect more? She (woman) has a notion that a woman should not marry within seven years of her (woman) husband's disappearance -- that her (woman) own self shouldn't, I mean -- because his (husband) body was not found. It may be merely this legal reason which influences her (woman), or it may be a religious one, but she (woman) is reluctant to talk on the point- Yet she (woman) has promised -- implied -- that she (woman) will ratify an engagement to-night.'' ``Seven years.'' murmured Oak. ``No, no -- it's no such thing!
'' he (man) said, with im- patience. Five years, nine months, and a few days. Fifteen months nearly have passed since he (man) vanished, and is there anything so wonderful in an engagement of little more than five years?'' (unknown)
``It seems long in a forward view. Don't build too much upon such promises, sir. Remember, you have once be'n deceived. Her (woman) meaning may be good; but there -- she (woman)'s young yet.'' (unknown)
``Deceived? Never!'' (Boldwood/Mr. Boldwood/BOLDWOOD)
said Boldwood, vehemently.
``She (woman) never promised me at that first time, and hence she (woman) did not break her (woman) promise! If she (woman) promises me, she (woman)'ll marry me, Bathsheba is a woman to her (woman) word.'' (White)
IV Troy was sitting in a corner of The White Hart tavern at Casterbridge, smoking and drinking a steaming mixture from a glass. A knock was given at the door, and Pennyways entered.
``Well, have you seen him (me)?'' (unknown)
Troy inquired, pointing to a chair.
``Boldwood?'' (unknown)
``No -- Lawyer Long.'' (unknown)
``He (Long) wadn' at home. I went there first, too.'' (unknown)
``That's a nuisance.'' (unknown)
''`Tis rather, I suppose.'' (unknown)
``Yet I don't see that, because a man appears to be drowned and was not, he (man) should be liable for anything. I shan't ask any lawyer -- not I.'' (unknown)
``But that's not it, exactly. If a man changes his (man) name and so forth, and takes steps to deceive the world and his (man) own wife, he (man)'s a cheat, and that in the eye of the law is ayless a rogue, and that is ayless a lammocken vagabond; and that's a punishable situation.'' (unknown)
``Ha-ha! Well done, Pennyways.'' (Troy/Mrs. Troy)
Troy had laughed, but it was with some anxiety that he (Hart) said,
``Now, what I want to know is this, do you think there's really anything going on between her (wife) and Boldwood? Upon my soul, I should never have believed it! How she (wife). must detest me! Have you found out whether she (wife) has encouraged him (Boldwood)?'' (he)
``I haen't been able to learn. There's a deal of feeling on his (Boldwood) side seemingly, but I don't answer for her (wife). I didn't know a word about any such thing till yesterday, and all I heard then was that she (wife) was gwine to the party at his (Boldwood) house to-night. This is the first time she (wife) has ever gone there, they say. And they say that she (wife)'ve not so much as spoke to him (Boldwood) since they were at Greenhill Fair: but what can folk believe o`t? How- ever, she (wife)'s not fond of him (Boldwood) -- quite offish and quite care less, I know.'' (unknown)
``I'm not so sure of that... She (wife)'s a handsome woman, Pennyways, is she (wife) not? Own that you never saw a finer or more splendid creature in your life. Upon my honour, when I set eyes upon her (wife) that day I wondered what I could have been made of to be able to leave her (wife) by herself so long. And then I was hampered with that bothering show, which I'm free of at last, thank the stars.'' (He)
He (Hart) smoked on awhile, and then added,
``How did she (wife) look when you passed by yesterday?'' (He)
``Oh, she (wife) took no great heed of me, ye may well fancy; but she (wife) looked well enough, far's I know. Just flashed her (wife) haughty eyes upon my poor scram body, and then let them go past me to what was yond, much as if I'd been no more than a leafless tree. She (wife) had just got off her (wife) mare to look at the last wring-down of cider for the year; she (wife) had been riding, and so her (wife) colours were up and her (wife) breath rather quick, so that her (wife) bosom plimmed and feli-plimmed and feli-every time plain to my eye. Ay, and there were the fellers round her (wife) wringing down the cheese and bustling about and saying, Ware o' the pommy, ma'am: `twill spoil yer gown. ``Never mind me,'' says she (Troy). Then Gabe brought her (Troy) some of the new cider, and she (Troy) must needs go drinking it through a strawmote, and not in a nateral way at all. ``Liddy,'' says she (Troy), ``bring indoors a few gallons, and I'll make some cider-wine.
'' Sergeant, I was no more to her (Troy) than a morsel of scroffin the fuel house!'' (I)
``I must go and find her (wife) out at once -- O yes, I see that-i must go. Oak is head man still, isn't he (man)?'' (unknown)
``Yes, 'a b`lieve. And at Little Weatherbury Farm too. He (man) manages everything.'' (unknown)
``Twill puzzle him (man) to manage her (wife), or any other man of his (man) compass!'' (unknown)
``I don't know about that. She (wife) can't do without him (man), and knowing it well he (man)'s pretty independent. And she (wife)'ve a few soft corners to her (wife) mind, though I've never been able to get into one, the devil's in't!'' (unknown)
``Ah baily she (wife)'s a notch above you, and you must own it: a higher class of animal-a finer tissue. How- ever, stick to me, and neither this haughty goddess, dashing piece of womanhood, Juno-wife of mine -LRB-Juno was a goddess, you know-RRB-, nor anybody else shall hurt you. But all this wants looking into, I perceive. What with one thing and another, I see that my work is well cut out for me.'' (unknown)
V
``How do I look to-night, Liddy?'' (Bathsheba/Bathsheba Everdene/BATHSHEBA)
said Bathsheba, giving a final adjustment to her (Troy) dress before leaving the glass.
``I never saw you look so well before. Yes-i'll tell you when you looked like it -- that night, a year and a half ago, when you came in so wildlike, and scolded us for making remarks about you and Mr. Troy.'' (unknown)
``Everybody will think that I am setting myself to captivate Mr. Boldwood, I suppose.'' (she)
she (Troy) murmured. ``At least they'll say so. Can't my hair be brushed down a little flatter? I dread going -- yet I dread the risk of wounding him (Boldwood) by staying away.``Anyhow, ma'am, you can't well be dressed plainer than you are, unless you go in sackcloth at once.
``Tis your excitement is what makes you look so noticeable to-night.'' (unknown)
``I don't know what's the matter, I feel wretched at one time, and buoyant at another. I wish I could have continued quite alone as I have been for the last year or so, with no hopes and no fears, and no pleasure and no grief. ``Now just suppose Mr. Boldwood should ask you -- only just suppose it -- to run away with him (Boldwood), what would you do, ma'am?'' ``Liddy -- none of that.'' said Bathsheba, gravely. ``Mind, I won't hear joking on any such matter. Do you hear?'' ``I beg pardon, ma'am. But knowing what rum things we women be, I just said -- however, I won't speak of it again.'' ``No marrying for me yet for many a year; if ever,
``twill be for reasons very, very different from those you think, or others will believe! Now get my cloak, for it is time to go.'' (me)
VI ``Oak, said Boldwood, ``before you go I want to mention what has been passing in my mind lately -- that little arrangement we made about your share in the farm I mean. That share is small, too small, consider- ing how little I attend to business now, and how much time and thought you give to it. Well, since the world is brightening for me, I want to show my sense of it by increasing your proportion in the partnership. I'll make a memorandum of the arrangement which struck me as likely to be convenient, for I haven't time to talk about it now; and then we'll discuss it at our leisure. My intention is ultimately to retire from the manage- ment altogether, and until you can take all the expendi- ture upon your shoulders, I'll be a sleeping partner in the stock. Then, if I marry her (I) -- and I hope-i feel I shall, why -- -- '' ``Pray don't speak of it, sir.'' said Oak, hastily. ``We don't know what may happen. So many upsets may befall `ee. There's many a slip, as they say -- and I would advise you-i know you'll pardon me this once -- not to be TOO SURE.'' ``I know, I know. But the feeling I have about in- creasing your share is on account of what I know of you Oak, I have learnt a little about your secret: your interest in her (I) is more than that of bailiff for an em- ployer. But you have behaved like a man, and I, as a sort of successful rival-successful partly through your goodness of heart -- should like definitely to show my sense of your friendship under what must have been a great pain to you.'' ``O that's not necessary, thank `ee.'' said Oak, hurriedly. ``I must get used to such as that; other men have, and so shall I.'' Oak then left him (Sergeant). He (Sergeant) was uneasy on Boldwood's account, for he (Sergeant) saw anew that this constant passion of the farmer made him (Sergeant) not the man he (Sergeant) once had been. As Boldwood continued awhile in his (Boldwood) room alone -- ready and dressed to receive his (Boldwood) company -- the mood of anxiety about his (Boldwood) appearance seemed to pass away, and to be succeeded by a deep solemnity. He (Boldwood) looked out of the window, and regarded the dim outline of the trees upon the sky, and the twilight deepening to darkness. Then he (Boldwood) went to a locked closet, and took from a locked drawer therein a small circular case the size of a pillbox, and was about to put it into his (Boldwood) pocket. But he (Boldwood) lingered to open the cover and take a momentary glance inside. It contained a woman's finger-ring, set all the way round with small diamonds, and from its appearance had evidently been recently purchased. Boldwood's eyes dwelt upon its many sparkles a long time, though that its material aspect concerned him (Boldwood) little was plain from his (Boldwood) manner and mien, which were those of a mind following out the presumed thread of that jewel's future history. The noise of wheels at the front of the house became audible. Boldwood closed the box, stowed it away carefully in his (Boldwood) pocket, and went out upon the landing. The old man who was his (man) indoor factotum came at the same moment to the foot of the stairs. ``They be coming, sir -- lots of 'em -- a-foot and a- driving!'' ``I was coming down this moment. Those wheels I heard -- is it Mrs. Troy?'' ``No, sir -- `tis not she (Troy) yet.'' A reserved and sombre expression had returned to Boldwood's face again, but it poorly cloaked his (Boldwood) feel- ings when he (Boldwood) pronounced Bathsheba's name; and his (Boldwood) feverish anxiety continued to show its existence by a galloping motion of his (Boldwood) fingers upon the side of his (Boldwood) thigh as he (Boldwood) went down the stairs. VII ``How does this cover me?'' said Troy to Pennyways, ``Nobody would recognize me now, I'm sure.'' He (Boldwood) was buttoning on a heavy grey overcoat of Noachian cut, with cape and high collar, the latter being erect and rigid, like a girdling wall, and nearly reaching to the verge of travelling cap which was pulled down over his (Boldwood) ears. Pennyways snuffed the candle, and then looked up and deliberately inspected Troy ``You've made up your mind to go then?'' he (Boldwood) said. ``Made up my mind? Yes; of course I have.'' ``Why not write to her (Troy)?
``Tis a very queer corner that you have got into, sergeant. You see all these things will come to light if you go back, and they won't sound well at all. Faith, if I was you I'd even bide as you be -- a single man of the name of Francis. A good wife is good, but the best wife is not so good as no wife at all. Now that's my outspoke mind, and I've been called a long-headed feller here and there.'' (unknown)
``All nonsense!'' (unknown)
said Troy, angrily.
``There she (wife) is with plenty of money, and a house and farm, and horses, and comfort, and here am I living from hand to mouth -- a needy adventurer. Besides, it is no use talking now; it is too late, and I am glad of it; I've been seen and recognized here this very afternoon. I should have gone back to her (wife) the day after the fair, if it hadn't been for you talking about the law, and rubbish about getting a separation; and I don't put it off any longer. What the deuce put it into my head to run away at all, I can't think! Humbugging sentiment -- that's what it was. But what man on earth was to know that his (man) wife would be in such a hurry to get rid of his (man) name!'' (unknown)
``I should have known it. She (wife)'s bad enough for anything.'' (unknown)
``Pennyways, mind who you are talking to.'' (unknown)
``Well, sergeant, all I say is this, that if I were you I'd go abroad again where I came from -- `tisn't too late to do it now. I wouldn't stir up the business and get a bad name for the sake of living with her (wife) -- for all that about your play-acting is sure to come out, you know, although you think otherwise. My eyes and limbs, there'll be a racket if you go back just now -- in the middle of Bold- wood's Christmasing!'' (unknown)
``H'm, yes. I expect I shall not be a very welcome guest if he (guest) has her (wife) there.'' (the sergeant)
said the sergeant, with a slight laugh.
``A sort of Alonzo the Brave; and when I go in the guests will sit in silence and fear, and all laughter and pleasure will be hushed, and the lights in the chamber burn blue, and the worms -- Ugh, horrible! -- Ring for some more brandy, Pennyways, I felt an awful shudder just then! Well, what is there besides? A stick-i must have a walking-stick.'' (Pennyways)
Pennyways now felt himself to be in something of a difficulty, for should Bathsheba and Troy become recon- ciled it would be necessary to regain her (Troy) good opinion if he (sergeant) would secure the patronage of her (Troy) husband. I sometimes think she (Troy) likes you yet, and is a good woman at bottom.'' he (sergeant) said, as a saving sentence. ``But there's no telling to a certainty from a body's outside. Well, you'll do as you like about going, of course, sergeant, and as for me, I'll do as you tell me.'' ``Now, let me see what the time is.'' said Troy, after emptying his (sergeant) glass in one draught as he (sergeant) stood.
``Half- past six o'clock. I shall not hurry along the road, and shall be there then before nine.'' (Boldwood/Mr. Boldwood/BOLDWOOD)

CHAPTER LIII

CONCURRITUR -- HORAE MOMENTO

OUTSIDE the front of Boldwood's house a group of men stood in the dark, with their faces towards the door, which occasionally opened and closed for the passage of some guest or servant, when a golden rod of light would stripe the ground for the moment and vanish again, leaving nothing outside but the glowworm shine of the pale lamp amid the evergreens over the door.

``He (sergeant) was seen in Casterbridge this afternoon -- so the boy said.'' (unknown)
one of them remarked in a whisper.
``And l for one believe it. His (boy) body was never found, you know.'' (unknown)
''`Tis a strange story.'' (unknown)
said the next.
``You may depend upon't that she (you) knows nothing about it.'' (unknown)
``Not a word.'' (unknown)
``Perhaps he (boy) don't mean that she (you) shall.'' (another man)
said another man.
``If he (boy)'s alive and here in the neighbourhood, he (boy) means mischief.'' (unknown)
said the first.
``Poor young thing: I do pity her (you), if `tis true. He (boy)'ll drag her (you) to the dogs.'' (unknown)
``O no; he (boy)'ll settle down quiet enough.'' (unknown)
said one disposed to take a more hopeful view of the case.
``What a fool she (you) must have been ever to have had anything to do with the man! She (you) is so self-willed and independent too, that one is more minded to say it serves her (you) right than pity her (you).'' (unknown)
``No, no. I don't hold with `ee there. She (you) was no otherwise than a girl mind, and how could she (you) tell what the man was made of? If `tis really true, `tis too hard a punishment, and more than she (you) ought to hae. -- Hullo, who's that?'' (unknown)
This was to some footsteps that were heard approaching.
``William Smallbury.'' (unknown)
said a dim figure in the shades, coming up and joining them.
``Dark as a hedge, to- night, isn't it? I all but missed the plank over the river ath`art there in the bottom -- never did such a thing before in my life. Be ye any of Boldwood's workfolk?'' (He)
He (man) peered into their faces.
``Yes -- all o' us. We met here a few minutes ago.'' (unknown)
``Oh, I hear now -- that's Sam Samway: thought I knowed the voice, too. Going in?'' (unknown)
``Presently. But I say, William.'' (Samway)
Samway whispered,
``have ye heard this strange tale?'' (Samway)
``What -- that about Sergeant Troy being seen, d'ye mean, souls?'' (Liddy/Smallbury/Liddy Smallbury)
said Smallbury, also lowering his (Smallbury) voice.
``Ay: in Casterbridge.'' (unknown)
``Yes, I have. Laban Tall named a hint of it to me but now -- but I don't think it. Hark, here Laban comes himself, 'a b`lieve.'' (unknown)
A footstep drew near.
``Laban?'' (unknown)
``Yes, `tis I.'' (unknown)
said Tall.
``Have ye heard any more about that?'' (unknown)
``No.'' (unknown)
said Tall, joining the group.
``And I'm in- clined to think we'd better keep quiet. If so be `tis not true, `twill flurry her (ye), and do her (ye) much harm to repeat it; and if so be `tis true, `twill do no good to forestall her (ye) time o' trouble. God send that it mid be a lie, for though Henery Fray and some of 'em do speak against her (ye), she (ye)'s never been anything but fair to me. She (ye)'s hot and hasty, but she (ye)'s a brave girl who'll never tell a lie however much the truth may harm her (ye), and I've no cause to wish her (ye) evil.'' (unknown)
``She (ye) never do tell women's little lies, that's true; and `tis a thing that can be said of very few. Ay, all the harm she (ye) thinks she (ye) says to yer face: there's nothing underhand wi' her (ye).'' (every man)
They stood silent then, every man busied with his (man) own thoughts, during which interval sounds of merri- ment could be heard within. Then the front door again opened, the rays streamed out, the wellknown form of Boldwood was seen in the rectangular area of light, the door closed, and Boldwood walked slowly down the path.
''`Tis master.'' (Boldwood/Mr. Boldwood/BOLDWOOD)
one of the men whispered, as he (Boldwood) neared them. ``We'd better stand quiet -- he (ye)'ll go in again directly. He (ye) would think it unseemly o' us to be loitering here. Boldwood came on, and passed by the men without seeing them, they being under the bushes on the grass. He (Boldwood) paused, leant over the gate, and breathed a long breath. They heard low words come from him (Boldwood). ``I hope to God she (ye)'ll come, or this night will be nothing but misery to me! O my darling, my darling, why do you keep me in suspense like this?'' He (Boldwood) said this to himself, and they all distinctly heard it. Boldwood remained silent after that, and the noise from indoors was again just audible, until, a few minutes later, light wheels could be distinguished coming down the hill. They drew nearer, and ceased at the gate. Boldwood hastened back to the door, and opened it; and the light shone upon Bathsheba coming up the path. Boldwood compressed his (Boldwood) emotion to mere welcome: the men marked her (Boldwood) light laugh and apology as she (Boldwood) met him (Boldwood): he (Boldwood) took her (Boldwood) into the house; and the door closed again. ``Gracious heaven, I didn't know it was like that with him (God)!'' said one of the men. ``I thought that fancy of his (God) was over long ago.
``You don't know much of master, if you thought that.'' (Samway)
said Samway.
``I wouldn't he (God) should know we heard what 'a said for the world.'' (unknown)
remarked a third.
``I wish we had told of the report at once.'' (unknown)
the first uneasily continued.
``More harm may come of this than we know of. Poor Mr. Boldwood, it will, be hard upon en. I wish Troy was in -- -- Well, God forgive me for such a wish! A scoundrel to play a poor wife such tricks. Nothing has prospered in Weatherbury since he (God) came here. And now I've no heart to go in. Let's look into Warren's for a few minutes first, shall us, neighbours?'' (Liddy/Smallbury/Liddy Smallbury)
Samway, Tall, and Smallbury agreed to go to Warren's, and went out at the gate, the remaining ones entering the house. The three soon drew near the malt-house, approaching it from the adjoining orchard, and not by way of the street. The pane of glass was illuminated as usual. Smallbury was a little in advance of the rest when, pausing, he (Smallbury) turned suddenly to his (Smallbury) companions and said,
``Hist! See there.'' (companions)
The light from the pane was now perceived to be shining not upon the ivied wall as usual, but upon some object close to the glass. It was a human face.
``Let's come closer.'' (unknown)
whispered Samway; and they approached on tiptoe. There was no disbelieving the report any longer. Troy's face was almost close to the pane, and he (Smallbury) was looking in. Not only was he (Smallbury) looking in, but he (Smallbury) appeared to have been arrested by a conversation which was in progress in the malt-house, the voices of the interlocutors being those of Oak and the maltster.
``The spree is all in her (wife) honour, isn't it -- hey?'' (the man)
said the old man.
``Although he (Warren) made believe `tis only keeping up o' Christmas?'' (unknown)
``I cannot say.'' (unknown)
replied Oak.
``O `tis true enough, faith. I cannot understand Farmer Boldwood being such a fool at his (Boldwood) time of life as to ho and hanker after thik woman in the way 'a do, and she (woman) not care a bit about en.'' (The men)
The men, after recognizing Troy's features, withdrew across the orchard as quietly as they had come. The air was big with Bathsheba's fortunes to-night: every word everywhere concerned her (Smallbury). When they were quite out of earshot all by one instinct paused.
``It gave me quite a turn -- his (Boldwood) face.'' (unknown)
said Tall, breathing.
``And so it did me.'' (Samway)
said Samway.
``What's to be done?'' (unknown)
``I don't see that `tis any business of ours.'' (Liddy/Smallbury/Liddy Smallbury)
Smallbury murmured dubiously. ``But it is! ``Tis a thing which is everybody's business, said Samway.
``We know very well that master's on a wrong tack, and that she (woman)'s quite in the dark, and we should let 'em know at once. Laban, you know her (woman) best -- you'd better go and ask to speak to her (woman).'' (unknown)
``I bain't fit for any such thing.'' (Laban)
said Laban, nervously.
``I should think William ought to do it if anybody. He (William)'s oldest.'' (unknown)
``I shall have nothing to do with it.'' (Liddy/Smallbury/Liddy Smallbury)
said Smallbury.
''`Tis a ticklish business altogether. Why, he (Smallbury)'ll go on to her (Smallbury) himself in a few minutes, ye'll see.'' (Liddy/Smallbury/Liddy Smallbury)
``We don't know that he (William) will. Come, Laban.'' (unknown)
``Very well, if I must I must, I suppose.'' (unknown)
Tall reluct- antly answered.
``What must I say?'' (unknown)
``Just ask to see master.'' (unknown)
``O no; I shan't speak to Mr. Boldwood. If I tell anybody, `twill be mistress.'' (unknown)
``Very well.'' (Samway)
said Samway. Laban then went to the door. When he (Smallbury) opened it the hum of bustle rolled out as a wave upon a still strand -- the assemblage being immediately inside the hall-and was deadened to a murmur as he (Smallbury) closed it again. Each man waited intently, and looked around at the dark tree tops gently rocking against the sky and occasionally shivering in a slight wind, as if he (man) took interest in the scene, which neither did. One of them began walking up and down, and then came to where he (man) started from and stopped again, with a sense that walking was thing not worth doing now.
``I should think Laban must have seen mistress by this time.'' (Liddy/Smallbury/Liddy Smallbury)
said Smallbury, breaking the silence.
``Per- haps she (mistress) won't come and speak to him (Boldwood).'' (unknown)
The door opened. Tall appeared, and joined them
``Well?'' (unknown)
said both.
``I didn't like to ask for her (mistress) after all.'' (Laban)
Laban faltered out.
``They were all in such a stir, trying to put a little spirit into the party. Somehow the fun seems to hang fire, though everything's there that a heart can desire, and I couldn't for my soul interfere and throw damp upon it -- if 'twas to save my life, I couldn't!'' (unknown)
``I suppose we had better all go in together.'' (Samway)
said Samway, gloomily.
``Perhaps I may have a chance of saying a word to master.'' (the men)
So the men entered the hall, which was the room selected and arranged for the gathering because of its size. The younger men and maids were at last just beginning to dance. Bathsheba had been perplexed how to act, for she (them) was not much more than a slim young maid herself, and the weight of stateliness sat heavy upon her (them). Sometimes she (them) thought she (them) ought not to have come under any circumstances; then she (them) considered what cold unkindness that would have been, and finally resolved upon the middle course of staying for about an hour only, and gliding off unobserved, having from the first made up her (them) mind that she (them) could on no account dance, sing, or take any active part in the proceedings. Her (them) allotted hour having been passed in chatting and looking on, Bathsheba told Liddy not to hurry her (them)- self, and went to the small parlour to prepare for departure, which, like the hall, was decorated with holly and ivy, and well lighted up. Nobody was in the room, but she (them) had hardly been there a moment when the master of the house entered.
``Mrs. Troy -- you are not going?'' (he)
he (master) said.
``We've hardly begun!'' (unknown)
``If you'll excuse me, I should like to go now.'' (she)
Her (them) manner was restive, for she (them) remembered her (them) promise, and imagined what he (master) was about to say.
``But as it is not late.'' (she)
she (them) added,
``I can walk home, and leave my man and Liddy to come when they choose.'' (she)
``I've been trying to get an opportunity of speaking to you.'' (Boldwood/Mr. Boldwood/BOLDWOOD)
said Boldwood.
``You know perhaps what I long to say?'' (Bathsheba)
Bathsheba silently looked on the floor.
``You do give it?'' (he)
he (Boldwood) said, eagerly.
``What?'' (she)
she (them) whispered.
``Now, that's evasion! Why, the promise. I don't want to intrude upon you at all, or to let it become known to anybody. But do give your word! A mere business compact, you know, between two people who are beyond the influence of passion.'' (Boldwood/Mr. Boldwood/BOLDWOOD)
Boldwood knew how false this picture was as regarded himself; but he (Boldwood) had proved that it was the only tone in which she (them) would allow him (Boldwood) to approach her (them).
``A promise to marry me at the end of five years and three-quarters. You owe it to me!'' (unknown)
``I feel that I do.'' (Bathsheba/Bathsheba Everdene/BATHSHEBA)
said Bathsheba;
``that is, if you demand it. But I am a changed woman -- an unhappy woman -- and not -- not -- -- '' (Bathsheba/Bathsheba Everdene/BATHSHEBA)
``You are still a very beautiful woman, said Boldwood. Honesty and pure conviction suggested the remark, unaccompanied by any perception that it might have been adopted by blunt flattery to soothe and win her (woman). However, it had not much effect now, for for she (woman) said, in a passionless murmur which was in itself a proof of her (woman) words: ``I have no feeling in the matter at all. And I don't at all know what is right to do in my diddicult position, and I have nobody to advise me. But I give my promise, if I must. I give it as the rendering of a debt, conditionally, of course, on my being a widow.'' ``You'll marry me between five and six years hence?'' ``Don't press me too hard. I'll marry nobody else.'' ``But surely you will name the time, or there's nothing in the promise at all?
'' O, I don't know, pray let me go!'' (she)
she (them) said, her (them) bosom beginning to rise.
``I am afraid what to do! want to be just to you, and to be that seems to be wrong- ing myself, and perhaps it is breaking the commandments. There is considerable doubt of his (my) death, and then it is dreadful; let me ask a solicitor, Mr. Boldwood, if I ought or no!'' (unknown)
``Say the words, dear one, and the subject shall be dismissed; a blissful loving intimacy of six years, and then marriage -- O Bathsheba, say them!'' (he)
he (Boldwood) begged in a husky voice, unable to sustain the forms of mere friendship any longer.
``Promise yourself to me; I deserve it, indeed I do, for I have loved you more than anybody in the world! And if I said hasty words and showed uncalled-for heat of manner towards you, believe me, dear, I did not mean to distress you; I was in agony, Bathsheba, and I did not know what I said. You wouldn't let a dog suffer what I have suffered, could you but know it! Sometimes I shrink from your knowing what I have felt for you, and sometimes I am distressed that all of it you never will know. Be gracious, and give up a little to me, when I would give up my life for you!'' (she)
The trimmings of her (them) dress, as they quivered against the light, showed how agitated she (them) was, and at last she (them) burst out crying.
``And you'll not -- press me -- about anything more -- if I say in five or six years?'' (she)
she (them) sobbed, when she (them) had power to frame the words.
``Yes, then I'll leave it to time.'' (unknown)
``Very well. If he (you) does not return, I'll marry you in six years from this day, if we both live.'' (she)
she (them) said solemnly.
``And you'll take this as a token from me.'' (Boldwood/Mr. Boldwood/BOLDWOOD)
Boldwood had come close to her (them) side, and now he (Boldwood) clasped one of her (them) hands in both his (Boldwood) own, and lifted it to his (Boldwood) breast.
``What is it? Oh I cannot wear a ring!'' (she)
she (them) ex- claimed, on seeing what he (Boldwood) held;
``besides, I wouldn't have a soul know that it's an engagement! Perhaps it is improper? Besides, we are not engaged in the usual sense, are we? Don't insist, Mr. Boldwood -- don't!'' (he)
In her (them) trouble at not being able to get her (them) hand away from him (Boldwood) at once, she (them) stamped passionately on the floor with one foot, and tears crowded to her (them) eyes again.
``It means simply a pledge -- no sentiment -- the seal of a practical compact.'' (he)
he (Boldwood) said more quietly, but still retaining her (them) hand in his (Boldwood) firm grasp.
``Come, now!'' (Boldwood/Mr. Boldwood/BOLDWOOD)
And Boldwood slipped the ring on her (them) finger.
``I cannot wear it.'' (she)
she (them) said, weeping as if her (them) heart would break.
``You frighten me, almost. So wild a scheme! Please let me go home!'' (unknown)
``Only to-night: wear it just to-night, to please me!'' (Bathsheba/Bathsheba Everdene/BATHSHEBA)
Bathsheba sat down in a chair, and buried her (them) face in her (them) handkerchief, though Boldwood kept her (them) hand yet. At length she (them) said, in a sort of hopeless whisper --
``Very well, then, I will to-night, if you wish it so earnestly. Now loosen my hand; I will, indeed I will wear it to-night.'' (she)
``And it shall be the beginning of a pleasant secret courtship of six years, with a wedding at the end?'' (unknown)
``It must be, I suppose, since you will have it so!'' (she)
she (them) said, fairly beaten into non-resistance. Boldwood pressed her (them) hand, and allowed it to drop in her (them) lap.
``I am happy now.'' (he)
he (Boldwood) said.
``God bless you!'' (He)
He (Boldwood) left the room, and when he (Boldwood) thought she (them) might be sufficiently composed sent one of the maids to her (them) Bathsheba cloaked the effects of the late scene as she (them) best could, followed the girl, and in a few moments came downstairs with her (them) hat and cloak on, ready to go. To get to the door it was necessary to pass through the hall, and before doing so she (them) paused on the bottom of the staircase which descended into one corner, to take a last look at the gathering. There was no music or dancing in progress just now. At the lower end, which had been arranged for the work- folk specially, a group conversed in whispers, and with clouded looks. Boldwood was standing by the fireplace, and he (Boldwood), too, though so absorbed in visions arising from her (them) promise that he (Boldwood) scarcely saw anything, seemed at that moment to have observed their peculiar manner, and their looks askance.
``What is it you are in doubt about, men?'' (he)
he (Boldwood) said. One of them turned and replied uneasily:
``It was something Laban heard of, that's all, sir.'' (unknown)
``News? Anybody married or engaged, born or dead?'' (the farmer)
inquired the farmer, gaily.
``Tell it to us, Tall. One would think from your looks and mysterious ways that it was something very dreadful indeed.'' (unknown)
``O no, sir, nobody is dead.'' (unknown)
said Tall.
``I wish somebody was.'' (Samway)
said Samway, in a whisper.
``What do you say, Samway?'' (Boldwood/Mr. Boldwood/BOLDWOOD)
asked Boldwood, some- what sharply.
``If you have anything to say, speak out; if not, get up another dance.'' (unknown)
``Mrs. Troy has come downstairs.'' (unknown)
said Samway to Tall.
``If you want to tell her (Troy), you had better do it now.'' (unknown)
``Do you know what they mean?'' (the farmer)
the farmer asked Bathsheba, across the room.
``I don't in the least,'' (Bathsheba/Bathsheba Everdene/BATHSHEBA)
said Bathsheba. There was a smart rapping at the door. One of the men opened it instantly, and went outside.
``Mrs. Troy is wanted.'' (he)
he (farmer) said, on returning.
``Quite ready.'' (Bathsheba/Bathsheba Everdene/BATHSHEBA)
said Bathsheba.
``Though I didn't tell them to send.'' (unknown)
``It is a stranger, ma'am.'' (the man)
said the man by the door.
``A stranger?'' (she)
she (them) said.
``Ask him (stranger) to come in.'' (Boldwood/Mr. Boldwood/BOLDWOOD)
said Boldwood. The message was given, and Troy, wrapped up to his (Boldwood) eyes as we have seen him (Boldwood), stood in the doorway. There was an unearthly silence, all looking towards the newcomer. Those who had just learnt that he (newcomer) was in the neighbourhood recognized him (newcomer) instantly; those who did not were perplexed. Nobody noted Bathsheba. She (them) was leaning on the stairs. Her (them) brow had heavily contracted; her (them) whole face was pallid, her (them) lips apart, her (them) eyes rigidly staring at their visitor. Boldwood was among those who did not notice that he (Boldwood) was Troy.
``Come in, come in!'' (he)
he (Boldwood) repeated, cheerfully,
``and drain a Christmas beaker with us, stranger!'' (he)
Troy next advanced into the middle of the room, took off his (Boldwood) cap, turned down his (Boldwood) coat-collar, and looked Boldwood in the face. Even then Boldwood did not recognize that the impersonator of Heaven's persistent irony towards him (Boldwood), who had once before broken in upon his (Boldwood) bliss, scourged him (Boldwood), and snatched his (Boldwood) delight away, had come to do these things a second time. Troy began to laugh a mechanical laugh: Boldwood recognized him (Boldwood) now. Troy turned to Bathsheba. The poor girl's wretched- ness at this time was beyond all fancy or narration. She (girl) had sunk down on the lowest stair; and there she (girl) sat, her (girl) mouth blue and dry, and her (girl) dark eyes fixed vacantly upon him (Boldwood), as if she (girl) wondered whether it were not all a terrible illusion. Then Troy spoke.
``Bathsheba, I come here for you!'' (She)
She (girl) made no reply. ``Come home with me: come! Bathsheba moved her (stranger) feet a little, but did not rise. Troy went across to her (Troy). ``Come, madam, do you hear what I say?'' he (Boldwood) said, peremptorily. A strange voice came from the fireplace -- a voice sounding far off and confined, as if from a dungeon. Hardly a soul in the assembly recognized the thin tones to be those of Boldwood. Sudden dispaire had trans- formed him (Boldwood). ``Bathsheba, go with your husband!'' Nevertheless, she (girl) did not move. The truth was that Bathsheba was beyond the pale of activity -- and yet not in a swoon. She (girl) was in a state of mental GUTTA SERENA; her (girl) mind was for the minute totally deprived of light at the same time no obscuration was apparent from without. Troy stretched out his (Boldwood) hand to pull her (Troy) her (Troy) towards him (Boldwood), when she (Troy) quickly shrank back. This visible dread of him (Boldwood) seemed to irritate Troy, and he (Boldwood) seized her (Troy) arm and pulled it sharply. Whether his (Boldwood) grasp pinched her (Troy), or whether his (Boldwood) mere touch was the 'cause, was never known, but at the moment of his (Boldwood) seizure she (Troy) writhed, and gave a quick, low scream. The scream had been heard but a few seconds When it was followed by sudden deafening report that echoed through the room and stupefied them all. The oak partition shook with the concussion, and the place was filled with grey smoke. In bewilderment they turned their eyes to Boldwood. at his (Boldwood) back, as stood before the fireplace, was a gun- rack, as is usual in farmhouses, constructed to hold two guns. When Bathsheba had cried out in her (Troy) husband's grasp, Boldwood's face of gnashing despair had changed. The veins had swollen, and a frenzied look had gleamed in his (Boldwood) eye. He (Boldwood) had turned quickly, taken one of the guns, cocked it, and at once discharged it at Troy. Troy fell. The distance apart of the two men was so small that the charge of shot did not spread in the least, but passed like a bullet into his (Boldwood) body. He (Boldwood) uttered a long guttural sigh -- there was a contraction -- an exten- sion -- then his (Boldwood) muscles relaxed, and he (Boldwood) lay still. Boldwood was seen through the smoke to be now again engaged with the gun. It was double-barrelled, and he (Boldwood) had, meanwhile, in some way fastened his (Boldwood) hand- kerchief to the trigger, and with his (Boldwood) foot on the other end was in the act of turning the second barrel upon himself. Samway his (Boldwood) man was the first to see this, and in the midst of the general horror darted up to him (Boldwood). Boldwood had already twitched the handkerchief, and the gun exploded a second time, sending its contents, by a timely blow from Samway, into the beam which crossed the ceiling. ``Well, it makes no difference!'' Boldwood gasped.
``There is another way for me to die.'' (unknown)
Then he (Boldwood) broke from Samway, crossed the room to Bathsheba, and kissed her (man) hand. He (Boldwood) put on his (Boldwood) hat, opened the door, and went into the darkness, nobody thinking of preventing him (Boldwood).

CHAPTER LIV

AFTER THE SHOCK

BOLDWOOD passed into the high road and turned in the direction of Casterbridge. Here he (Boldwood) walked at an even, steady pace over Yalbury Hill, along the dead level beyond, mounted Mellstock Hill, and between eleven and twelve o'clock crossed the Moor into the town. The streets were nearly deserted now, and the waving lamp-flames only lighted up rows of grey shop-shutters, and strips of white paving upon which his (Moor) step echoed as his (Moor) passed along. He (Moor) turned to the right, and halted before an archway of heavy stonework, which was closed by an iron studded pair of doors. This was the entrance to the gaol, and over it a lamp was fixed, the light en- abling the wretched traveller to find a bellpull. The small wicket at last opened, and a porter appeared. Boldwood stepped forward, and said some- thing in a low tone, when, after a delay, another man came. Boldwood entered, and the door was closed behind him (Boldwood), and he (Boldwood) walked the world no more. Long before this time Weatherbury had been thoroughly aroused, and the wild deed which had ter- minated Boldwood's merrymaking became known to all. Of those out of the house Oak was one of the first to hear of the catastrophe, and when he (Oak) entered the room, which was about five minutes after Boldwood's exit, the scene was terrible. All the female guests were huddled aghast against the walls like sheep in a storm, and the men were bewildered as to what to do. As for Bathsheba, she (Oak) had changed. She (Oak) was sitting on the floor beside the body of Troy, his (Boldwood) head pillowed in her (Oak) lap, where she (Oak) had herself lifted it. With one hand she (Oak) held her (Oak) handkerchief to his (Boldwood) breast and covered the wound, though scarcely a single drop of blood had flowed, and with the other she (Oak) tightly clasped one of his (Boldwood). The household convulsion had made her (Oak) herself again. The temporary coma had ceased, and activity had come with the necessity for it. Deeds of endur- ance, which seem ordinary in philosophy, are rare in conduct, and Bathsheba was astonishing all around her (Oak) now, for her (Oak) philosophy was her (Oak) conduct, and she (Oak) seldom thought practicable what she (Oak) did not practise.
